headline: The Guggenheim’s Greatest Hits Come Roaring Back
text: Of New York City’s major museum collections, the Guggenheim’s is the hardest to see, because so little of it is usually on view. Blame Frank Lloyd Wright’s design, that big empty well of light and air with a little art up the sides. Not that I object to the building. I’ve adored it since my first visit as an out-of-town kid in 1960, the year after it opened. There was art on the ramps then, but all I remember is thinking: spaceship. Still do.

headline: Reductress Takes Its Satirical Voice Beyond the Internet
text: Stumbling unaware into a standup show is a mistake New York City tourists make daily. But at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in Chelsea, on the second Thursday of January, audience members did not seem confused as to why they were sipping beer in a dark cellar, awaiting the first act of the monthly comedy night staged by Reductress, the soon-to-be four-year-old satirical online magazine. The self-selecting crowd appeared, like the site’s readership, to be made up of liberal-minded women.

headline: A Heroine Who Does Adulthood on Her Own Terms
text: ALL GROWN UP By Jami Attenberg 197 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.

headline: A Death in the I.C.U.
text: On a recent night, I watched a man with terminal cancer die in the intensive care unit.

headline: 1971 | Ostriches, a Six-Foot-Tall Gay Duck and John Shaft
text: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: Review: ‘The Sense of an Ending,’ and the Elusiveness of Truth
text: Adapted from a brief but emotionally potent 2011 novel by Julian Barnes, “The Sense of an Ending” initially honors its source material by taking clever, inventive cinematic liberties with it. The book, a first-person account of its aged protagonist, Tony Webster, has a bifurcated structure: “how I remembered these events” and “what really happened.” Flashbacks arrive in blink-and-you-miss-them bursts that then expand to explain the significance of a look or a gesture; memory becomes a form of time travel, putting Tony (Jim Broadbent) inside his own recollections, taking the place of his young self.

headline: Matters of Public Record: Rich Resource for Reporters
text: Back from Jerusalem, where he served as interim bureau chief from April to July of last year, the Times investigative reporter James Glanz was interested in doing a “cool story about cancer.”

headline: Butterfunk Kitchen
text: The menu in this restaurant in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, is built on the memories of Nana’s kitchen.

headline: Butterfunk Kitchen Is Driven by Soul Food and Built on Memories
text: “This,” the waitress said, stroking the glass jar on the table as if it were a beloved and dangerous pet. “It is not mild; it is not medium. It is hot. Go slow.”

headline: Samuel L. Jackson and Others on Black British Actors in American Roles
text: LONDON — The actor Samuel L. Jackson has sidled into a debate about the roles for black actors on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Donald Tusk Gets 2nd Term as President of European Council
text: BRUSSELS — Donald Tusk was appointed on Thursday to a second term as president of the European Council, one of the European Union’s governing bodies, despite objections from the government of his own country, Poland, that had created an unprecedented confrontation in Brussels.

headline: New York City to Get Less Federal Aid for Housing
text: President Donald J. Trump has yet to put his mark on the federal budget, but in a possible harbinger of leaner times to come, officials in New York City are already contending with declines in federal financing for programs that assist some of the city’s poorest residents.

headline: Will a Leak Reveal Trump’s Tax Returns? Don’t Hold Your Breath
text: WASHINGTON — The early days of the Trump administration have turned Washington into a land of leaks, with a national security adviser’s telephone calls, raw intelligence dossiers and confidential C.I.A. surveillance schemes spilling into the public. But the holy grail of leaks remains elusive: President Trump’s tax returns.

headline: Cars Will Talk to One Another. Exactly How Is Less Certain.
text: The Cadillac CTS is racing toward a blind corner, raising the anxiety of its passengers. Suddenly, a chime sounds and a “front cross traffic alert” warning flashes on a screen attached to the windshield. Even though there’s nothing visible ahead, the driver jams on the brakes — just as another Cadillac CTS jumps out from around the corner. Disaster averted.

headline: Driven | 2017 Ram 1500
text: The Ram 1500, having dropped the Dodge name, pampers like any modern truck these days with features found on luxury cars.

headline: Video Review: A Pickup Truck That’s Both Primal and Pampering
text: Pickups aren’t just big, they’re big business. The Ram 1500, with an engine note that announces its presence, can be better equipped than some luxury sedans.

headline: Woman Who Streamed Boyfriend’s Death by Police Faces Unrelated Assault Charge
text: By narrating the raw aftermath of a police shooting in a widely shared Facebook Live video last year, Diamond Reynolds turned the death of her boyfriend, Philando Castile, into a nationwide call for racial justice.

headline: From a Wedding Writer’s Notebook, 10 Views on Love
text: When writing for the weddings pages of The New York Times — which I have done since 1992, at first on a weekly basis and now occasionally — the job is to walk into a room full of well-dressed strangers and collect the best descriptions you can find about love and marriage, mostly love. It isn’t easy. For one thing, people sense a stranger in their midst as acutely as a herd of gazelles might, and they tend to scatter, or stare from a distance in a menacing way.

headline: Tech Roundup: Preventing Hacking From Happening to You
text: The documents revealed by WikiLeaks that indicate the Central Intelligence Agency has been sitting on a collection of spy-friendly software vulnerabilities are certainly intriguing. More worrisome, perhaps, is the question of who else knows about these security weaknesses.

headline: Tweaking Alerts From Google Calendar
text: Q. Google Calendar automatically warns me 10 minutes before my next appointment, but I’d like a little more notice. How do I increase the amount of time between warnings and meetings?

headline: WikiLeaks Will Help Tech Companies Fix Security Flaws, Assange Says
text: WASHINGTON — For years, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, has been derided as an anti-American anarchist, indiscriminate in publishing leaks and far too cozy with Russia. For more than four years, he has been hiding out in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London to avoid sexual assault investigators in Sweden.

headline: Kristen Stewart on Trump and Her New Movie, ‘Personal Shopper’
text: In 2015, Kristen Stewart became the first American actress to win a César Award, the French equivalent of an Oscar, for a role that was almost lost in translation: Valentine, the personal assistant to an aging movie star, in Olivier Assayas’s “Clouds of Sils Maria.”

headline: Is Trump Being Investigated? ‘No Comment,’ Justice Dept. Says
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s weekend Twitter message asserting that former President Barack Obama had tapped his phones forced the White House into ever more verbal contortions on Thursday as aides struggled to defend the president’s charge.

headline: Domenico Starnone’s New Novel Is Also a Piece in the Elena Ferrante Puzzle
text: TIESBy Domenico StarnoneTranslated by Jhumpa Lahiri150 pp. Europa Editions. Paper, $16.

headline: Michigan Plays Big Ten Tournament in Practice Uniforms
text: Michigan hit the floor for its Big Ten tournament opener with Illinois on Thursday looking a little unusual. The scene looked less like a conference championship than a Tuesday night at the Y.M.C.A.

headline: T’s 50 Best Photos From Fashion Month
text: Highlights from the fall/winter 2017 shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris — on and off the runway.

headline: Over a Century of Baking
text: For generations, the family-run Holtermann’s Bakery on Staten Island has been offering staples from bygone eras, like Pullman bread and meltaway cake.

headline: A Time Capsule in Every Pullman Loaf at This 139-Year-Old Bakery
text: Nestled in the heart of Staten Island, the neighborhoods of Great Kills and Richmondtown offer glimpses into the past, with centuries-old buildings, one of the last volunteer firefighter units in New York City, and Historic Richmond Town, a museum and farm that traces its history back to colonial times. In business now for 139 years, Holtermann’s Bakery, at 405 Arthur Kill Road, might not be the oldest time capsule. But to the hordes of loyal customers, many of whom have been stopping by for decades, it is probably the most delicious.

headline: With Trump in White House, Some Executives Ask, Why Not Me?
text: Having reached the top of a major corporation and amassed a fortune, chief executives often wonder: What’s next?

headline: Rituals | Rick Owens
text: The designer begins his day by answering a few emails, taking a shower — and dyeing his own hair.

headline: South Korea, Syria, C.I.A.: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Facebook Reports BBC to Police Over Investigation Into Child Sex Images
text: LONDON — When Angus Crawford, a journalist at the British Broadcasting Corporation, started reporting on sexualized images of children on Facebook, he knew he had to proceed with caution.

headline: Watch Rick Owens Dye His Hair
text: The fashion designer Rick Owens cuts a striking figure. He’s always dressed in his own clothes — which at times have included floor-sweeping coats and boots with five-inch heels. His standard day-to-day outfit includes his signature prehistoric-looking sneakers with odd, angular rubber panels for soles, while the rest of the leg is encased in a tight elastic leather sock, meeting at the knee with droopy-drawer shorts.

headline: In Texas Court: ‘Your Bond Just Went Up’
text: These videos were played in court during a lawsuit in Texas over bail fairness. In one, a hearing officer sets a $5,000 bond for a man arrested on charges of illegally sleeping under a freeway overpass.

headline: John Kerry to Write Memoir for Simon & Schuster
text: After leaving the office of secretary of state in January, John Kerry has a new, slightly less stressful task ahead of him: writing his memoir.

headline: Maria Sharapova’s Imminent Return Stirs Debate on Wild Cards
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — A year after the news of her positive doping test shook the BNP Paribas Open, Maria Sharapova again dominated conversation here in absentia.

headline: Theresa May Resists Pressure to Call Early British Election to Bolster ‘Brexit’
text: LONDON — Theresa May, Britain’s accidental prime minister, seems unassailable, with her opposition in disorder.

headline: A Roman Sarcophagus Is Rescued from Humble Duty as a Flower Pot
text: This was no ordinary flower pot holding up the tulips in an English garden.

headline: One Model, 32 Beauty Looks
text: The Italian model Greta Varlese’s season of hair and makeup, in pictures.

headline: In Defense of the Arts
text: Benefits were held recently for the School of American Ballet, Anthology Film Archives, Atlantic Theater Company and MoveOpolis.

headline: In Defense of the Arts
text: With federal arts funding in jeopardy, arts groups large and small held fund-raisers within the past week. The School of American Ballet held its winter ball on March 6 at Lincoln Center. The Anthology Film Archives had a gala at Capitale on March 2. The Atlantic Theater Company hosted a gala at the Pierre on March 6. And the dance and arts collective MoveOpolis held a benefit at New York Live Arts on March 8.

headline: The Cancer Researcher: Ohio State Responds
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Breaking the Rules Could Win You $250,000
text: The M.I.T. Media Lab’s proposition is simple: Break the rules or shake up the status quo, and you might win $250,000 in cash — no strings attached. No, it’s not a joke. Nominations for the lab’s new Disobedience Award are open.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 7 Will Debut in July
text: On Thursday “Game of Thrones” fans learned the information they have awaited for months: Season 7 of the show will arrive on July 16. But first they had to spend over an hour watching ice melt.

headline: Making Child Care Affordable for All
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Education Rules Are Swept Aside by Congress
text: With all the attention paid to President Trump’s lightning-rod secretary of education, Betsy DeVos, and her advocacy for private school vouchers, little public notice has been paid to the action on education in Congress — where lawmakers have broader power than Ms. DeVos to make changes to the nation’s school system.

headline: Still Fighting, and Dying, in the Forever War
text: In November 2016, Navy Senior Chief Petty Officer Scott Dayton became the first member of the United States military to die in the continuing conflict in Syria. Chief Dayton was killed by an improvised bomb in the northern part of the country, during a raid against the Islamic State. He was an explosive ordnance disposal technician, a member of the elite bomb squad, as was I, and everyone called him Scotty. He left behind a wife and two children. He was 42 years old.

headline: Fact Check: Spicer’s Pre-emptive Attack on the Nonpartisan C.B.O.
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s spokesman on Wednesday deflected concerns that a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act had yet to be scored by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office by questioning the agency’s track record.

headline: Indonesia’s Sentencing of ‘Son of God’ Adds to Alarm Over Crackdown
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Back in his days as a badminton coach with the Indonesian national team, Ahmad Mushaddeq traveled the world on the state’s dime. But after he became the spiritual leader of a back-to-the-land organic farming movement on the island of Borneo, regarded by his followers as the messiah who succeeded Muhammad, the government locked him up for the second time on charges of blasphemy.

headline: New Documentary Captures the Elusive Azzedine Alaïa
text: Famous but underappreciated has become a foolproof template for documentary subjects in recent years, used in films as disparate as “Searching for Sugar Man,” “20 Feet From Stardom” and “My Architect.” Add to the trope a cinematic fascination with fashion and you have the basis for a poetic documentary about a tempestuous and imposingly gifted Tunisian-born French designer who, while exalted among cognoscenti, is all but unknown to the wider world.

headline: Netflix Casts a Wider Net for Original Documentaries
text: It was early in March 2015, the filmmaker Ava DuVernay recalled recently, when she was approached by Lisa Nishimura, the vice president for original documentary and comedy programming at Netflix, who asked “if I had any story I wanted to tell.” As it happened, Ms. DuVernay had been thinking “about an overview of where the United States currently stands in terms of mass incarceration.”

headline: A.I.G. Needs a New, Risk-Focused C.E.O. Right Away
text: Surprising the market and the board is not a recipe for success for a chief executive. Peter Hancock did both last month in an enormous $5.6 billion charge at the American International Group, and now he’s on the way out. His replacement needs a better handle on risk and communication than predecessors had, and the sense to fend off a probable revived breakup push from Carl Icahn and John Paulson. It’s a tough call.

headline: Samantha Bee Show Apologizes to Writer for ‘Nazi Hair’ Mockery
text: The TBS comedy program “Full Frontal With Samantha Bee” apologized on Thursday for broadcasting a segment in which a writer who has talked about his cancer diagnosis was mocked for having what the program called “Nazi hair.”

headline: Minnesota Pledged to Be Good (but Not This Good)
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Eric Kaler, the president of the University of Minnesota, kept the letters. They arrived in a large envelope one day last summer, handwritten by more than a dozen members of a chagrined Gophers men’s basketball team.

headline: A Photographer Re-examines Los Angeles
text: After 10 years in New York, Gillian Steiner recently moved back to her California hometown — with a critical eye.

headline: On the N.C.A.A. Tournament Bubble, but Making a Case Off the Court
text: Moments after Georgia Tech was eliminated Tuesday in the opening round of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, Josh Pastner, the Yellow Jackets’ coach, started sounding like a politician.

headline: Does Trump Take Credit? Yes. Blame? Not So Fast.
text: To the Editor:

headline: What It Feels Like When a Mosque Is Threatened
text: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: Two Hollywood classics released just a decade apart, two superlative poets joined in friendship and legacy — how often do books about cultural pillars of the American 20th century arrive so neatly paired? Our selections this week feature satisfying studies of “High Noon” and “Casablanca,” and innovative biographies of Elizabeth Bishop and Robert Lowell. Fiction lovers will welcome new work by Jim Shepard, David Grossman and Mohsin Hamid. When you’ve finished reading, go out and take a walk: in the city (“Flâneuse: Women Walk the City in Paris, New York, Tokyo, Venice and London”) or in the country (“The Nature Fix: Why Nature Makes Us Happier, Healthier and More Creative”). It’ll do you good, we promise.

headline: Radioactive Boars in Fukushima Thwart Residents’ Plans to Return Home
text: They descend on towns and villages, plundering crops and rampaging through homes. They occasionally attack humans. But perhaps most dangerous of all, the marauders carry with them highly radioactive material.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
text: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: Louvre Attendants Strike After Vermeer Bottleneck
text: PARIS — Dozens of museum attendants at the Louvre went on strike on Thursday to protest what they said was the museum’s poor handling of crowds at a temporary exhibition dedicated to Vermeer, with another strike possible on Friday.

headline: ‘Game Change’ Authors Writing Book About ‘Trump the Man’ and His Campaign
text: On election night last year, the political journalists and analysts Mark Halperin and John Heilemann appeared on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” and offered stunned commentary to their ashen-faced host as Donald J. Trump’s victory became clear.

headline: A Soothing Skyline and a Weimaraner, ‘the Most Architectural of Dogs’
text: NEW HAVEN — When Deborah Berke took over as dean of the Yale School of Architecture last year, she gut-renovated an apartment here, turning a two-bedroom into a one-bedroom by knocking out a wall.

headline: Review: The Soundtrack Is the Star of ‘Who’s Crazy?’
text: In late 1964, Tom White, an American living in Paris, encountered the avant-garde troupe the Living Theater, also from the United States. While the group was waiting for its leaders, Julian Beck and Judith Malina, to return from the States (they were serving brief prison terms related to back taxes; the long story was recounted in The New York Times last year), the members paired up with Mr. White to make a film. That loose-narrative movie, “Who’s Crazy?,” had its New York premiere last year and is screening here again this week.

headline: Text to Text: ‘The Outsiders’ and ‘Bored, Broke and Armed’
text: Browse all our Text to Text lesson plans.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
text: Through March 25. Gladstone Gallery, 530 West 21st Street, Manhattan; 212-206-7606, gladstonegallery.com.

headline: In Orchestrating Barcelona Rally, Neymar Proves Ready for the Baton
text: There was no unseemly argument, no heated, agonized debate. Barcelona had five minutes to play, and a penalty kick to take. Lionel Messi, the world’s finest player, had not missed one all season; indeed, he had scored one about a half an hour earlier.

headline: Irish Whiskeys Rise Above the Annual Celebration
text: It’s that time of year again, when St. Patrick’s Day approaches and the thoughts of beverage writers across the land turn to Irish whiskey. But for American spirits drinkers, Irish whiskey is clearly no longer a once-a-year fling.

headline: A Dutch Master’s Surreal Visions
text: If you happened to see Werner Herzog’s video installation “Hearsay of the Soul” in the 2012 Whitney Biennial, you have already caught sight of the startlingly experimental etched vistas of the 17th-century Dutch master of the Golden Age, Hercules Segers. Greatly magnified details of his strangely barren, slightly unreal landscapes dominated Mr. Herzog’s five-channel video installation, which paid homage to Dutch artistry.

headline: Review: Give a Student Some Offal, and You’ll Regret It in ‘Raw’
text: “Raw,” Julia Ducournau’s jangly opera of sexual and dietary awakening, is an exceptionally classy-looking movie about deeply horrifying behavior. Infusing each scene with a cold, unwelcoming beauty, the Belgian cinematographer Ruben Impens makes his camera complicit in the trashy goings-on. Sneaking beneath bedsheets and sliding over young flesh, his lens takes us places we may not want to go.

headline: Jon Huntsman Is Said to Accept Post as Ambassador to Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has accepted President Trump’s offer to be ambassador to Russia, people with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday, taking on a diplomatic assignment that would be challenging in the best of times but is more so now, given the questions swirling around the Trump campaign and its links to Russia.

headline: Review: Love as the World Wars, in ‘The Ottoman Lieutenant’
text: “The Ottoman Lieutenant” is an overwrought nurse romance merged with a history lesson, a combination that is hard to take as seriously as the film wants to be taken.

headline: Review: A Combustible Pair Find Love in ‘The Other Half’
text: Acting prowess is in vast abundance in the moody romance “The Other Half.” Tatiana Maslany (the dazzling star of “Orphan Black”) plays Emily, a bipolar painter and teacher; Tom Cullen (Lord Gillingham on “Downton Abbey”) portrays Nickie, a brooding cabdriver and musician whose brother vanished almost five years ago. When these two meet, passionate sparks fly, but not without consequences.

headline: The Truth About the WikiLeaks C.I.A. Cache
text: On Tuesday morning, WikiLeaks released an enormous cache of documents that it claimed detailed “C.I.A. hacking tools.” Immediately afterward, it posted two startling tweets asserting that “C.I.A. hacker malware” posed a threat to journalists and others who require secure communication by infecting iPhone and Android devices and “bypassing” encrypted message apps such as Signal and WhatsApp.

headline: From Alexei Jawlensky, Abstract Faces at Full Intensity
text: The son of a colonel in the imperial Russian Army, Alexei Jawlensky was 18 and a cadet when a visit to the All-Russian Exhibition of Industry and Art in Moscow in 1882 changed his life by introducing him to painting. Eventually he moved to Munich with Marianne von Werefkin, another artistic expat from the nobility, vacationed with Kandinsky, bought a van Gogh and studied Buddhism, yoga and theosophy.

headline: Review: In ‘This Beautiful Fantastic,’ a Gardener Blooms
text: With spring imminent, backyard putterers are turning their thoughts to the garden, which makes “This Beautiful Fantastic,” a charming tale about one, all that much sweeter.

headline: Review: In ‘Canners,’ One Man’s Trash Is Another’s Nickel Treasure
text: Manfred Kirchheimer, born in Germany in 1931, is an indispensable New York filmmaker, a noticer and a listener without peer. His best-known work is probably “Stations of the Elevated,” a short documentary from 1981 that is a wordless, jazzy, poetic hymn to public transportation, graffiti and the battered glory of a rough time in the city’s history. Though his new feature, “Canners,” takes place in the present, a relatively safer and more prosperous era, it demonstrates that New York remains, in several senses, a tough place.

headline: Beware, a Notorious Broadway Bomb Is Ticking Again
text: On the wall that commemorates Broadway flops at the theater district restaurant Joe Allen — a few spots down from the sinister artwork for “Carrie,” the floppiest flop of all — there hangs a stardusted poster for the 1973 musical “Rachael Lily Rosenbloom and Don’t You Ever Forget It!” To connoisseurs of stage catastrophes, that disco-infused curiosity is perched there with pedigree: It’s one of just seven Broadway musicals that closed in previews. (Can a show close if it never opened? Discuss.)

headline: Review: In ‘Brimstone,’ the B Is for Bleak, Brutal and Bloody
text: It doesn’t take long before “Brimstone” makes good on the promise — and threat — implicit in its title. A western horror show with an unrelenting Old and New Testament kick, it opens on an ambiguous scene that soon gives way to a world of terrors, many involving children and parents. In one scene, a fetal hand juts out of the womb; in another, a man is gutted and his entrails are draped over his still-breathing body. It’s a hard, ugly world, or so the Dutch writer and director Martin Koolhoven keeps insisting for 149 grueling minutes.

headline: After a Stillbirth, Tests Can Help Pinpoint the Cause
text: Some 26,000 women in the United States give birth to a stillborn child each year. It’s a harrowing experience for parents, and many eventually want to know what went wrong, in part to avoid going through a similar experience in the future. But in the days after delivery, when tests to search for a cause must be conducted, doctors are often hesitant to suggest them, and grief-stricken parents often reluctant to permit them.

headline: Airbnb Raises $1 Billion More in a Funding Round
text: Airbnb has raised an additional $1 billion, expanding its war chest at a time of increased investor interest in fast-growing businesses.

headline: This Week’s Movies: March 10, 2017
text: The New York Times film critics review “Kong: Skull Island,” “Personal Shopper” and “The Sense of an Ending."

headline: Parents of Girls Scalded to Death in Homeless Housing May Sue
text: The parents of two toddlers scalded to death by steam from a radiator in a Bronx apartment for the homeless have filed a legal document that could pave the way for lawsuits against the city, the landlord and a nonprofit social services company that handled their case.

headline: New Hamas Charter Would Name ‘Occupiers,’ Not ‘Jews,’ as the Enemy
text: CAIRO — Hamas, the Palestinian Islamist group that has governed the Gaza Strip for a decade, is drafting a new platform to present a more pragmatic and cooperative face to the world, Hamas officials confirmed on Thursday.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
text: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: In ‘Natural Opium,’ a Tourist Attuned to Every Indignity
text: NATURAL OPIUMSome Travelers’ TalesBy Diane JohnsonOut of print

headline: The Making of the Making of a Movie
text: Michel Gondry, the writer and director of “Be Kind Rewind,”  discusses his process.

headline: Review: ‘Aging Magician,’ a Fable Complete With Complexities
text: Harold, a middle-aged, solitary sad sack, earns his living making and repairing clocks. What really consumes him, though, is the children’s book he has been writing for years, about an aging magician who must pass on his Book of Secrets to a receptive child, a magician heir. But before he can do so, the magician collapses and is rushed to a hospital.

headline: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

headline: A Brand Name for a Hedge Fund Happy Hour: Trump’s Mar-a-Lago
text: The invitation suggests your run-of-the-mill weekday evening of drinks, canapés and networking for the hedge fund crowd.

headline: First Underwater Video of Elusive True’s Beaked Whales
text: True’s beaked whales look a bit like weird dolphins with big foreheads, fat bellies and small flippers. They’re about the size of an elephant. And yet they are so elusive that most scientists who study them have never seen one in the wild.

headline: With Rebels Gone, Colombia Jumps Into the Pot Industry
text: CORINTO, Colombia — For years, Blanca Riveros has had the same routine: After fixing breakfast and taking her son to school, she heads home to a large plastic trash bag filled with marijuana.

headline: Snap Sketch: The Faces of Paris Fashion Week
text: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers draws the people — and looks — at the fall/winter 2017 collections in Paris.

headline: A Possible Clue in Jane Austen’s Glasses. Did Arsenic Kill Her?
text: LONDON — The cause of Jane Austen’s mysterious death at the age of 41 has been much pondered over the years. Was it a hormonal disorder? Cancer? Complications from drinking unpasteurized milk?

headline: Classical Music in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

headline: We Rounded Up Politics Stories You Shouldn’t Miss
text: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. That’s why we’re collecting great political feature writing from The New York Times and around the web that offers context, analysis and insight.

headline: A Brooklyn Charter School Looks Past ‘No Excuses’
text: Four years ago, while reporting on the difficulties of life in Brownsville, Brooklyn, one of the poorest neighborhoods in New York, I met a school administrator named Marsha Gadsden who worked for the Ascend Public Charter Schools network. Ms. Gadsden had grown up not far away, attended prep school on a scholarship and later went to Georgetown and Harvard, and she told me she worried about the unforgiving disciplinary codes used by her employer and so many urban charter schools around the country.

headline: Comedy in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

headline: Republican Party, C.I.A., Syria: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Trump’s New Travel Ban May Be Hard to Beat. But States Are Trying.
text: President Trump’s executive order banning travel from six predominantly Muslim countries faced a new front of opposition from the states on Thursday, as the attorney general of Washington announced that he would seek to block the order from taking effect next week.

headline: Dolley Madison and Her Peers Ran Their Own ‘Pussy-Hat’ Brigade
text: Before there were “pussy hats,” there were the women of Revolutionary-era America.

headline: Fans Honor The Notorious B.I.G.
text: Fans paid tribute to Christopher Wallace, a.k.a. Biggie, on the 20th anniversary of his death by rapping their favorite lyrics on social media.

headline: ‘Steve Wolfe: Remembering Steve’ Speaks Volumes About an Artist
text: Steve Wolfe, an artist who died last year at 60, was known for the small, select library of trompe l’oeil books he created. From his first solo show in 1989, Wolfe’s sculptures and wall pieces were all-but-perfect replicas of worn, well-used copies of modern classics and artist monographs and catalogs — usually his own — tweaked to within a hair of the original. Initially anonymous and ordinary in appearance, these copies become exquisitely personal as you grasp the level of skill and commitment required to make them. They are labors of love.

headline: Review: ‘American Crime’ Fixes on Migrant Dreamers in the Fields
text: The third season of “American Crime,” the gritty ABC drama with an investigative heart, will unspool just as President Trump’s proposed border wall will be generating a lot of discussion. The series wants a piece of that debate, but not the obvious one about cost and necessity. It wants you to ponder just why anyone would want to work the fields of the giant farms that are so important to the United States economy.

headline: Dance in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to dance performances.

headline: Iran’s Top Leader Appears to Rebuke President as Election Nears
text: Iran’s top leader criticized the pace of national economic growth on Thursday in what appeared to be a rebuke of the president, who had forecast prosperous times after the 2015 accord that lifted international sanctions in exchange for nuclear limits.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Lincoln and the Lost Souls

headline: Stephen Ross, Economist Who Developed Arbitrage Pricing Theory, Dies at 73
text: Stephen A. Ross, a seminal theorist whose work over three decades reshaped the field of financial economics, died on March 3 at his home in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 73.

headline: Vestiges of Old Harlem
text: David Vades Joseph, who grew up in Harlem, photographs the neighborhood as he knew it.

headline: Images of Old-School Harlem, Rapidly Vanishing
text: Is Harlem coming or going? Evolving into its next iteration or disappearing under the onslaught of change? It depends on whom you ask. For the photographer David Vades Joseph, who grew up in the neighborhood’s Hamilton Heights section, Harlem is an idea that is vanishing daily. “Certain mom and pop stores that I’ve walked past most of my life aren’t there anymore,” Mr. Vades Joseph, 30, said recently. “Buildings that I grew up with are being torn down and replaced by condominiums. It’s haunting, in a way.”

headline: Marilyn Young, Historian Who Challenged U.S. Foreign Policy, Dies at 79
text: Marilyn B. Young, a leftist, feminist, antiwar historian who challenged conventional interpretations of American foreign policy, died on Feb. 19 at her home in Manhattan, where she was a longtime professor at New York University. She was 79.

headline: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to new art shows — and some that will be closing soon.

headline: Sustained by Saints and Song, This Little Italy Shopkeeper Hangs On
text: E. Rossi & Company, an Italian gift shop on Grand Street near Mulberry Street in Little Italy, has become something of a museum of Italian-American pop culture.

headline: Events for Children in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

headline: Chris Bertish Becomes First to Cross Atlantic by Paddleboard
text: As dawn broke over the Caribbean on Thursday, Chris Bertish, bearded and shirtless, paddled toward Antigua’s English Harbour more than three months after leaving Africa, successfully finishing the first crossing of the Atlantic Ocean in a stand-up paddleboard.

headline: Where Do You Go on a Saturday Night in New York?
text: Saturday night in New York. It’s when Times Square, the Village and Williamsburg are even more jammed — inside bars, restaurants, clubs and on the sidewalks. But there are many New Yorks, and many Saturday nights, and not all of them unfold in the same old places. That’s where we need your help:

headline: Howard Hodgkin
text: Howard Hodgkin was one of the most admired artists of the postwar period.

headline: Howard Hodgkin, Whose Paintings Were Coded With Emotion, Dies at 84
text: Howard Hodgkin, a British artist whose lush, semiabstract paintings, aquiver with implicit drama, established him as one of the most admired artists of the postwar period, died on Thursday in London. He was 84.

headline: From Green Taxis to Taxes on Nose Jobs, Budget Tips for New York
text: Maybe the skies will continue to rain tax money in New York City, where more people are now on the city payroll than at any time in modern history. And perhaps the budget that President Trump and Republicans in Congress come up with will not slash the federal money that comes to the city.

headline: Kurt Moll, German Basso Profundo, Dies at 78
text: Kurt Moll, the imposing German bass whose theatrical flair and cavernous low notes allowed him to plumb the serenity, humor and ferocity of a wide array of operatic characters created by Mozart, Strauss and Wagner, died on March 5 in Cologne, Germany. He was 78.

headline: Trump’s Intelligence Nominee Gets Early Lesson in Managing White House
text: WASHINGTON — If Dan Coats, President Trump’s nominee to serve as the director of national intelligence, had any illusions about what he was getting into, the past seven weeks have certainly made clear the challenges he will face in a job created after the Sept. 11 attacks to coordinate the activities of the entire intelligence community.

headline: Tanning Industry, Taxed Under Obama, Cheers G.O.P. Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The tanning industry found little to celebrate during Barack Obama’s presidency, but it’s starting to cheer up.

headline: ‘Stand Your Ground’ Could Get Worse
text: Republican legislators in Florida are planning to compound the deadly mischief of the state’s Stand Your Ground law by allowing accused killers even greater leeway to claim self-defense and immunity from prosecution in violent confrontations.

headline: White House Casts Pre-emptive Doubt on Congressional Budget Office
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump showed an affinity for “working the referees” in his race to the White House, criticizing a federal judge as biased, panning polls as rigged and even questioning the aptitude of the nation’s intelligence agencies.

headline: With Trump in White House, His Golf Properties Prosper
text: WASHINGTON — It is a golden age for golf — at least as far as the Trump Organization is concerned.

headline: Yoelkis Cespedes, Half Brother of Mets’ Yoenis, Draws Notice
text: TOKYO — These days, many of Cuba’s best baseball players can be found in the major leagues in the United States. And until Cuba changes its stance on defectors, those players will not be allowed to represent the island nation in the World Baseball Classic.

headline: Sessions Says Guantánamo Is a ‘Very Fine Place’ for New Suspects
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions said on Thursday that he would advise President Trump to send newly captured terrorism suspects to the wartime prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, which he called “a very fine place,” rather than to bring them to civilian court for prosecution by the Justice Department he now runs.

headline: South Korea Removes President Park Geun-hye
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean court removed the president on Friday, a first in the nation’s history, rattling the delicate balance of relationships across Asia at a particularly tense time.

headline: Brock Osweiler Traded to Browns, but He May Not Stay
text: The Houston Texans announced on Thursday that they had traded quarterback Brock Osweiler to the Cleveland Browns — though it’s not certain that Osweiler will throw a pass for the Browns in 2017.

headline: Dismal Turnout
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Deb refers to puzzles like this as “crunchy”; I thought this one could have broken a tooth. Lots of uncommon midlength entries, combined with clues that seemed designed to get the mind to wander and doubt, and it took me a good long time to peck an entry hole to begin with. I did it with TAPPER at 3D, a guy who’s been pretty ubiquitous in the news, and LOTT at 54A, one of those good ol’ boys in politics who just seemed like the worst in a simpler era (and, guess what, he’s back).

headline: Review: Dismantling ‘The Glass Menagerie’
text: That shattering sound you hear coming from the Belasco Theater is the celebrated director Sam Gold taking a hammer to everything that’s delicate in “The Glass Menagerie.” The jagged, glistening shards of Tennessee Williams’s breakthrough play are available for inspection in the revival that opened on Thursday night.

headline: New Details Emerge in Murder Case After Ex-Officer’s Suicide
text: Gerard Benderoth, a retired New York City police officer and bodybuilder, was pulled over by F.B.I. agents and local police officers on Wednesday morning in a small town near the Hudson River just a short drive from his home. The agents and officers, who were investigating Mr. Benderoth’s links to a case involving a drug conspiracy and four murders, hoped to get him to cooperate with their inquiry, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: U.N. Court Declines to Reopen Bosnia’s Genocide Case Against Serbia
text: PARIS — The United Nations’ highest court on Thursday denied a request by Bosnia to reopen a 2007 case that cleared Serbia of playing an active role in the genocide committed during the war in Bosnia in the 1990s.

headline: 35 Girls Killed in Guatemala Fire May Have Been Locked In
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Guatemalan human rights officials said Thursday that they believe that the 35 girls who were killed when a fire swept through a dormitory at a children’s home had been unable to escape because they were locked inside.

headline: Redskins Fire G.M. Scot McCloughan on First Day of Free Agency
text: While other teams in the N.F.L. were scrambling to make deals on Thursday, the first day of free agency, the Washington Redskins announced that they had fired their general manager.

headline: Keeping the Beat
text: Adam Shankman discusses his direction and choreography for the movie musical "Hairspray."

headline: Davis Cup May Switch to Best-of-Three-Set Matches
text: The leaders of the International Tennis Federation took a significant step on Thursday toward ending a 117-year tradition when they voted unanimously in favor of a proposal that would switch the Davis Cup to best-of-three-set matches.

headline: Ryan Dempster Returns From Retirement to Pitch for Canada
text: MIAMI — Ryan Dempster has not pitched in the major leagues in more than three seasons, and he is not making a comeback. At 39, after nearly 3,000 professional innings, he knows he could not withstand the rigors of a season.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Kong: Skull Island’

headline: ‘A Broader View’ vs. ‘An Invasion’: Dutch Voters Speak Out on Immigration
text: Dutch voters go to the polls next week after a loud and divisive campaign that focused on immigration, the first of a series of European elections this year that could propel populist forces into power. Geert Wilders, the virulently anti-immigrant leader of the Netherlands’ Party of Freedom, or P.V.V., has led the charge on the immigration debate, drawing in parties on the mainstream right.

headline: Ex-Players Accuse N.F.L. Teams of Violating Prescription Drug Laws, Report Says
text: Former players have asserted that N.F.L. teams violated federal prescription drug laws, The Washington Post reported on Thursday after it reviewed sealed court documents from a federal lawsuit filed by the ex-players.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Love’ and ‘The Vampire Diaries’
text: “Love,” the Netflix comedy series filled with Judd Apatow’s signature blend of discomfort and brutal honesty, returns for Season 2: 12 episodes of misadventures in dating for the unlikely couple Gus and Mickey. And “The Vampire Diaries,” a CW drama that rode the wave of “Twilight” popularity eight seasons ago, comes to an end with an action-packed series finale.

headline: Afghanistan Is Now Trump’s War
text: Before the White House responds to the Pentagon’s latest request for a troop surge in Afghanistan to counter insurgent forces that now control substantial parts of the country, it would serve administration officials well to examine the long history of deluded thinking about what could be accomplished if the United States committed more troops to the effort.

headline: A Bill So Bad It’s Awesome
text: It has long been obvious to anyone following health policy that Republicans would never devise a workable replacement for Obamacare. But the bill unveiled this week is worse than even the cynics expected; its awfulness is almost surreal. And the process by which it came to be tells you a lot about the state of the G.O.P.

headline: The Republican Health Care Crackup
text: The Republican health care bill could represent the moment when the old order of American politics completely cracks up, the end of a certain era in American politics.

headline: The Bombs of Steve Bannon
text: Like much of the world, I’ve been trying to understand Stephen K. Bannon, the chief strategist and guiding force behind the chaos of Donald Trump’s bizarre presidency — chaos by design.

headline: Design Competition, or Ideological Crisis?
text: Donald J. Trump ran on a platform of building a wall on the southern border of the United States when 650 miles of wall is already built. If he does nothing, he needs only to inform people that the existing 650 miles of wall (O.K., it’s a non-contiguous fence) is working.

headline: Why Is Mr. Tillerson in a Perpetual State of Duck and Cover?
text: For a guy who has spent his life delivering messages — as a businessman, reality TV star, presidential candidate and now president — President Trump is doing an abysmal job explaining his view of the world and America’s place in it. Normally, that would increase the importance of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. But if Mr. Trump’s messages are confusing, Mr. Tillerson’s are almost nonexistent.

headline: John Kasich: End the Partisan Warfare on Health Care
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Americans are relying on leaders in Washington to fix health care, not engage in yet another unproductive partisan standoff. In 2010, one side of the political aisle in Congress, the Democrats, chose to “fix” health care unilaterally, without bipartisan support. The result was Obamacare, which has run up government spending while failing to drive down the cost of health care.

headline: Want to Fix Schools? Go to the Principal’s Office
text: CHICAGO — Gregory Jones, the principal of Kenwood high school, has learned that when spring finally arrives in Chicago, trouble often arrives with it. He saw it happen again on a warm afternoon last May, when students were lingering outside the school, on the city’s South Side, and a fight broke out.

headline: Are You Middle Class Enough to Deserve a Health Care Tax Break?
text: Something fascinating happened during the most recent rewrite of the Obamacare repair bill: Its authors tried to define who is middle class enough to be deserving of a big tax handout.

headline: Steady U.S. Job Growth Sets Stage for Fed to Raise Interest Rates
text: A wave of hiring in February — President Trump’s first full month in office — pointed to a strong foundation for the nation’s economy, providing further evidence for the Federal Reserve that the moment to raise interest rates has come.

headline: Even Before the Wall, Migrants Find the U.S. Forbidding
text: SONOYTA, Mexico — Reiner Ríos Gómez, who is from Honduras’s capital, Tegucigalpa, lifted his shirt last week to expose a scar about 12 inches long in the middle of his back, where he said a machete hit him as he fled the robbers who were trying to steal his pay: 2,800 lempiras, or about $119, for half a month’s work in construction.

headline: When Is a Drought Over? A Wet California Wants to Know
text: LOS ANGELES — The Hollywood Reservoir is nestled in a basin surrounded, usually, by dusty brown hillsides, broken up by the occasional dry wisp of shrubbery. Not these days. After yet another burst of rain the other day, the hills were transformed into lush fields of knee-high grass, spotted with purple flowers. And the reservoir? As high as it has been in years.

headline: When Mothers Bully Back
text: Many years ago, I threw a playground ball at the head of a boy who was repeatedly dunking my young son underwater. Before I threw the ball, I shouted at him to stop, but he continued. I was at the other end of the pool, maybe a six-second swim away, but my 5-year-old son was gasping and pleading, and the fastest way to make my point was to throw the ball.

headline: Wisconsin and Minnesota Await Latest Round in Ice-Melting Rivalry
text: Since earning the preseason No. 1 ranking, Wisconsin has yet to slip from its perch atop college women’s hockey. Last weekend, the Badgers (31-2-4) captured their third straight Western Collegiate Hockey Association tournament title, winning what is regularly the toughest conference in the nation.

headline: Prewar Is So Last Year
text: Prewar charm in New York City is defined by original details like crown moldings, built-in bookshelves, coffered ceilings and fireplaces, some more decorative than others. But driven by design trends and the need for more space, some apartment buyers are doing what some would consider unthinkable: tearing out traditional finishes.

headline: ‘Revolution? What Revolution?’ Russia Asks 100 Years Later
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin plans to sit out the centenary of the Russian Revolution.

headline: Friday Mailbag: A Surprising Advertisement and Some Missing Fathers
text: On Thursday the new head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Scott Pruitt, said that carbon dioxide was not a primary contributor to global warming. That statement was at odds with the global scientific consensus on climate change — and with Pruitt’s own agency. But readers wouldn’t be wrong to think that he came to this conclusion by way of The Times.

headline: Who Needs Manhattan? Hanging With the Locals on Bell Boulevard
text: Johno Gargan stepped out of a wind-whipped evening and into Bourbon Street, a large New Orleans-style restaurant whose long, busy bar is one of the centers of the bustling night life scene in Bayside, Queens.

headline: Charlie Crist, Once a Republican, Takes a Seat Among Democrats in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Charlie Crist, Democrat of Florida, has had many identities. Governor. Senate candidate. State attorney general. Education commissioner. State legislator. Democrat. Republican. Independent.

headline: Fukushima, 6 Years On: Empty and Eerie
text: Inside the exclusion zone surrounding Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, homes and restaurants are still abandoned despite Japan’s plan to lift the evacuation order.

headline: The Lonely Towns of Fukushima
text: Thousands of people fled from their homes, offices and schools six years ago after a devastating earthquake and tsunami caused a meltdown at a nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan. To this day, few have returned, leaving behind ghost towns where eerie signs of the departed linger under a caking of dust.

headline: My Grandmother’s Story Is Ending as Mine Begins

But Bonhomie, the first dining venture from the group behind the Parisian cocktail bars Little Red Door and Lulu White, brings those elements together harmoniously.

headline: What’s Under Discussion at One of China’s Biggest Political Gatherings
text: BEIJING — It’s that time again, when more than 5,000 delegates to China’s National People’s Congress and its advisory body, the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference, meet in Beijing to endorse legislation and discuss government plans for the coming year. They talk about their policy ideas with the local media too, and coverage of their proposals and the online comments they attract provide glimpses into some of the issues on the minds of Chinese today.

headline: 11 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics

Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, we’re also tooting our own horn here. We’ll share can’t-miss Times stories from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

headline: The N.B.A.’s ‘Turkish Thunder’ Excels at a Painful Task

A 6-foot-10 power forward for the Atlanta Hawks, Ilyasova was averaging 13.7 points and 5.8 rebounds a game through Friday. He is a dependable defender and an excellent outside shooter. He even has a cool nickname: Turkish Thunder.

headline: How Gigi Loizzo, Guggenheim Museum’s Retail Chief, Spends Her Sundays
text: As the director of retail strategy and operations for the Guggenheim Museum, Gigi Loizzo selects the items sold in the museum’s store and is in charge of building its e-commerce site. She commutes into Manhattan from her home in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx five days a week, so on the weekends, she prefers to keep things local. Ms. Loizzo, 55, lives in a townhouse with her husband, Angel Molina, 57, a recent retiree; their daughter, Maya Luz Molina, 29, an accessories designer; their three dogs, Bruno, Bad Betty and Larry; and a cat, New Kitty.

headline: Protests Erupt in South Korea After President Park Geun-hye Is Ousted
text: Silence fell over thousands of supporters of South Korea’s president, Park Geun-hye, as the country’s Constitutional Court announced it was removing her from office on Friday. The unanimous ruling capped months of turmoil for a country that has been gripped by the corruption scandal that brought down Ms. Park.

headline: Pressed Into Caregiving Sooner Than Expected
text: It was August, and Gina Rinehart was preparing for another school year as a special-education teacher in Hemet, Calif., when she got the call: Her father, Floyd Hall, was facing surgery to remove a tumor in his lung.

headline: Nigeria’s President, Muhammadu Buhari, Returns Home, but His Health Remains a Mystery
text: LONDON — President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria returned home on Friday after spending seven weeks in Britain on a vacation that turned into an extended medical leave, with questions about his health and about the stability of Africa’s most populous country remaining unanswered.

headline: Margaret Atwood on What ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’ Means in the Age of Trump
text: In the spring of 1984 I began to write a novel that was not initially called “The Handmaid’s Tale.” I wrote in longhand, mostly on yellow legal notepads, then transcribed my almost illegible scrawlings using a huge German-keyboard manual typewriter I’d rented.

headline: Trump’s Climate Views: Combative, Conflicting and Confusing
text: Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, drew criticism on Thursday for saying that carbon dioxide was not a primary contributor to global warming, contradicting years of established science. But his boss, President Trump, has similarly raised doubts about the cause of global warming and has said a great deal more on the subject — as part of an argument, an applause line, a punch line or an insult.

headline: Another Woman at the March Madness Mike? That Only Took 2 Decades

headline: A $2,000 Room and Stale Pastry? When Luxury Travel Goes Awry
text: Cristina Verger, a wedding and event planner, arrived at the Hotel Boscolo in Milan eager to mix business with pleasure. With the hotel’s room rates topping $2,000 a night, her expectations were high.

headline: When the Kids Crash Your BBC Interview
text: There are well-known drawbacks to working from home: the isolation, the need for self-discipline.

headline: When Japan Had a Third Gender
text: A figure in a translucent kimono coyly holds a fan. Another arranges an iris in a vase. Are they men or women?

headline: Emily Coates’s ‘Incarnations’: Quantum Leaps, When Physics Meets Dance
text: As colleagues at Yale University, the former New York City Ballet dancer Emily Coates and the particle physicist Sarah Demers have collaborated on classes, lessons and a textbook. The course they designed and taught together, “Physics of Dance,” introduced students to concepts from each discipline using the other. Taking that teamwork to the stage, Ms. Coates unveils a new work at Danspace Project starting Thursday, March 16. Part lecture, part performance, “Incarnations” addresses topics ranging from Newton’s corporeality to the Higgs boson particle. An early showing of the piece, in 2015, included a winning demonstration of how George Balanchine, who defined a high-speed American style of ballet, finessed the physics of the pirouette. Ms. Coates will be joined by Ms. Demers and the dancers Lacina Coulibaly, Iréne Hultman and Jon Kinzel — and the music director Will Orzo. The postmodern visionary Yvonne Rainer, with whom Ms. Coates has danced, will also make a brief appearance. (danspaceproject.org)

headline: ‘Groundhog Day’ Offers Repetition, Offers Repetition
text: Bill Murray’s indelible performance as a jaded, delightfully obnoxious weatherman in the 1993 film “Groundhog Day” is a hard act to follow — even if the movie proved that repetition offers comic rewards. In any case, after a well-received run in London last summer, a new musical based on the movie about that weatherman having to relive the same day repeatedly, arrives on Broadway this month (hopefully bringing spring weather along with it).

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Should Trump Get Credit for Good Jobs Numbers?
text: The first monthly jobs report to reflect the state of the economy during the Trump presidency is quite good. There’s not much to dislike about the 235,000 jobs added in February, nor an unemployment rate that ticked down to 4.7 percent, nor an average hourly earnings rise of 0.2 percent.

headline: True North: ‘Marsden Hartley’s Maine’ at the Met Breuer
text: The painter Marsden Hartley (1877-1943) ranged far and wide during his career, but when he returned to his home state for good in 1937, declaring his intention to be “the painter of Maine,” he seemed to find an intellectual birthright he had been seeking his whole life.

text: Oops.

headline: A Tribe Called Red and Clap! Clap! in a Cross-Borough Double Bill
text: Ancient traditions plus modern electronics: It’s one recipe for music that brings a human element to the digital dance floor and could introduce a new audience to venerable sounds. Two versions of that approach are due in New York on Friday, March 17, with timing that makes it plausible to attend them both.

headline: Julia Bullock and Sarah Connolly Offer Enchantments New and Old
text: Ever since its meticulous restoration in 2013, the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory, with its mahogany wainscoting and enormous fireplace, has become an intimate space for chamber music and recitals. On Wednesday, March 15, the velvety-voiced British mezzo-soprano Sarah Connolly presents an enticing recital of songs by Copland, Berlioz, Schumann and Poulenc, accompanied by the pianist Joseph Middleton, in this inviting setting. With flexible seating, the room accommodates 140 or so people. This program will be presented twice; the second performance is on Friday. (armoryonpark.org)

headline: ‘The Odyssey’ Explores the Life of Jacques Cousteau
text: Its Homeric title notwithstanding, Jérôme Salle’s “The Odyssey” is less an epic than a standard biopic of the explorer-turned-filmmaker Jacques-Yves Cousteau, as played by Lambert Wilson.

headline: Yes, Your Sleep Schedule Is Making You Sick
text: Jet lag makes everyone miserable. But it makes some people mentally ill.

headline: Allies Fear Trump Is Eroding America’s Moral Authority
text: PARIS — When the State Department released its annual human rights report last week, it contained many of the usual tough American judgments of other countries. Iran was criticized for restricting freedom of religion and the media; Russia for discriminating against minorities; Eritrea for using torture; Bulgaria for violence against migrants and asylum seekers. The list went on.

Instead, it became another high-profile and unflattering incident for United States customs authorities who have been tasked with enforcing President Trump’s border security initiatives.

text: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there’s much more where these came from.

headline: Newfound Fame for Stubbs & Wootton Slippers, the ‘Bumper Sticker for Your Foot’

They both are devoted clients of the footwear brand Stubbs & Wootton, known for its patterned and embroidered slippers.

headline: ‘Cries From Syria,’ on HBO, Is a Grim Look at That Nation’s ’s War

headline: The Artist Jimmie Durham: A Long Time Gone, but Welcomed Back
text: LOS ANGELES — It was a big night for the 76-year-old American artist Jimmie Durham. That evening, Jan. 28, was the opening of his retrospective at the Hammer Museum here, eagerly anticipated because he has not had a solo show in the United States in 22 years.

headline: Using the TV App for iOS

headline: Flecks of Extraterrestrial Dust, All Over the Roof
text: After decades of failures and misunderstandings, scientists have solved a cosmic riddle — what happens to the tons of dust particles that hit the Earth every day but seldom if ever get discovered in the places that humans know best, like buildings and parking lots, sidewalks and park benches.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Michelle Dockery
text: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the actress Michelle Dockery, who is best known for her role in “Downton Abbey.” Dockery co-stars in “The Sense of an Ending,” which opens in select theaters on March 10. She shares her list exclusively with T.

headline: Honey, Please Pick Up Some Grilled Tilapia at the Gas Station
text: LEESBURG, Va. — Last summer, when two women were looking for a restaurant space in this Northern Virginia town of 48,000, one of the options held multiple enticements: It was affordable, it had a good location, the kitchen was fit for Asian cooking and it was in a gas station.

headline: The N.C.A.A Tournament Challenge: Determining Who’s In and What’s Their Seed
text: The most important and controversial annual function of the selection committee for the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament is to decide which 36 teams merit at-large bids into the final field alongside the 32 conference champions that qualify automatically.

headline: U.N. Accuses Turkey of Killing Hundreds of Kurds

headline: Shopping for Clocks
text: With daylight saving time beginning this weekend, clocks will get more attention than usual. Some people may marvel at later sunsets; others will simply curse timepieces that are difficult to adjust.

headline: In the Kitchen With Joanne Fluke, Author of the Hannah Swensen Culinary Mysteries
text: Bon Appétit: The term “cozy mystery” always makes me laugh — you do realize there’s a corpse here, right, people? Surely some enterprising novelist will churn out “Murder Most Hyggelig” soon. Until then, the coziest cozies remain those by Joanne Fluke, whose Hannah Swensen culinary mysteries star a small-town Minnesota baker and feature recipes alongside the dead bodies; her latest, “Banana Cream Pie Murder,” is new at No. 3 in hardcover fiction.

headline: The Yankee Clippers: Clint Frazier Gets a Trim
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Deep inside Steinbrenner Field, the unkindest cut of all took place early Friday morning — Clint Frazier’s hair.

headline: Kids Are Getting Older Quicker. And Disney Tries to Adapt.
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Grandma is mad. Her grown daughter, Bex, who got pregnant as a teenager, just blazed back into town and let a big secret slip. Grandma had raised 13-year-old Andi to believe that Bex was her older sister. Well, the truth is a tad more complicated.

headline: Copy Edit This! Quiz No. 4
text: The Times’s standards editor, Philip B. Corbett, invites readers to correct grammatical errors in recent New York Times articles.

headline: What Happens When You Fight a ‘Deep State’ That Doesn’t Exist
text: The Trump administration, in its fight against the “deep state,” could risk exacerbating the very problems it has pinned on shadowy bureaucratic forces: leaking, internal conflict and the politicization of institutions like intelligence agencies.

headline: Trump Immigration Crackdown Is Great for Private Prison Stocks
text: Nightmarish as the last two months have been for immigrants threatened by detention or deportation, it has been a marvelous time for two companies that stand to benefit from the Trump administration’s policies.

headline: Trump’s Plan on Fannie and Freddie? Clues May Emerge Soon
text: Fixing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giants that still operate under government supervision, is nowhere near the top of the Trump administration’s to-do list. Since the election, administration officials, including Steven T. Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, have said little about their plans for the companies.

headline: Review: In Documentaries on Syria, Much Despair and a Dash of Hope
text: If the idea of cozying up to Russia strikes you as harmless, or all those Syrian refugees are too far away to seem real, the HBO documentary “Cries From Syria” is something you ought to watch. But be prepared for an unrelenting blast of misery without a lot of context.

headline: The French Love to Eat This. Why Don’t Americans?
text: It remains a mystery to me why a delicious rabbit dinner, a habit in France, is such a hard sell in the United States, a meal many Americans would shy away from. This is not to say that you can’t buy rabbit here, but you don’t see it on a daily basis in butcher shops or at the supermarket.

headline: A Lake Turned Pink in Australia. It’s Not the Only One.
text: Over the past week, the internet has been getting excited over a hot-pink lake in the heart of Melbourne. And despite what science fiction nostalgia it may conjure up, this is not a scene from “Ghostbusters” or “The X-Files.” This is very much a real, natural phenomenon that occurs all over the planet. It’s what happens when the only thing living in a supersalty lake is a single-celled, salt-loving microbe that makes pigments called carotenoids.

headline: Trump Keeps Low Profile After Praising Health Care Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump praised House Republican leaders on Friday for their plan to overhaul the Affordable Care Act, but otherwise kept a conspicuously low profile, with a newfound silent treatment of the news media.

headline: Life With Dad, the Funeral Director
text: Before the age of 12, I had seen about a dozen dead bodies. It was actually a pretty typical childhood — or at least it was for me, because my father was a funeral director.

headline: In This Ballet, a Sweetly Disturbing Confection From Alexei Ratmansky
text: A Viennese pastry shop, dancing sweets, a little boy who overindulges and a revolution by the lower pastry orders. An almost unknown Richard Strauss score. Décor and costumes by the pop-surrealist artist Mark Ryden. And a great title: “‘Whipped Cream’! It’s really wonderful,” Alexei Ratmansky said of his full-length work for American Ballet Theater after a long day of rehearsal last week.

headline: What We’re Reading

headline: Michael Flynn Was Paid to Represent Turkey’s Interests During Trump Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — The candidate he was advising last fall was running on a platform of America First. The client he was working for last fall was paying him more than $500,000 to put Turkey first.

You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

headline: Woman Detained After Speaking About Deportation Fears Is Released
text: A 22-year-old undocumented immigrant who was detained by the authorities last week after speaking out about her deportation fears was released on Friday, her lawyers and rights groups said.

headline: The Top 10 Moments of Paris Fashion Week
text: Paris Fashion Week marked a few important milestones: The designer Dries Van Noten held his 100th runway show, a celebratory marker of a brilliant career. The collection, which featured vibrant prints, oversize silhouettes and jewel-toned faux fur jackets, was modeled by the greatest names in the business, including Amber Valletta, Nadja Auermann and Kirsten Owen — all models who have walked in Van Noten’s shows since 1993. Later in the week, Jean Touitou of A.P.C. celebrated his 30th year in business with an intimate show at the brand’s studio on the Left Bank. The collection was about simplicity, but done well: there were no-fuss denim jackets, pants, trench coats and military dresses.

headline: Review: John Adams Wrestles the Ghosts of His Musical Fathers
text: The New York Philharmonic opened what was billed as an all-John Adams concert on Thursday with a bit of Beethoven. Mr. Adams, reacting from the stage of David Geffen Hall, said he felt tempted to “quit while I’m ahead and skip my own piece.”

headline: Unhappy Customers Make Him Happy, and Rich
text: A few pugnacious companies out there are skeptical about the age-old maxim that the customer is always right. But the Haggler has never encountered a business that delights in calling its customers wrong, and then insults those customers in obscenity-filled emails and YouTube videos.

headline: Listen to Songs From the Fashion Month Runways
text: Fashion month, which officially came to a close this week, saw Raf Simons’s debut at Calvin Klein — and more than a few political statements on the runway. But aside from what we saw, what we heard at the shows was especially memorable. Some soundtracks offered a direct connection to the collection they accompanied: At Chanel, for example, Elton John’s “Rocket Man” blared while a massive rocket emblazoned with the brand’s logo “took off” inside Paris’s Grand Palais. Elsewhere, soundtracks sent slightly more subliminal messages. Many designers opted for songs that were overtly political, such as David Bowie’s “This Is Not America” at Calvin Klein or Richie Havens’s “Freedom” at the Row. Many others featured music by strong female vocalists, such as Nina Simone’s “Funkier Than a Mosquito’s Tweeter” at Mara Hoffman and an all-out dance party to Christina Aguilera’s “What a Girl Wants” at Brandon Maxwell. At Ryan Roche, the designer’s 13-year-old daughter and her 15-year-old friend sang live versions of songs by Stevie Nicks in a nod to the next generation; and Stella McCartney paid tribute to the late George Michael, with models dancing to a remix of his song “Faith.”
