headline: A Staten Island Urban Farmer
text: Zaro Bates operates and lives on a 5,000-square-foot farm on Staten Island, which may make her the city’s only commercial farmer-in-residence. But instead of a shingled farmhouse surrounded by acres of fields, Ms. Bates lives in a second-floor studio in a midrise apartment complex built on the site of a former naval base overlooking New York Bay.

headline: Renting Your Home Out, By the Hour
text: Like other New Yorkers, Alex Story occasionally rents out her home through Airbnb, relinquishing her East Village townhouse to strangers who sleep in her bed, eat in her kitchen and lounge on her sofa. But she has found a less intrusive way to profit from her property: She rents it out by the hour, instead.

headline: Stop Beating Black Children
text: “This is gonna hurt me more than it hurts you.”

headline: White-Hot Aria, Engulfing Bass: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Moments
text: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what they’ve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

headline: Ouster of South Korean President Could Return Liberals to Power
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The foes of South Korea’s likely new leaders have called them blindly naïve, closet North Korea followers and anti-American — an unsettling accusation in a country where the alliance with Washington has been the military bedrock for seven decades.

headline: Unrest Flares at Nepal-India Border After Fatal Shooting of Nepali
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Protests flared on Friday along the border between Nepal and India, a day after Indian security forces fatally shot a Nepali man who was protesting their presence on disputed territory.

headline: Two People Die after Eating Raw-Milk Cheese Made in New York State
text: Two people have died following an outbreak of listeria linked to a popular artisanal raw milk cheese made in upstate New York, the authorities said this week.

headline: Statue Being Pulled From a Gritty Patch of Cairo Could Be of Ramses
text: CAIRO — The gritty, working-class neighborhood of Matariya in northeast Cairo brims with noise and poverty, a place where motorized rickshaws vie with donkey carts on narrow, trash-strewn streets. But this week, archaeologists began pulling from a patch of barren ground a glistening 26-foot statue they say might be a world-class find.

headline: Trump Abruptly Orders 46 Obama-Era Prosecutors to Resign
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration moved on Friday to sweep away most of the remaining vestiges of Obama administration prosecutors at the Justice Department, ordering 46 holdover United States attorneys to tender their resignations immediately — including Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.

headline: Mosque Is Blocked in New Jersey, but Dispute Is Far From Over
text: BAYONNE, N.J. — They thought they had found the perfect place to build the first mosque and Islamic community center in this city’s history: an empty 8,500-square-foot warehouse at the end of a dead-end block, with room on its lot for 37 parking spots.

headline: Paris Fashion Week in 60 Seconds
text: T Magazine's market director, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, recaps the fall/winter 2017 collections from Paris.

headline: The Rice-Size Fly That Hits the Bull’s-Eye Every Time
text: Despite being just the size of a rice grain, robber flies, which live all over the world, are champion predators. In field experiments, they can detect targets the size of sand grains from nearly two feet away — 100 times the fly’s body length — and intercept them in under half a second. What’s more, they never miss their mark.

headline: Robin Camp, Canadian Judge, Resigns Over Handling of Rape Trial
text: OTTAWA — A judge who became known throughout Canada for asking a complainant why she could not just keep her “knees together” during a sexual assault has resigned from Federal Court. It was the latest in a series of episodes that have prompted questions about the handling of sexual assault cases in Canada.

headline: Points of No Return
text: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: Los Angeles’s Thriving Jazz Scene Produces Four New Albums
text: New York remains the popular and commercial center of jazz, but other cities are increasingly dictating its development. Young musicians in places like Philadelphia and Chicago — where systems for intergenerational exchange still thrive outside academia — are marrying established regional patois with a broad base of influences from across the black musical canon, and around the globe.

headline: New York Examiner Won’t Disclose Cause of Russian Envoy’s Death
text: UNITED NATIONS — A terse note from the New York City Office of Chief Medical Examiner on Friday saying that it could not disclose the “cause and manner” of a senior Russian diplomat’s death in February set off a flood of conspiratorial posts on Twitter, but both Russian and American officials said the announcement was a matter of diplomatic protocol.

headline: Trump’s Abortion Strategy
text: Divide and conquer. That’s the way to understand President Trump’s informal offer to Planned Parenthood: Stop doing abortions and you can keep the federal funding that the House Republican bill to replace Obamacare would otherwise eliminate. The president was reportedly trying to placate both conservatives and his daughter Ivanka, who, during the campaign, apparently pushed him to recognize that “millions of women are helped by Planned Parenthood.”

headline: Paul Taylor Season’s Premieres Lack the Luster of Its Revivals
text: What are we to make of the choreographer Paul Taylor and his annual three-week New York season? His dancers — the company is based here — are among the city’s most accomplished, personable and sensuous; his repertory includes many of the world’s most oddly imaginative masterpieces.

headline: S.E.C. Rejects Winklevoss Brothers’ Bid to Create Bitcoin E.T.F.
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday it had rejected an application to create an exchange-traded fund tied to the price of Bitcoin.

headline: Cast the Trump Mini-Series: Who Should Play the Donald?
text: When news broke that the reporters Mark Halperin and John Heilemann would be writing a book chronicling Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign — and that this book would be turned into an HBO mini-series — we wanted to help Tom Hanks, the executive producer, and the rest of the principals, by offering some casting suggestions.

headline: Saudi Aramco I.P.O. May Merit a Social Engineering Discount
text: Saudi Aramco is in danger of undermining its own cash call.

headline: Oil Price Drop Triggers a ‘Herd Mentality’ of Selling
text: HOUSTON — Often turbulent, the oil market had become almost boring the past few months, with prices moving little and hovering around $51 to $56 a barrel.

headline: A Red-Tailed Hawk Dies Behind City Hall. Coincidence? Probably.
text: The first corpse was found near the tip of City Hall Park in January — the body of a red-tailed hawk that had dropped dead from some high spot onto the sidewalk. On Friday, a second corpse appeared: Another red-tailed hawk was spotted dead in a tree behind City Hall, not far from Mayor Bill de Blasio’s second-floor office window.

headline: Republican Party, ‘Kong: Skull Island’: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Distinguished Writers Debate Sense of ‘Mission’ in Trump Era
text: “Every aspect of our mission is being challenged.” Suzanne Nossel, the executive director of PEN America, the literary and human rights organization, was speaking onstage at Cooper Union on Wednesday night. PEN’s annual general meeting featured a distinguished panel, moderated by Ms. Nossel, of five writers talking about the role of journalism and literature under the presidency of Donald J. Trump.

headline: How the Dutch Stopped Being Decent and Dull
text: In normal times, few people outside the Netherlands would have paid the slightest attention to this week’s Dutch parliamentary elections. In normal times, even people who would have paid attention could have expected yet another solid middle-of-the-road government to be formed by a coalition of parties, usually including Christian or Social Democrats, or business-minded conservatives, led by earnest political managers.

headline: From Flight 370 Hunt, New Insight Into Indian Ocean’s Unknown Depths
text: On March 8, 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished with 239 passengers and crew aboard as it crossed the Indian Ocean, triggering a large-scale search for its remains that lasted nearly three years. As a byproduct of the tragedy, scientists have gained access to more than 100,000 square miles of seafloor mapped at a level of detail that provides a rare look at the ocean’s geological processes.

headline: Smart Republicans?
text: I claim no special expertise in the legislative process. But reading a couple of pieces about what looks like a health care debacle from the good folks at Vox, I have some thoughts about what’s going on — namely, don’t presume that Ryan and company have any idea what they’re doing.

headline: Couldn’t Get Into Yale? 10 New York City High Schools Are More Selective
text: And you thought it was hard to get into Yale.

headline: Pope Francis Signals Openness to Ordaining Married Men in Some Cases
text: Pope Francis this week signaled receptiveness to appeals from bishops in the remote and overwhelmed corners of the Roman Catholic Church to combat a deepening shortage of priests by ordaining married men who are already committed to the church.

headline: Zack Wheeler Makes Solid Start, and Police Stop a Tim Tebow Fan
text: Not every day in spring training is eventful, but Friday certainly was for the Mets.

headline: Anthony Beilenson, Congressman Who Fought for Abortion Rights, Dies at 84
text: Anthony Beilenson, a 10-term congressman who persuaded fellow California legislators and Gov. Ronald Reagan 50 years ago to approve what was then one of the nation’s most permissive abortion rights bills, died on March 5 in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: Waymo Asks Court to Block Uber’s Self-Driving Car Project
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Waymo, the self-driving car business spun out of Google’s parent company last year, asked a federal court on Friday to block Uber’s work on a competing self-driving vehicle that Waymo claimed could be using stolen technology.

headline: Robert James Waller, Author of ‘The Bridges of Madison County,’ Dies at 77
text: Robert James Waller, whose gauzy, romantic novel “The Bridges of Madison County” became a runaway best seller on its publication in 1992 and the basis of a popular film, died on Friday at his home in Fredericksburg, Tex. He was 77.

headline: After Warily Circling, Trump and Angela Merkel Prepare to Meet
text: WASHINGTON — When President Trump welcomes Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany to the Oval Office on Tuesday, their meeting will take on a symbolism unlike any he has held so far: The great disrupter confronts the last defender of the liberal world order.

headline: Daniel Arnold’s Tongue-in-Cheek Take on New York Style
text: Daniel Arnold has a fascination with Midtown Manhattan — “It’s kind of a time capsule of New York,” he said — and that’s where most of these photos were taken, between November and January. A photographer with over 135,000 followers on Instagram, Mr. Arnold is known for finding humor in everyday New York moments, like people standing around eating hot dogs or dogs pulling on their walkers. In this case, he was also looking for the lively and eccentric style found on the city’s wintry streets. He walked us through the moments he captured below.

headline: IndyCar Racing, No Longer Spinning Its Wheels, Draws Greater Interest
text: The 100th Indianapolis 500 did such an extraordinary box office last year, drawing the first sellout in race history with an estimated crowd of 350,000, that race officials understood that it would be virtually impossible to match ticket sales for the 101st race on May 28.

headline: Their Intimate Photos Were Shared. Now the Marine Corps Wants Them to Speak Up.
text: WASHINGTON — The Marine Corps’ top officer on Friday urged female Marines whose intimate photos were secretly shared by a members-only Facebook group of active-duty and retired Marines to come forward and cooperate with military investigators.

headline: South Korea Breathes a Sigh of Relief
text: SEOUL, South Korea — There was no hesitation, no ambiguity. On Friday, all eight judges on South Korea’s Constitutional Court voted to remove Park Geun-hye from the presidency.

headline: Carol Field, Italian Food Expert, Dies at 76
text: Carol Field, an authority on Italian cuisine whose classic cookbook “The Italian Baker,” published in 1985, introduced Americans to regional breads like ciabatta and focaccia, as well as to desserts, died on Friday in San Francisco. She was 76.

headline: Dutch Greens Make Inroads Days Before Vote for Parliament
text: AMSTERDAM — In the final days before next week’s parliamentary elections in the Netherlands, the far-right leader’s support appeared to be softening and a previously minor party, the Greens, led by a charismatic young politician, was poised to become one of the two top parties on the left.

headline: Another Spring (Sort of) for the Architect of the Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The day after Mets pitchers and catchers reported to the team’s spring training facility here a month ago, Sandy Alderson strolled through the clubhouse. He greeted each player by name, and a smile stretched across his face.

headline: New Guideline Will Allow First-Year Doctors to Work 24-Hour Shifts
text: First-year doctors in training will now be permitted to work shifts lasting as long as 24 hours, eight hours longer than the current limit, according to a professional organization that sets work rules for graduates from medical schools in the United States.

headline: The Triangle: A Simple Name for a Complex Basketball Scheme
text: When Courtney Lee was deciding whether to sign with the Knicks last summer, he did not really take into consideration the offensive system he would be asked to play within. He had already logged eight N.B.A. seasons, and most offenses in the league have only so much variance.

headline: With Preet Bharara’s Dismissal, Storied Office Loses Its Top Fighter
text: For more than seven years, Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, made a name for himself as one of the nation’s most aggressive and outspoken prosecutors of public corruption and Wall Street crime.

headline: Blade Runner Tests Limits of Prosthetics, Years After Oscar Pistorius
text: A decade after Oscar Pistorius caused track-and-field officials to re-examine their rules regarding the use of prosthetic limbs at the Olympics, a high school amputee is running in open competition on similar carbon-fiber blades. And once again, guidelines are gray, even nonexistent.

headline: Snapchat Pornography to Test Advertisers’ Tolerance for Risk
text: One of the most powerful advertising-buying firms has been warning its clients about the risks of their corporate marketing inadvertently showing up next to pornography on Snapchat.

headline: Republican Health Plan Could End Insurance Coverage of Abortion
text: The Republican proposal to replace the Affordable Care Act would bar people from using federal tax credits to buy health insurance plans that cover abortion.

headline: Trump’s Immigration Orders May Be Affecting Canada, U.S. Official Admits
text: OTTAWA — John F. Kelly, the American homeland security secretary, acknowledged on Friday that President Trump’s executive orders on immigration and the perception that the United States was now inhospitable toward Muslims may be causing more migrants to seek refuge in Canada.

headline: How Healthy Are You? G.O.P. Bill Would Help Employers Find Out
text: A bill in Congress could make it harder for workers to keep employers from getting access to their personal medical and genetic information and raise the financial penalties for those who opt out of workplace wellness programs.

headline: Wealthy Would Get Billions in Tax Cuts Under Obamacare Repeal Plan
text: Two of the biggest tax cuts in Republican proposals to repeal the Affordable Care Act would deliver roughly $144 billion over the coming decade to those with incomes of $1 million or more, according to a congressional analysis.

headline: Breaking Up With ‘The Bachelor’
text: I’ve spent a lot of time since Nov. 8 wondering how Donald J. Trump happened, and whether any part of his vindictive, chaotic and xenophobic presidency might, in some small way, be my fault.

headline: Pacification, Through the Barrel of a Gun
text: With 11,000 men killed and little to show for it, 1967, in retrospect, is remembered as a year of concern for the United States in the Vietnam War. But at the time, optimism reigned. The offensive operations by American military forces throughout 1966 had halted the gains of the People’s Army of Vietnam and the People’s Liberation Armed Forces (known to its enemies as the Viet Cong). Those gains, combined with mounting efforts to “pacify” the civilian population, seemed to point the way toward victory — if not in 1967, then soon after.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Steady Job Gains Set Stage for Fed to Raise Key Rate
text: “They may have been phony in the past, but it’s very real now.”

headline: Glad Tidings About the Three Faces of Donald Trump
text: Good news: the president seems pretty enthusiastic about bringing down drug prices. This is important both because drug prices are way too high and because positive reports out of Washington are so very, very rare.

headline: Duke, Shrugging Off the Boos, Rallies to Beat North Carolina
text: For North Carolina fans visiting Brooklyn for the first time this week to attend the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, the irritation of jumping over a slush puddle only to barely miss a subway train has not been nearly as bad as the sight of Duke’s Grayson Allen.

headline: Bernie Sanders: Trump Should Avoid a Bad Zika Deal
text: Donald J. Trump told the American people during his presidential campaign, “This country is being drained of its jobs and its money because we have stupid people making bad deals.” He promised to make better deals, ones in which we would win so much we “may even get tired of winning.”

headline: Try to Win
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Natan Last is no stranger to word introduction, and part of this puzzle’s challenge was the admirable number of new crossword entries, especially in the acrosses. This was a puzzle I had (for schedule reasons) to start and finish in more than one sitting and I think the time away, to let the middle region of my brain make connections, helped me solve in general. I answered a few short down gimmes like LILO, SHAD, RUE and DATA, gave the whole grid a once-over, then left it alone for a day and a night, and when I came back several of the long answers popped into mind.

headline: Trump Ends Silence With Palestinians, Opening a Path
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump spoke with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Friday for the first time since taking office and invited him to visit the White House, opening a new avenue of diplomacy as he develops his own peace initiative for the Middle East.

headline: Rugby’s More Perfect Union
text: In Dublin next Saturday, Ireland and England will play the final game of the Six Nations Championship. Thousands of miles away, in an office in New York, I will follow every pass, kick, tackle, ruck and scrum.

headline: Sue While the Conflicts Are Hot
text: The president’s son Eric probably said it best: “I think our brand is the hottest it has ever been.” No surprise there — nothing like a presidency to boost business. It is nevertheless shocking to see the brazenness of the ethical conflicts and watch the first family celebrate its good fortune.

headline: What the Jobs Report Is Telling Mr. Trump
text: Wait a minute, didn’t President Trump say he had inherited a mess? Yet there he was on Friday retweeting a Twitter post about the solid February jobs report. “GREAT AGAIN:+235,000.”

headline: Henry Fowler concerned over “two quarterbacks”
text: Henry Fowler concerned over “two quarterbacks”

headline: Anne Friedman Glauber, Champion of Social Causes, Dies at 63
text: Anne Friedman Glauber, who amplified her voice as a public relations executive to help prevent domestic violence, empower women in war-torn countries and support fellow patients of pancreatic cancer, died on Feb. 28 in Manhattan. She was 63.

headline: Muhammad Ali Jr., Detained Last Month at Airport, Stopped Again
text: One day after Muhammad Ali Jr. spoke with members of Congress about being detained at a Florida airport last month, he was briefly stopped again before boarding a flight on Friday afternoon, his lawyer said.

headline: A Biddle Jackson Fight
text: A Biddle-Jackson fight.

headline: United States, With a Halting First Step, Chases Its First World Baseball Classic Title
text: MIAMI — As their opening game of the World Baseball Classic stretched into extra innings on Friday, the United States’ players faced an unsettling possibility. Starting with the top of the 11th at all W.B.C. games, every inning must begin with runners on first and second bases.

headline: Why can’t he wait?
text: Why can’t he wait.

text: Hurt my pride

text: A new Fed chief

headline: Canada Today: A Dead-End Road, Judging a Judge and Broadway
text: Last month we looked at migrants entering Canada through sometimes risky, illegal border crossings from the perspective of the Canadian side of the border. This week, Rick Rojas went to the part of New York State known as the North Country to provide the reverse border perspective through an article about how people are making their way to the border. Here are his thoughts on the experience:

headline: Letter From Foreign Policy Experts on Travel Ban
text: More than 130 members of America’s foreign policy establishment denounced President Trump’s revised travel ban on Friday as just as damaging to the United States’ interests and reputation as his original order.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘S.N.L.’ and the Kids’ Choice Awards
text: Scarlett Johansson hosts “Saturday Night Live,” on NBC. And this weekend is your last opportunity to stream the opening-night concert at the Pierre Boulez Saal in Berlin, designed by Frank Gehry, on arte.tv.

headline: Trump’s Revised Travel Ban Is Denounced by 134 Foreign Policy Experts
text: WASHINGTON — More than 130 members of America’s foreign policy establishment denounced President Trump’s revised travel ban on Friday as just as damaging to the United States’ interests and reputation as his original order that halted refugees and froze travelers from predominantly Muslim countries.

headline: In Reversal, Boston St. Patrick’s Day Parade Welcomes Gay Veterans Group
text: A group of gay and transgender military veterans barred from marching in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in South Boston will now be allowed to participate in the March 19 event.

headline: How a Mother Copes With Zika
text: At the epicenter of the Zika crisis, a mother in Recife, Brazil, struggles to care for her afflicted baby.

headline: A Zika Tale in a Favela
text: RECIFE, Brazil — At night, rats often scurry on top of the thin gray mattress where Maria de Fátima dos Santos and Paulo Rogério Cavalcanti de Araújo sleep with their two small children in a one-room house with a floor of dirt and concrete, and a green plastic basin for a toilet.

headline: Want to Help Those Coping With Zika?
text: The following organizations direct donations to help cope with Zika in Latin America. Depending on the organization, the funding may be used to help provide services to affected families, educate people about preventing Zika infection, contribute to efforts to improve diagnosis, or other functions.

headline: Backpage’s Sex Ads Are Gone. Child Trafficking? Hardly.
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Since she was 14, Tiffany says, she has been sold for sex, offered via hundreds of advertisements on Backpage.com, a website that grew rich on classified ads for services like escorts, body rubs and exotic dancers. Far from being a marketplace for consensual exchanges, Backpage, the authorities said, often used teasers like “Amber Alert” and “Lolita” to signal that children were for sale.

headline: Behind the Quiet State-by-State Fight Over Electric Vehicles
text: When Georgia repealed its generous $5,000 tax credit on electric vehicles in July 2015, and instead slapped a $200 registration fee on electric cars, sales quickly tumbled.

headline: For Brazil’s Zika Families, a Life of Struggle and Scares
text: ESCADA, Brazil — Not a soul was in sight on the narrow dusty street, except for a cat skittering under a three-quarter moon.

headline: ‘Realize One Day You’ll Be Old’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: I’m Not O.K. Neither Are You. Who Cares?
text: Most self-help books make exhausting demands of their readers. The endless list-making and inventorying. The frequent deployment of the encomium “Yay, you!” The tacit assertion that “journey” has not been overexposed as a result of the “Don’t Stop Believin’” glut. It’s easy to conclude, why can’t someone just write a self-improvement book called “Canceling Lunch” and be done with it?

headline: Glenn Close and Patrick Kennedy on the Weight of Mental Illness
text: Glenn Close does not read her reviews. So the jumbo excerpt on the marquee where she is reprising her Tony Award-winning role in “Sunset Boulevard” (“One of the great stage performances of this century”), surrounded by flashing lights, may be a spoiler.

headline: Damascus Bombings Near Pilgrimage Sites Kill Dozens
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A double bombing near Shiite shrines often visited by foreign pilgrims in Damascus, Syria, killed at least 40 people on Saturday, shattering the capital’s efforts to isolate itself from the war raging elsewhere in the country. Many of the dead were from neighboring Iraq.

headline: Narendra Modi’s B.J.P. Party Wins Big in Uttar Pradesh, India’s Largest State
text: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi led his party to a landslide victory in India’s largest state on Saturday, consolidating his power and putting him in a strong position to win re-election in 2019.

headline: Farhad’s and Cecilia’s Week in Tech: Tech Policy, Too, Is Undergoing a Sea Change
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is out this week, so Cecilia Kang, a tech reporter in Washington, stepped in.

headline: Yemen Market Airstrike Kills at Least 16 People
text: SANA, Yemen — An airstrike by a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia on an open market in western Yemen killed at least 16 people, United Nations and local officials said Saturday.

headline: Is a Co-op Required to Report Break-Ins to Shareholders?
text: Q. In January, a burglar slipped into our  co-op in Hudson Heights, Manhattan, behind a shareholder who was walking out. He stole a laundry cart  and  packages. The theft was reported to the police, but it took the board almost two weeks to notify shareholders. The notice minimized the event, failing to give a full account of it. What responsibility does the board have to shareholders  in reporting security breaches?

headline: Two Saves, One Life Together
text: James Williams and Marc Wenderoff were married March 11 at the Parker, a hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Barby K. Siegel, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: No Health Insurance Is Hard. No Phone? Unthinkable.
text: SPRINGVILLE, Utah — As the health care debate thundered away in Washington, Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah stirred up a social media squall the other day by suggesting that uninsured Americans should invest in their own health care “rather than getting that new iPhone that they just love.”

headline: Why U.S. Antimissile System in South Korea Worries China
text: BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal of its own, and now concerns about the effectiveness of that arsenal as a deterrent are driving it into confrontation with the United States over an antimissile system being built in South Korea. Here’s an explanation of why.

headline: Uprooted by War, Threatened by Boko Haram and Desperate to Go Home
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Dozens of drivers lined up in beat-up vehicles stuffed with mattresses, cooking pots and other belongings, clogging a road outside one of the most desperate and dangerous camps that serve as refuge from the war with Boko Haram.

headline: Belgium’s New Deportation Law Raises Red Flag With Civil Rights Groups
text: BRUSSELS — Belgium’s Parliament has quietly passed legislation giving the government extraordinary powers to deport legal residents on the mere suspicion of engagement in terrorist activities, or for “presenting a risk” to public order or national security, without a criminal conviction or the involvement of a judge.

headline: If Russia Inquiry Is Not ‘Legitimate,’ Democrats May Abandon It
text: WASHINGTON — They agreed just a week ago to the terms of a House Intelligence Committee investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. But now some of the panel’s Democrats are warning that they may pull their support for the inquiry if it becomes mired in party-line politics.

headline: Even Child Care Divides Parties. Ivanka Trump Tries Building a Bridge.
text: WASHINGTON — One evening last month, a small group of Republican lawmakers — all of them women — were summoned to the Roosevelt Room of the White House for a private meeting.

headline: Variety: Missing Links
text: VARIETY PUZZLE(S) — It took me forever and a day to make any progress on this variety puzzle, the style of which was new to me, and I really look forward to seeing your experiences in the comments.

headline: Intruder Gets Within Steps of White House
text: WASHINGTON — A man carrying a backpack jumped over a fence and got within several steps of the White House before being arrested late Friday, the Secret Service said. The intrusion, the first reported since President Trump took office, came as the president was inside the residence.

headline: A Work in Progress, Since Before the Civil War
text: If Page 1 is the front door to The New York Times, Pages 2 and 3 are the entranceway.

headline: From an Obit Writer, the Last Word on ‘The Last Word’
text: In her next life, Shirley MacLaine may come back as a movie critic — you never know. If she does (or even if she doesn’t), she won’t likely look back on “The Last Word,” released this month, as a current-life highlight.

headline: The Holy Grail for Reporters: Presidential Secrets
text: The New York Times and other news organizations are in pursuit of President Trump’s secrets, including his possible links to Russia and that most elusive of leaks: his tax returns.

headline: The G.O.P.’s High-Risk Strategy for Health Law Repeal
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump and House Republicans are pressing forward with a high-risk strategy to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, disregarding the views of medical professionals and potentially imperiling the party’s political future in conservative states where many voters stand to lose their health care.

headline: Meet Diego, the Centenarian Whose Sex Drive Saved His Species
text: CHARLES DARWIN RESEARCH STATION, Galápagos — Of all the giant tortoises on these islands, where the theory of evolution was born, only a few have received names that stuck.

headline: Latino Players Relish the World Baseball Classic
text: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — Two questions remain constant during the 2017 World Baseball Classic, the fourth installment of the tournament: Who will win? And how much will players care?

headline: Tenants on the 18th Floor
text: The New York Times is not the only newsroom at 620 Eighth Avenue.

headline: Tillerson Leads From State Dept. Shadows as White House Steps In
text: WASHINGTON — Henry A. Kissinger slipped into the State Department last week for a quiet lunch in his old office with Rex W. Tillerson, the former Exxon Mobil chief executive, who has all but covered himself in a cloak of invisibility in his first six weeks as secretary of state.

headline: Venezuelan Baseball Players Love Their Chaotic Country From Afar
text: Five years after he was kidnapped in his native Venezuela, Wilson Ramos, a catcher for the Tampa Bay Rays, finally secured the paperwork necessary for his family to live with him in the United States. Carlos Carrasco, a pitcher for the Cleveland Indians who was born in Venezuela, passed his United States citizenship test in August and has not returned to his birthplace for years.

headline: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara Says He Was Fired After Refusing to Quit
text: The call to Preet Bharara’s office from President Trump’s assistant came on Thursday. Would Mr. Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, please call back?

headline: Erdogan Calls Dutch ‘Nazi Remnants’ After Turkish Minister Is Barred
text: PARIS — The Dutch government on Saturday intensified a diplomatic dispute between Turkey and its NATO allies in Europe by refusing to let the Turkish foreign minister fly into the Netherlands to campaign on behalf of a referendum that would augment the power of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.

headline: Reader Responses to Our Underground Railroad Issue
text: In the March 5 edition of the Race/Related newsletter, we asked you to share explorations of your family history, after Monica Drake, travel editor at The Times, wrote about hers.

headline: Resist the Internet
text: So far, in my ongoing series of columns making the case for implausible ideas, I’ve fixed race relations and solved the problem of a workless working class. So now it’s time to turn to the real threat to the human future: the one in your pocket or on your desk, the one you might be reading this column on right now.

headline: In a Refugee’s Bags, Memories of Home
text: Seeds and saplings, musical instruments, elderly parents leaving home for the first time. Telephones containing recordings of voices, festivals, pictures of the missing and the dead. Recipes for eggplant stuffed with hot peppers. A nursery rhyme sung in a dying language. These are just some of what Syrian and Iraqi refugees and migrants bring with them as they travel across borders and into new lives.

headline: Are Your Sperm in Trouble?
text: Let’s begin with sex.

headline: A Lifeline for Troubled Veterans
text: After the United States withdrew troops from Iraq in 2011, thousands of combat troops were expelled from the force with less than honorable discharges as the military came under pressure to downsize quickly. This left a large number of veterans — including many kicked out for minor infractions — without access to health care and other benefits that are granted to service members who leave the armed forces with honorable discharges.

headline: Crime and the Adolescent Brain
text: When the Supreme Court banned capital punishment for crimes that were committed when a defendant was under the age of 18, it ruled that “standards of decency” had evolved to recognize that a juvenile’s “lack of maturity and an underdeveloped sense of responsibility” distinguished his crimes from those of an adult.

headline: Kiss Me, I’m Pretty Sure I’m Irish
text: Every person alive can define himself in a single sentence. That’s what the novelist Susan Rieger once told me, and as soon as she said it I knew what mine would be: I come from a large, Irish Catholic family.

headline: Don’t Think About the White Bear
text: I first heard about the white bear trick in my eighth-grade West Virginia studies class. The girl sitting in front of me turned around and said, “Try not to think of a white bear.”

headline: The Dangerous Safety of College
text: The moral of the recent melee at Middlebury College, where students shouted down and chased away a controversial social scientist, isn’t just about free speech, though that’s the rubric under which the ugly incident has been tucked. It’s about emotional coddling. It’s about intellectual impoverishment.

headline: In Los Angeles, a Festival of Love and Hapa-ness
text: Los Angeles — The current political moment, with its upwelling of nationalism and xenophobia, has a repellent taste, like a mouthful of citrus pith, all bitter and white.

headline: Prisoners of Boko Haram, Then Prisoners of Fame
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — The next time international do-gooders decide to lend their hashtag support to a cause in Africa, it would be wise to remember the fallout of the Bring Back Our Girls campaign.

headline: The Moral Failing of Obamacare Repeal
text: PITTSBURGH — Imagine a car crash. There’s twisted metal, broken glass and the low moaning of an injured human being. An ambulance arrives, and two emergency medical technicians get out.

headline: The Law’s Emotion Problem
text: In the 1992 Supreme Court case Riggins v. Nevada, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy acknowledged — perhaps unwittingly — that our legal system relies on a particular theory of the emotions. The court had ruled that a criminal defendant could not forcibly be medicated to stand trial, and Justice Kennedy concurred, stressing that medication might impair a defendant’s ability to exhibit his feelings. This, he warned, would interfere with the critical task, during the sentencing phase, of trying to “know the heart and mind of the offender,” including “his contrition or its absence.”

headline: Misogyny and Women in Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blackhawks’ Patrick Kane, an M.V.P., Is Still Looking to Improve
text: CHICAGO — For all of his natural talent and the seemingly endless collection of moves in his arsenal, Patrick Kane remains, in many ways, unsatisfied.

headline: Trump Adviser Had Twitter Contact With Figure Tied to Russians
text: WASHINGTON — Roger J. Stone Jr., an off-and-on adviser to President Trump for decades, has acknowledged that he had contact on Twitter with Guccifer 2.0, the mysterious online figure that is believed to be a front for Russian intelligence officials.

headline: Struggling With Japan’s Nuclear Waste, Six Years After Disaster
text: FUKUSHIMA DAIICHI NUCLEAR POWER STATION — Six years after the largest nuclear disaster in a quarter-century, Japanese officials have still not solved a basic problem: what to do with an ever-growing pile of radioactive waste. Each form of waste at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, where three reactors melted down after an earthquake and a tsunami on March 11, 2011, presents its own challenges.

headline: Texas Congressional Maps Are Struck Down for Discrimination
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A panel of federal judges in San Antonio has ruled that a handful of Texas congressional districts drawn by the Republican-dominated state Legislature in 2011 discriminated against black and Hispanic voters and violated the Voting Rights Act and the Constitution.

headline: Taking the Fifth
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you asked me in court, I’d gladly tell you that the title of this puzzle refers to the alphabet rather than the justice system, and stuff that gets taken doesn’t always get taken away.

headline: Reporting on Zika Families — and Their Resilience
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times.

headline: Bladed Runner Hunter Woodhall Fails to Qualify for Finals at Indoor Meet
text: The steep, claustrophobic curves at the Armory track in Manhattan took their toll Saturday on the high school runner Hunter Woodhall, a Paralympic medalist who was competing on prosthetic blades at the New Balance Nationals Indoor meet against some of the top scholastic stars.

headline: Princeton, at Center of Bull’s-Eye, Keeps Focus Against Penn
text: PHILADELPHIA — Princeton won the first game of the inaugural Ivy League men’s basketball postseason tournament Saturday, barely averting an upset by Penn and denying traditionalists an “I told you so.”

headline: New Ferguson Video Adds Wrinkle to Michael Brown Case
text: In the two and a half years since Michael Brown, a black 18-year-old, was shot and killed by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., the explosive case has been parsed in intricate detail. Witnesses offered varying descriptions of the fatal encounter. Investigators examined bloodstain evidence on the street where Mr. Brown died. And the police released a security video from a nearby store that showed Mr. Brown pushing a worker and taking cigarillos minutes before the shooting.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Tortoise Whose Sex Drive Saved His Species
text: “He’ll keep reproducing until death.”

headline: Corrections: March 12, 2017
text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Venezuela Outlasts Italy in a Marathon
text: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — Venezuela, one of the most talented teams in the World Baseball Classic, needed 10 innings and sustained two injuries in an 11-10 win over Italy on Saturday.

headline: United States Quiets Dominican Bats, but Only for a Time
text: MIAMI — Of all the American stars who were asked to play in the World Baseball Classic, Andrew Miller might have had the best excuse to say no. He had toiled for nearly 20 innings in the postseason for the Cleveland Indians, right through Game 7 of the World Series, when he finally seemed to tire. He could have eased into a new year.

headline: Camille Perri, Helen Pennock
text: Camille Perri and Helen Pennock were married March 10 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Alisa Fuentes, a staff member in the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Aliza Stern, Ian Grossman
text: Aliza Ann Stern and Ian Dov Grossman are to be married March 12 at the Schoolhouse at Cannondale, a restaurant in Wilton, Conn. Rabbi Colin Brodie is to perform the ceremony at Temple B’nai Torah in Trumbull, Conn.

headline: Kelly Paulson, Michael Furchtgott
text: Kelly Christina Paulson and Michael Max Furchtgott are to be married March 12 on a whale-watching vessel in the Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary in Maui, Hawaii. Rabbi Barry Axler is to officiate.

headline: Sheetal Rajagopal, Sushanth Bhaskarabhatla
text: Sheetal Rajagopal and Sushanth Bhaskarabhatla were married March 8 at the Chicago Marriage and Civil Union Court. Stephanie K. Miller, a judge of the First Municipal District of Chicago, officiated. On Dec. 21, the couple took part in a traditional Hindu ceremony in Bangalore, India.

headline: Lauren Weinstein, Eli Kintisch
text: Lauren Beth Weinstein and Eli Steven Kintisch are to be married March 12 at Hotel Monaco in Washington. Lilah L. Pomerance, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, is to officiate, with Cantor Benjamin Kintisch, the groom’s brother, participating.

headline: Laura Gleiberman, Seth Heller
text: Laura Gleiberman and Seth Isaac Heller were married March 11 at the Cosmos Club, a private social club in Washington. Rabbi Eric B. Stark officiated.

headline: Stephanie Simon, Michael Wax
text: Stephanie Nicole Simon, the daughter of Randi J. Simon and Dr. Richard J. Simon of Weston, Fla., was married March 11 to Michael Nathan Wax, the son of Ruth A. Silon of South Euclid, Ohio, and Mitchell L. Wax of Lakewood, Ohio. Rabbi Gayle Pomerantz officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Miami. Paul A. Engelmayer, a United States district judge for the Southern District of New York for whom the bride was a clerk from 2013 to 2014, participated.

headline: Putin and Merkel: A Rivalry of History, Distrust and Power
text: BERLIN — He was skinny in his trim, dark suit, an almost lupine figure, nervous and unexpectedly youthful for a president of Russia. Taking the lectern beneath the dome of the restored Reichstag, Vladimir V. Putin soon shifted to German, with a fluency that startled the German lawmakers and a pro-West message that reassured them. The Cold War seemed over.

headline: Sarah Melby, Jochem Zijp
text: Sarah Crommelin Melby and Jochem Philip Zijp were married March 11 at the Meridian House, an event space in Washington. Alexandra Melby Farnum, the bride’s sister, received permission from the Marriage Bureau of the District of Columbia Courts to officiate.

headline: Noah Levine, Jonathan Rebell
text: Noah Allen Levine and Jonathan Edward Rebell were married March 11 at the Angel Orensanz Foundation, an event space in New York. Andrew S. Koerner, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions.

headline: Jessica Cohen, Jeffrey Barmach
text: Jessica Cohen and Jeffrey Alan Barmach are to be married March 12 at Woodfield Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Michael G. Berenbaum, a cousin of the bride, is to officiate.

headline: Julia Powell, James Love IV
text: Dr. Julia Blair Powell and James Erskine Love IV were married March 11 at the Figure Eight Island Yacht Club in Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Scott Black Johnston, senior pastor of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, officiated.

headline: Caitlin Miller, Jared Dolan
text: Dr. Caitlin Mary Miller and Jared Edward Dolan were married March 10. Msgr. William Dever, a Roman Catholic priest and the great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church in Naples, Fla.

headline: Chasing Big Sports Goals, Rutgers Stumbles Into a Vat of Red Ink
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — Ah, how grandness beckoned. When Rutgers officials announced in 2012 that their university would join the Big Ten, one of the nation’s premier athletic conferences, the sun itself seemed to burn brighter.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘American Crime’ and ‘Jurassic Park’
text: ABC’s anthology series “American Crime” returns for its third season with a new story starring Felicity Huffman, Timothy Hutton and Regina King. And the first three “Jurassic Park” films are ripe for binge-watching on Netflix.

headline: Will the N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket Be Leaked Again? CBS Hopes Not
text: The anonymous Twitter poster who leaked last year’s N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament pairings halfway through CBS’s televised selection show is on the minds of a lot of people this weekend.

headline: Israel Wins Again in the W.B.C., Beating Cuba to Stay Undefeated
text: TOKYO — Israel had not played from behind during its magical run at the World Baseball Classic until Sunday, when it overcame an early one-run deficit to beat Cuba, 4-1, in the first game of the second round of the tournament.

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Donald Trump Botches His ‘Independence Day’ Moment
text: Sure, “Saturday Night Live” has offered ample criticism of President Trump and his young administration. But in its latest episode, the program expressed confidence that he’ll be in office until at least 2018, long enough to see America decimated by an alien invasion force from the planet Zorblatt 9.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
text: 210 Christopher Street, Montclair

headline: How the Republican Health Plan Could Affect You
text: Some examples of how the proposal’s effects could play out.

headline: What I Love | B.H. Barry
text: The name B.H. Barry was invented for a sideline gig. Now, Mr. Barry embraces his career as a fight director and delights in his penthouse duplex.

headline: A Stage Fight Director’s Gentler Side
text: African violets. A ukulele. “The first impression of me is a man of violence,” B.H. Barry said. But his home suggests otherwise. Step inside as part of our What I Love series.

headline: From Stage Combat to Hudson Views
text: You can see the Hudson rolling serenely along from the many windows in B. H. Barry’s penthouse duplex on the Upper West Side. Special tip for first-time visitors: The river is even more lovely to look at when you’re standing on the terrace off the 16th-floor living room.

headline: G.O.P. Desire to Keep Party Feuds Private Breaks Down Over Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — Top Republicans never like to see their internal party quarrels messily spilled out in public for all to see.

headline: Donald Trump, Republican Party, Daylight Saving: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Park Geun-hye, Ousted South Korean Leader, Leaves Presidential Palace
text: SEOUL, South Korea — For months, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators have gathered almost weekly near the presidential Blue House in Seoul, calling for the departure of Park Geun-hye as South Korea’s leader.

headline: Pakistan City’s Affluent Women Bring Islam Into Their Lives and Lifestyles
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — It was a weekday afternoon in an upscale neighborhood of Karachi, but the hall was packed for the lecture on Islam and marriage.

headline: He Didn’t Like ‘Homeland.’ Now He’s Advising It.
text: A sharply dressed lawyer represented his Muslim-American clients before a three-judge panel in New York recently, claiming that because federal authorities tried to coerce them into becoming informants, they had the right to receive monetary damages.

headline: Russian Espionage Piggybacks on a Cybercriminal’s Hacking
text: To the F.B.I., Evgeniy M. Bogachev is the most wanted cybercriminal in the world. The bureau has announced a $3 million bounty for his capture, the most ever for computer crimes, and has been trying to track his movements in hopes of grabbing him if he strays outside his home turf in Russia.

headline: After $225 Billion in Deals Last Year, China Reins In Overseas Investment
text: BEIJING — China struck $225 billion in deals to acquire companies abroad last year, a record-breaking number that signaled to the world that Chinese business leaders were hot to haggle.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Maoist Rebels Ambush and Kill 11 Police Officers in India
text: NEW DELHI — Maoist rebels killed 11 Indian police officers and seized their automatic weapons and ammunition after ambushing a foot patrol on Saturday morning in the eastern state of Chattisgarh, according to a police official.

headline: A Financial Lifeline for Owners of Historic Homes
text: You never know what you might find when you start peeling away layers. For Attila Piros, that is more than an aphorism. It is an explanation of why his rowhouse in a historic district in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was not what everyone thought it was.

headline: Heavy Snowfall Is Forecast Across Northeastern U.S.
text: Maybe you thought you were going to get through this winter without too much rough weather. Not so fast. If the current forecast is accurate, there is still some winter yet to come.

headline: 2017 N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket: Who Has the Edge in Each Region?
text: Villanova (31-3), which won last year’s N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament on a three-pointer at the buzzer in the championship game, was awarded the top overall seed in this year’s bracket, released Sunday evening, one day after winning the Big East tournament.

headline: An Incisive Play About Hasidism, With Actors Who Lived It
text: Melissa Weisz, a working actress in Manhattan, did not exactly grow up a drama club kid.

headline: Israel at the World Baseball Classic: From Curiosity to Contender
text: TOKYO — When Peter Kurz, the president of the Israel Association of Baseball, left home two weeks ago to accompany Team Israel on its first trip to the World Baseball Classic, he packed two passports, a decision that was both practical and whimsical.

headline: ‘Kong: Skull Island’ Roars as March Becomes a Tent-Pole Season
text: LOS ANGELES — As Hollywood has focused on making lumbering, all-audience movies stuffed with visual effects — “Kong: Skull Island,” which arrived on Friday, being a prime example — movie studios have run into a problem: where to put them all.

headline: Lloyd Conover, Inventor of Groundbreaking Antibiotic, Dies at 93
text: Lloyd H. Conover, a chemist whose breakthrough invention of one of the most effective and widely prescribed antibiotics, tetracycline, led to a whole new approach to developing such drugs, died on Saturday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 93.

headline: In Armenia, ‘What Do You Want to Be?’ Is Asked in Infancy
text: Children in Armenia start thinking about their careers at a very young age — around six months or so.

headline: Jordan Frees Soldier Who Killed 7 Israeli Schoolgirls in ’97 Rampage
text: JERUSALEM — The fragile treaty between the two former enemies was not even three years old when a Jordanian soldier went on a shooting rampage and killed seven Israeli schoolgirls visiting a park in a border area known as the Island of Peace.

headline: Narendra Modi, South Korea Impeachment, Netherlands: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: In Brooklyn, Police Find Toppled Tombstones, but No Crime
text: The headstone was made in 1915 for a wife and mother named Fannie who lived to be 54 years old. And last weekend, 102 years later, police officers stood around it in Washington Cemetery in Brooklyn, looking beyond the name and dates for other kinds of clues.

headline: 2 of a Farmer’s 3 Children Overdosed. What of the Third — and the Land?
text: BLANCHESTER, Ohio — A life of farming taught Roger Winemiller plenty about harsh twists of fate: hailstorms and drought, ragweed infestations and jittery crop prices. He hadn’t bargained on heroin.

headline: A Glimpse Into the Life of a Slave Sold to Save Georgetown
text: He was an enslaved teenager on a Jesuit plantation in Maryland on the night that the stars fell. It was November 1833, and meteor showers set the sky ablaze.

headline: Is ICE’s Help-Wanted Sign a Welcome Mat for Rogue Applicants, Too?
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump has vowed a hiring surge of 10,000 immigration and customs officers to accelerate the deportation of unauthorized immigrants. But the aggressive pace he has laid out risks adding to the ranks of rogue agents who have been charged with abusing immigrants.

headline: Trump Lets Key Offices Gather Dust Amid ‘Slowest Transition in Decades’
text: WASHINGTON — At the State Department, the normally pulsating hub of executive offices is hushed and virtually empty. At the Pentagon, military missions in some of the world’s most troubled places are being run by a defense secretary who has none of his top team in place. And at departments like Treasury, Commerce and Health and Human Services, many senior posts remain vacant even as the agencies have been handed enormous tasks like remaking the nation’s health insurance system.

headline: Trump Wants Faster Growth. The Fed Isn’t So Sure.
text: WASHINGTON — For President Trump and his economic advisers, the strong February jobs report was a cause for celebration — and a first step toward delivering on the president’s promise of faster economic growth.

headline: As Daylight Saving Starts, Some Ask: Why Fall Back at All?
text: DAMARISCOTTA, Me. — Several years ago, the owner of a sandwich shop on the main drag here grew so tired of turning the clocks back in the fall — and witnessing the early sunsets that followed — that he simply decided not to. That year, he kept his shop on daylight saving time all winter.

headline: Members of the Italian Band Soviet Soviet Are Deported
text: Members of the Italian postpunk trio Soviet Soviet, booked to play at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., were detained in Seattle on Wednesday and eventually deported by United States Customs and Border Protection officials as immigration enforcement under the Trump administration continues to cause tension.

headline: The Five Big Numbers to Look For in the C.B.O. Report on Health Care Reform
text: The Congressional Budget Office is expected to “score” the Republicans’ health plan this week. Here, based on some expert estimates, is a guide to the key numbers.

headline: An Opera Inspired by Pink Floyd Will Get Its United States Premiere
text: The Cincinnati Opera has announced the United States premiere of “Another Brick in the Wall: The Opera,” capping its 98th season and its first after a $135 million restoration of the Cincinnati Music Hall. Opening in July 2018, “Another Brick in the Wall” features original words and music by Roger Waters of the psychedelic rock band Pink Floyd, whose 1979 album, “The Wall,” inspired the opera. The production made its world premiere at Opéra de Montréal in Quebec on Saturday.

headline: In Chicago and Philadelphia, the Difference a Park Makes
text: CHICAGO — Despite the bitter wind, Kim Wasserman showed me around La Villita Park. Occupying 21 acres in the middle of this city’s largest Mexican-American neighborhood, called Little Village, the park used to be a brownfield and illegal dump. Back then, the site leached toxins into hundreds of nearby basements. Sickened residents protested for years. The federal cleanup, finally completed in 2012, became the largest urban Superfund project in America.

headline: Richard Simmons’s Disappearing Act Inspires a Hit Podcast
text: Richard Simmons is not being tormented by black magic — or so says Mr. Simmons, the fitness guru, whose disappearance from public view three years ago has at least one close friend fearing he is under the spell of a witch.

headline: Live! With The Times: Singer-Songwriter Valerie June
text: The singer-songwriter Valerie June came to The New York Times headquarters on Monday, March 13 to perform songs for you and answer your questions. Read the conversation here.

headline: The President Changed. So Has Small Businesses’ Confidence.
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — The cream of the small-business community here tucked into their lunch on a top floor of a bank building and pondered the question put to them by their local lender’s economist.

headline: Why Winning a State Election Will Strengthen Modi’s Populism
text: VARANASI, India — India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, is a mesmerizing orator, in the way of a talk-show host with an acerbic tongue, and this month a campaign crowd of more than 50,000 showed up in Deoria, a hardscrabble town in the state of Uttar Pradesh, to hear his story. They knew and loved the part about how this son of a tea seller rose through the party ranks with no help from family connections. But the rest of his rags-to-power tale is changing fast.

headline: Review: In ‘Badrinath Ki Dulhania,’ Boy Meets Girl (and Learns to Respect Her)
text: Recent Bollywood movies have tried out, hesitantly and conservatively, versions of the Modern Woman: Heroines can have careers; they can live alone in the big city; they can even (if very rarely) have sex before marriage.

headline: Toronto’s Housing Boom Refills Empty Nests, Driving Prices Even Higher
text: OAKVILLE, Ontario — Janet Barber doesn’t dwell too much on the view from her driveway.

headline: Trump Far Behind Obama’s Pace on Nominees
text: A chart from the Office of Government Ethics obtained by The New York Times shows that the office had received only 63 disclosure reports for prospective Trump administration nominees as of March 5, less than a third of the 228 that Mr. Obama’s team had submitted by that date in 2009.

headline: Why ‘The Outsiders’ Lives On: A Teenage Novel Turns 50
text: TULSA, Okla. — On a particularly windy day in the Crutchfield neighborhood here, the writer S. E. Hinton was touring the renovations of the future Outsiders House museum. The rundown Craftsman bungalow was where the Curtis brothers — Darry, Sodapop and Ponyboy — lived in the 1983 Francis Ford Coppola movie based on Ms. Hinton’s book “The Outsiders.”

headline: An American Immigrant in Paris
text: PARIS — Soon after Donald Trump was inaugurated, I got a letter from France’s interior ministry informing me that I was now French. By the time it arrived, I’d been French for nearly two weeks, without even knowing it. (“Had you felt yourself becoming more and more rude?” a friend asked.)

headline: After Five Years of Bach, Trinity Church Takes On Handel
text: Bach at One — the free concert series in which the musical forces of Trinity Wall Street, directed by Julian Wachner, performed all of Bach’s sacred works over five years in St. Paul’s Chapel — mostly ran like clockwork. And on its return to the newly renovated chapel on March 6, with an altered focus, it gave every sign that it will continue to do so.

headline: It’s in the Stratosphere
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — If you’re tempted on a Monday to creep back to bed, you’ll understand the challenge of diving in, taking the plunge, committing to another week of peaks and valleys (and hopefully no geopolitical apocalypses). Since the top and bottom thirds of this grid had clues that spanned from left to right, there were plenty of supportive crosses that made the solve pretty quick for me.

headline: What’s Madison Avenue Pitching Now? Cultural and Political Awareness
text: Madison Avenue exists to persuade. (Check out how stylish this car looks! Doesn’t everyone seem to be having a great time while drinking this beer?) In a perilous political climate, however, some advertising agencies have decided to use their marketing acumen in service of advancing cultural and political causes, rather than selling products.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 13
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Heng on North Korea and Malaysia’s Bans
text: A bitter dispute over the investigation into the killing of Kim Jong-nam has resulted in the nations blocking each other’s citizens from leaving the country.

headline: George A. Olah, Carbon Compounds Pathfinder, Dies at 89
text: George A. Olah, a Hungarian-born scientist who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1994 for his study of the chemical reactions of carbon compounds, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.

headline: For Solace and Solidarity in the Trump Age, Liberals Turn the TV Back On
text: There is a new safe space for liberals in the age of President Trump: the television set.

headline: Trump Administration Is Said to Be Working to Loosen Counterterrorism Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is exploring how to dismantle or bypass Obama-era constraints intended to prevent civilian deaths from drone attacks, commando raids and other counterterrorism missions outside conventional war zones like Afghanistan and Iraq, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: Miscue Calls Attention to Amazon’s Dominance in Cloud Computing
text: SEATTLE — There have been many opportunities to consider how crucial Amazon has become to the smooth operation of the internet over the past few years.

headline: Printable N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket
text: North Carolina defeats Gonzaga to win its sixth N.C.A.A. championship.

headline: John Surtees, Two- and Four-Wheel Racing Champion, Dies at 83
text: John Surtees, an Englishman who won seven world motorcycle championships, then switched to auto racing and captured the 1964 Formula One points title, becoming the only racer to hold both two- and four-wheel world crowns, died on Friday in London. He was 83.

headline: Gonzaga Earns Second No. 1 Seed, and Hopes for Better Luck This Time
text: One-loss Gonzaga was installed as a No. 1 seed for the second time in program history, but the last time, in 2013, did not go so well. The Bulldogs lost to ninth-seeded Wichita State in the second round. But while Gonzaga (32-1) still has never been to a Final Four, the Bulldogs are a worthy No. 1: They lost only to Brigham Young and outscored opponents by more than 23 points a game. The Zags’ biggest problem? Arizona, the Pac-12 champion, lurks at No. 2.

headline: Losing a Step in the Subway Seat Game
text: Dear Diary:

headline: For Children Caught in Syria’s War, 2016 Was Worst Year Yet, U.N. Says
text: Children suffered a “drastic escalation” in violence from the Syrian civil war in 2016, the United Nations said Sunday in a report that showed child deaths jumped at least 20 percent from the year before and recruitment of child combatants more than doubled.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Yadier Molina Criticizes Security at World Baseball Classic
text: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — St. Louis Cardinals catcher Yadier Molina, who is playing for Puerto Rico in the World Baseball Classic, accused Major League Baseball of failing to provide security in the section where Puerto Rico players’ families sat during a 9-4 win over Mexico on Saturday.

headline: Man Without an ISIS Plan
text: On the campaign trail, no foreign policy issue seized Donald Trump more than the fight against the Islamic State. Once president, he signed an executive order giving his generals 30 days to produce a plan to defeat the terrorist group, and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis gave him options on Feb. 27.

headline: Steve King Says Civilization Can’t Be Restored With ‘Somebody Else’s Babies’
text: Representative Steve King, a Republican from Iowa who has a history of making inflammatory statements viewed by many as insensitive or outright racist, was roundly criticized on Sunday for his apparent endorsement of white nationalism.

headline: Joni Sledge, Singer in the ‘We Are Family’ Group Sister Sledge, Dies at 60
text: Joni Sledge, who along with her three sisters formed the disco-era family quartet Sister Sledge, best known for the hit song “We Are Family,” was found dead in her home in Phoenix on Friday. She was 60.

headline: Jay Lynch, Underground Comics Creator, Dies at 72
text: Jay Lynch, an artist, writer and satirist who was a central figure in the underground comics revolution of the 1960s and ’70s, died on March 5 at his home in Candor, N.Y. He was 72.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Familiar Favorites and Compelling Underdogs
text: The last anyone saw of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, Villanova’s Kris Jenkins was sinking a buzzer-beating 3-pointer to top North Carolina in the 2016 championship game.

headline: Board to Decide Puerto Rico’s Financial Future; Fed Rate Boost Is on Way
text: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

headline: The Choose-Your-Own-News Adventure
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A fascinating story emerged about Netflix last week.

headline: Turkey’s Relations With Europe Sink Amid Quarrel With Netherlands
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s quarrel with Europe worsened over the weekend after the Turkish president accused the Dutch government of Nazism, and Turkish politicians were barred or disinvited from events in two European countries, amid tensions ahead of a tight referendum on a new Turkish Constitution.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Heroin Infests Farms, a Grieving Parent Fears for the Future
text: “It’s in my blood. It’s the family name. I’ve done enough to disgrace our name. I want to do everything I can to mend it.”

headline: Preet Bharara Shunned Politics. His End Was Tinged by Them.
text: Ten days into his tenure as United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara saw his political and prosecutorial worlds collide.

headline: Mets Players at World Baseball Classic Reconnect With Roots
text: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — When Mets pitcher Seth Lugo speaks, the Louisiana in him becomes apparent. There is a Southern accent and no hint that he has Puerto Rican roots. He does not speak Spanish, and he had never been to the island until last month, when he met his relatives there for the first time. He jokes with his family that he is “quarter-Rican.”

headline: White House Addresses Trump’s Unorthodox Call to Preet Bharara
text: WASHINGTON — The White House offered an explanation on Sunday for a mysterious phone call that President Trump placed to Preet Bharara a day before abruptly dismissing him and 45 other United States attorneys, saying the president was merely trying to extend his good wishes.

headline: Preet Bharara’s Dismissal Has a Nixon-Era Parallel
text: The resignation statement from the United States attorney in Manhattan was blunt: “I hope that my fight for independence will make it easier for my successor to withstand the harsh, narrow partisan views on law enforcement currently in favor at the Department of Justice in Washington.”

headline: HSBC Names Mark Tucker to be First Outsider as Chairman
text: LONDON — Mark Tucker, chief executive of the Asian life insurer AIA Group, is set to replace Douglas Flint as chairman of HSBC in October, the bank said on Sunday.

headline: New Labor Nominee: Fair Leader or Self-Serving One?
text: MIAMI — In 2008, three years after R. Alexander Acosta had decamped from the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division for the United States attorney’s post in South Florida, the Justice Department’s in-house investigator laid out a damning conclusion: Under Mr. Acosta’s watch, his office had repeatedly violated federal law and department policies by weighing political affiliations in hiring and assessing civil rights employees.

headline: ‘Homeland,’ Season 6, Episode 8: The Never-Ending Trials of Quinn
text: Well, now I’m upset. And not in a good way.

headline: Review: ‘Villa’ Dramatizes a Plot of Chilean Land With a Dark Past
text: First, the atrocity. Then the architecture.

headline: Review: ‘Come From Away,’ a Canadian Embrace on a Grim Day
text: Try, if you must, to resist the gale of good will that blows out of “Come From Away,” the big bearhug of a musical that opened on Sunday night at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. But even the most stalwart cynics may have trouble staying dry-eyed during this portrait of heroic hospitality under extraordinary pressure.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 7, Episode 13: Morgan Takes a Turn
text: “This is it, Morgan. You have to kill, or else you might as well just kill yourself.”

headline: ‘Feud: Bette and Joan’ Episode 2: Give the People What They Want
text: After a tough day shooting “What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?,” director Robert Aldrich complains to his wife (Molly Price) that his two stars — Bette Davis and Joan Crawford — have ganged up on him, undermining his power on the set. He seethes that Jack Palance and Lee Marvin would never have resorted to such maneuvers. His wife replies flatly: “They don’t have to. They’re men.”

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: More Wendy, Please
text: In the first season of “Billions,” Wendy Rhoades acted as the narrative linchpin, the basest and truest explanation for why Chuck and Axe went to war against each other. As played so shrewdly by Maggie Siff, Wendy is the trophy that cannot be possessed, despite the claims made on her by both men in her life. Nevertheless, Chuck opened up an investigation against Axe Capital because Axe’s corruptive enterprise had Wendy under contract as its in-house enabler, coaching analysts to attack vulnerabilities in the market as lions would a wounded gazelle. Chuck couldn’t accept Wendy as a mere partner in their marriage — she was his woman, and her professional relationship with Axe felt to him like betrayal, a sexless affair.

headline: Playing for Fans Who Travel, Dominicans Feel Right at Home
text: MIAMI — The empty upper decks at Marlins Park on Sunday night said much about the stateside appeal of the World Baseball Classic. The host country was playing Canada in prime time, with a berth in the second round at stake. Yet an announced crowd of just 22,303 dropped by to politely enjoy the United States’ 8-0 victory.

headline: Willing to Blow the Whistle on Doping? New Legal Aid Group Wants to Help
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Inspired by the Russian doping scandal, a new nonprofit foundation is offering financial and legal assistance to whistle-blowers with information about cheating in international sports.

headline: Lowly Nets Send Knicks to 41st Loss
text: Knicks forward Kristaps Porzingis slumped his 7-foot-3 body into a chair in a dour visitors’ locker room at Barclays Center on Sunday and went about examining the latest turbulence in his team’s chaotic season. He had plenty of material, but little clarity.

headline: No Corrections: March 13, 2017
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Going to bat
text: Going to bat

headline: Four Players to Watch in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: When Kris Jenkins attended the ESPY Awards in July, the former N.B.A. sharpshooter Robert Horry made a point of coming over to share a moment.

headline: Excess capacity
text: Excess capacity

headline: Changing Dynamics for England’s Elite Devalue ‘the Double’
text: By the time Alex Ferguson sat down, late in 1999, to compose the first of his several memoirs, he had already accumulated a slew of honors. Championships in his native Scotland and in England. An assortment of cups, at home and abroad. And his most recent, most treasured: a long-awaited victory in the Champions League.

headline: An AIDS Museum: The Challenges Are Huge, but the Timing Is Right
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The National AIDS Memorial Grove in Golden Gate Park here is a somber glen of plants, trees, walks, grass and cairn, with thousands of names etched in stones and pavement. Visitors’ emotions run high, but the details of exactly how AIDS devastated and transformed the world are not found here.

headline: Netherlands Considers a New Relationship to Muslims With Coming Election
text: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands — Like many Muslims, Ahmed Aboutaleb has been disturbed by the angry tenor of the Dutch election campaign. Far-right candidates have disparaged Islam, often depicting Muslims as outsiders unwilling to integrate into Dutch culture.

headline: Forget Foreign Hacking. The Big Surprise Was a Candid F.B.I.
text: Of all the surprises Michael Schwirtz and Joseph Goldstein encountered while reporting today’s front-page story on America’s most wanted hacker, perhaps none was bigger than this: For once, the F.B.I. was excited to talk to them.

headline: Referees Refuse to Work Soccer Games in Mexico
text: Mexican sports fans mourned a weekend without soccer after referees for the country’s first-tier league refused to officiate games in protest of the decision not to impose tougher punishments on two players who shoved officials.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Bachelor’ and Beethoven
text: “The Bachelor” wraps up its 21st season as Nick Viall gives a rose to the winning woman — his potential fiancée. And on Medici.tv, Gustavo Dudamel begins conducting the cycle of Beethoven’s nine symphonies, which continues through Wednesday.

headline: Netherlands, Angela Merkel, Park Geun-hye: Your Monday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: With a Racket in One Hand, World Team Tennis Passes a Torch With the Other
text: In its early days, World Team Tennis attracted big stars and big opposition.

headline: A Vanishing Way of Life in Spain’s Coal Region
text: A once-proud workforce has seen its fortunes dwindle in Spain, where the government has found it cheaper to import coal.

headline: A G.O.P. Cri de Coeur, Deconstructed
text: To the Editor:

headline: Protectionism in the Guise of Tax Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Want to Keep the President at Bay? Two Consultants Have an Inside Track
text: Attention: corporate America.

headline: A Silicon Valley Train Gets Stuck
text: President Trump’s promise to repair crumbling roads, bridges, railways and other public works is off to a terrible start. Before his administration has even come up with the $1 trillion infrastructure proposal he has repeatedly promised, his Department of Transportation is sabotaging an important commuter rail project in California opposed by the state’s Republicans. This doesn’t send a good signal about the Trump administration’s commitment to infrastructure investment.

headline: Facts Are Enemies of the People
text: The U.S. economy added 10.3 million jobs during President Obama’s second term, or 214,000 a month. This brought the official unemployment rate below 5 percent, and a number of indicators suggested that by late last year we were fairly close to full employment. But Donald Trump insisted that the good news on jobs was “phony,” that America was actually suffering from mass unemployment.

headline: The Never-Ending War in Afghanistan
text: BOSTON — Remember Afghanistan? The longest war in American history? Ever?

headline: Trump and the Parasitic Presidency
text: We have now passed the 50-day mark of the Donald Trump administration and one thing is clear: There is no new Trump.

headline: What Our Cells Teach Us About a ‘Natural’ Death
text: Every Thursday morning on the heart transplant service, our medical team would get a front-row seat to witness an epic battle raging under a microscope. Tiny pieces of heart tissue taken from patients with newly transplanted hearts would be broadcast onto a gigantic screen, showing static images of pink heart cells being attacked by varying amounts of blue immune cells. The more blue cells there were, the more voraciously they were chomping away the pink cells, the more evidence that the patient’s inherently xenophobic immune system was rejecting the foreign, transplanted heart.

headline: Angels and Demons in the Cold War and Today
text: LOS ANGELES — George Kennan knew how to bring down the house. His lecture audiences started off skeptical about whether Russia really wanted to be remade on the American model. Then he told them about the Russian political prisoners who spent the weeks before the Fourth of July scrounging bits of cloth in red, white and blue. When the holiday came, they met their jailers by waving a sea of tiny hand-sewn stars and stripes through the bars.

headline: In Spain, ‘Mining Towns Become Ghost Towns’
text: From the stoic, coal-smudged faces of miners to the worn and scuffed tools of their trade, Álvaro Laiz’s photographs of northern Spain’s coal industry have a quiet dignity about them. They speak to an era when men with little education made a good, if dangerous, living. But now, like the tools that are museum relics, the miners themselves are being relegated to memory.

headline: Happy Holi! Celebrating Spring in India
text: Revel in Holi, a Hindu festival of spring, in the area where it is believed the festival originated.
