text: One member of New York City’s emergency medical services was killed and another injured when a man got into the driver’s seat of their ambulance and ran over one of them in the Bronx on Thursday night, the authorities said.

headline: With E.P.A. Cuts, States Would Lose Help in Emergencies
text: WASHINGTON — Late one Friday night in 2014, Ohio’s environmental agency received word of a frightening test result from Toledo’s water supply: A toxic greenish substance had rendered the drinking water of half a million Toledo residents unsafe to drink.

headline: From a Placid Judge, a Cutting Rejection of Trump’s Travel Ban
text: Judge Derrick K. Watson’s language was stern, even biting: In an order on Wednesday that blocked President Trump’s travel ban from taking effect, he rebuked the government for its “illogic” and for presenting arguments he bluntly called “not true.”

text: The White House budget director, Mick Mulvaney, defended the president’s budget proposal for 2018 by saying it puts numbers on Mr. Trump’s campaign promises.

headline: A Shift From ‘Soft Power’ Diplomacy in Cuts to the State Dept.
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson was on the other side of the planet on Thursday when the Trump administration announced that it would slash his department’s budget by 31 percent, potentially eliminating thousands of jobs.

headline: Women’s National Team Stands Firm in Face of U.S.A. Hockey’s Deadline
text: After members of the United States women’s national hockey team decided Wednesday to boycott the approaching world championship over stalled negotiations for increased wages and support, U.S.A. Hockey’s executive director, Dave Ogrean, announced that he looked forward “to continuing our discussions” with the players.

headline: Buoyed by Trump Budget Plan, Pentagon Draws Up a Shopping List
text: WASHINGTON — The biggest beneficiary in President Trump’s budget — the Defense Department — released a broad wish list on Thursday, signaling what it would do with its proposed $54 billion windfall, filling its shopping cart with desires including Apache helicopters for the Army, anti-submarine planes for the Navy, fighter jets and more training for selected personnel.

headline: Hacker Is a Villain to Russia and the United States, for Different Reasons
text: MOSCOW — Before United States prosecutors accused him of having orchestrated one of the largest computer thefts, Dmitry A. Dokuchaev’s legal problems were deepening in Russia, where he was once known by the hacker alias Forb and specialized in purloining credit card numbers.

headline: Sheldon Silver Appeal Looks to New Definition of Corruption
text: A lawyer for Sheldon Silver cited a unanimous Supreme Court decision that narrowed the definition of what kind of conduct can serve as the basis for a corruption prosecution, as he argued on Thursday that the disgraced former speaker of the State Assembly should be acquitted or granted a new trial.

headline: Campaign Pledges Haunt Trump in Court
text: WASHINGTON — In quick succession on Wednesday night, federal judges in Hawaii and Maryland blocked President Trump’s revised travel ban. They said statements Mr. Trump had made as a presidential candidate, including his call for “a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States,” helped doom the executive order.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Researchers Bristle at Extent of Cuts
text: “As to climate change, I think the president was fairly straightforward: We’re not spending money on that anymore.”

headline: Irish Premier Uses St. Patrick’s Day Ritual to Lecture Trump on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — On a calendar of foreign visitors that includes President Xi Jinping of China and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, the annual visit by the taoiseach of Ireland to mark St. Patrick’s Day should have been a delightful distraction for President Trump.

headline: Zack Wheeler, Mets’ Big Question Mark, Provides Some Answers
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — The biggest question on the Mets’ pitching staff took the mound Thursday afternoon for the second time this spring. In his second outing, after sitting out for two seasons, Zack Wheeler allowed two runs on three hits in two and a third innings. He threw 50 pitches, walked one and struck out two.

headline: Tanner Glass, Called Up by Rangers, Adds Physical Element at Forward
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault found himself with 15 healthy forwards at practice on Thursday — so many that he decided to assemble a fifth line and told them to dress in green jerseys. They stood out from the rest of the group not only because they looked different, but also because — for the moment — they were on the outside looking in.

headline: Well-Built
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I really love a tough Friday puzzle, if only after the fact. It’s like taking one of those “functional fitness” classes at the gym where straps, heavy balls and pushing a weighted sled are involved and you think you’re about to die at the moment the instructor declares “warm-up over!” This grid by Jacob Stulberg had some of everything like that: super-long entries, hardly any breaks in difficulty and even a clever little theme cluster that I didn’t get until the puzzle helpfully explained it to me in the far southeast corner, at 49D.

headline: Review: Brothers Joined by Fate and Furniture in ‘The Price’
text: Arthur Miller’s “The Price,” from 1968, is a tragedy disguised as a rummage sale. It plucks the slipcovers off the autobiographical material that Miller worked over for so much of his career — what sons owe to fathers, what brothers owe to each other, what the world owes to men of reasonable integrity. Women might owe things, too, but that was rarely Miller’s concern.

headline: Brooklyn NYPD Bribery Scheme Said to Be Even More Widespread
text: A member of a neighborhood watch group in Brooklyn who obtained dozens of handgun permits by bribing officers in the New York Police Department’s gun-licensing division also handed out cash and gifts to other officers assigned across Brooklyn, prosecutors said Thursday.

headline: What Trump’s Budget Could Mean for the Affected Agencies
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s first federal budget proposal calls for spending billions of dollars on the military and border security while imposing deep cuts to government departments that deal with the environment, diplomacy, the arts, science and cities.

headline: Canadians Fear Trump’s Budget Will Devastate Great Lakes
text: The Trump administration’s proposal to eliminate funding for a program that addresses major environmental and health threats in the Great Lakes would have a devastating impact on millions of Canadians, officials and environmental groups said on Thursday.

headline: The People From ‘Government Sachs’
text: During World War II, President Franklin D. Roosevelt selected Sidney J. Weinberg, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, to serve as the assistant director of the War Production Board. Mr. Weinberg was one of the few men on Wall Street to support Roosevelt in the 1932 election, and he went on to advise Presidents Harry S. Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: Joseph Nicolosi, Advocate of Conversion Therapy for Gays, Dies at 70
text: Joseph Nicolosi, a clinical psychologist whose advocacy of conversion therapy to diminish people’s same-sex attraction made him a vocal part of the “ex-gay” movement but marginalized him within the mental-health profession, died on March 8. He was 70.

headline: Merkel’s Playbook for Trump
text: Angela Merkel and Donald Trump couldn't be more different. They disagree on immigration, NATO, the European Union and trade. As they meet for the first time as world leaders, here are the factors that may shape their relationship.

headline: Knicks Continue Tailspin by Falling to Nets for Second Time in Five Days
text: As the Knicks walked off the court at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, slumping their shoulders and giving halfhearted hugs to the conquering Nets, a familiar reality set in. With their 121-110 loss to the Nets, they clinched their fourth straight losing season, and their 13th in the last 16 years.

headline: U.S. Military Denies Reports It Bombed Mosque in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The United States military said that it had carried out an airstrike against a meeting of Qaeda militants on Thursday in Syria and that a number of the extremists had been killed.

headline: Pushed Into the Future When Illness Strikes (in an Unlikely Place)

But somehow I had gotten the mumps. And the mumps had caused a rather obscene amount of swelling in a place other than my cheeks. A place that is essential to fertility.

headline: From Chorus to Lead in ‘Miss Saigon’
text: When "Miss Saigon" first looked to Broadway in 1990, controversy erupted over the fact that a white man was portraying a lead role. Jon Jon Briones, who is Asian, was in the chorus then. Today, he is one of the show's stars.

headline: Tefaf Maastricht, While ‘Softer,’ Still Impresses
text: For 30 years, Tefaf Maastricht in the Netherlands has been the world’s pre-eminent fair for art and antiques. But in recent years, collectors’ tastes have shifted from the old to the new, and Europe has experienced terrorist attacks and political instability. Tefaf’s reputation as a destination event faces challenges, particularly now that the fair, run by a nonprofit foundation, has established smaller  spring and fall editions in New York.

headline: The Seasons Aren’t What They Used to Be
text: SEWANEE, Tenn. — Sexual energies were loosed early this year in Tennessee, then quashed. In February, spring peepers made my ears ring as I walked through wetlands east of Nashville’s honky-tonks. These frogs were a month ahead of their normal schedule.

headline: Conservative Fantasies, Colliding With Reality
text: This week the Trump administration put out a budget blueprint — or more accurately, a “budget” blueprint. After all, real budgets detail where the money comes from and where it goes; this proclamation covers only around a third of federal spending, while saying nothing about revenues or projected deficits.

headline: Let Bannon Be Bannon!
text: I continue to worry about Steve Bannon. I see him in the White House photos, but he never has that sprightly Prince of Darkness gleam in his eye anymore.

headline: Even on Their Special Day, Irish Immigrants in America Have Reason to Fear
text: On this St. Patrick’s Day, the closest thing America has to a national holiday of immigration, unless you count Thanksgiving, feast of the undocumented Pilgrim, let us pause to honor the immigrants everybody loves.

headline: When the Irish Invaded Canada
text: We let these people into our country, and what did we get but an epidemic of cholera and criminals. They filled the jails and mental hospitals, the orphanages and poor houses. More than half of those arrested in New York City, just before the Civil War, were Irish.

headline: Trumpcare’s Lonely, and Seedy, Supporter
text: The Republican health bill doesn’t have many outside supporters. Groups representing doctors, nurses, hospitals, retirees, patients of various diseases and even insurers have all criticized it. Some of the only outside praise has come from the chief executive of Anthem, the country’s second largest insurer.

headline: Which Photograph Stays In Your Memory?
text: Of the millions of photographs or images you have viewed in your lifetime, are there any that stand out? Is there just one that pops into your mind? Why?

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Thinks Trump Should Watch ‘Sesame Street’
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: How to Get on an Arena’s Kiss Cam
text: Dress in the home team’s gear. “We want to feature fans who are wearing team apparel, who are in Kings’ jerseys and hats, that’s first and foremost,” says Brooklyn Boyars, the senior director of game presentation and events for the Los Angeles hockey team. (The Kings tend not to put fans rooting for the opponent on their video screen, she adds, “but if we do, we might poke fun at them.”) Or decorate yourself conspicuously in over-the-top costumes, hair or face paint. “We have a gentleman who wears a full European-type cape and crown, and he carries a goblet,” Boyars says. “It has absolutely nothing to do with the Kings, but that’s why we like it.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Limited-Edition ‘Peanuts’ Monopoly Set
text: Jamie writes: My friend Lori, a big fan of Snoopy, bought a limited-edition Peanuts Monopoly set for $10 at an estate sale. She looked up the price online, discovered it sells for $99 and now wants to resell it. I want her to enjoy it as she’d planned. Please order her to play Monopoly with me.

headline: We’ll Go No More a Roving
text: This poem takes its title from a poem by Lord George Byron, the most notorious of the 19th-century English Romantic poets. Byron wrote his poem — at age 29 — to lament his weariness and loss of energy for youthful misbehavior. McCrae’s poem adapts the poem’s basic structure to explore a different sort of weariness: His seems to be a song of postelection despair, an exhausted giving up on the possibility of ever escaping the legacy of slavery.

headline: The 3.5.17 Issue

headline: The Battle of ‘Miss Saigon’: Yellowface, Art and Opportunity
text: “Miss Saigon” started with an audacious idea — create a musical that explores the end of the Vietnam War through an ill-fated romance between a virginal Vietnamese bargirl and a hunky American G.I.

headline: Norman Podhoretz Still Picks Fights and Drops Names
text: “These parties I mentioned,” Norman Podhoretz said the other day, “everybody gave parties. And there was a lot of drinking. Some visiting literary celebrity would show up, Partisan Review would make a party or I would make a party. Everybody came. And it was a really passionate intellectual life. It’s hard to imagine today, but people actually came to blows over literary disagreements.”

headline: Stories
text: THE DARK AND OTHER LOVE STORIESBy Deborah Willis254 pp. Norton, $24.95.

headline: Putting a Faithful Friend to the Test
text: I moved to Qatar a few years ago, after being invited to study at one of the schools there. Born and raised in Pakistan, I was excited for the experience of living in Doha, although there were a few things I was concerned about. For one, the heat: In August, when I was to arrive, the sun scorches the earth with temperatures well above 100 degrees. I had also heard that in Qatar, my faith might cause problems.

headline: Snoop Dogg, Bow Wow and an Ill-Advised Retweet
text: Amid the thousands of tweets that fly from the keyboards of journalists every day, occasionally comes one that sets off an alarm: “Whoops. Should I have said that?” Wednesday afternoon, that bell should have sounded shortly after a New York Times culture writer, Sopan Deb, reacted to a vulgar tweet by the rapper Bow Wow with a comment Deb now wishes he hadn’t made.

headline: Trump and Ryan: Health Bill May Test Marriage of Convenience
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump, once the master pitchman for namesake vodka, steaks and now-moldering casinos, seems disinclined to attach his surname to the health care bill some allies have derided as “Ryancare.”

headline: Friday Mailbag: Where Are the Women?
text: This week letters to our inbox came in at a leisurely clip. Perhaps our East Coast readers were busy shoveling their driveways and sidewalks — not that we’re complaining. But it left this week’s mailbag short and sweet. If you missed them, the public editor’s column addressed two issues this week.

headline: Navigating Our Shameful, Maddeningly Complex Student Aid System
text: This month, the federal government switched off a tool that student financial aid applicants used to import their tax data into forms, adding laborious steps to a process that the tool was supposed to simplify. The possibility of identity theft was the stated reason, big enough to shut down the tool in the middle of the busy season for people seeking aid.

headline: How to Pick the Right New York City Suburb
text: Alison and Scott Simon saw many benefits to living in Manhattan. There was the diversity they loved, the easy commute, along with great bars, restaurants and cultural sites within walking distance or a subway ride.

headline: With Their Leaders at a Loss, Marine Veterans Fight Abusers
text: As a Marine infantry sergeant, James LaPorta once led an intelligence team in Afghanistan. Now, as a private citizen, he is doggedly tracking the moves of an online group that has been secretly compiling and sharing nude photos of hundreds of women in the Marine Corps.

headline: Why Are Basketball Games So Squeaky? Consider the Spiny Lobster
text: It is the unofficial soundtrack of basketball, a noise consistently heard but rarely considered — rubber-soled shoes squeaking on the hardwood.

headline: Burrowing Under Luminous Ice to Retrieve Mussels
text: KANGIQSUJUAQ, Quebec — For eight months a year, the flat bay around the village of Kangiqsujuaq in far northern Quebec freezes beneath a white expanse of ice and snow, leaving ravens and foxes as rare signs of life, along with Inuit and their dogs. Throughout the winter the Inuit hunt seal and caribou, and they fish through the ice for arctic char.

headline: A Harvest Underneath the Ice
text: For one hour, as the tide goes out, ice caves in northern Quebec yawn open with an abundance of mussels. Travel under the ice in 360 with the Inuit who harvest the mussels before the tide floods back in.

headline: Teaching With: ‘Kim Suozzi’s Last Wishes’
text: Cancer claimed Kim Suozzi at age 23, but she chose to have her brain preserved with the dream that neuroscience might one day revive her mind. This film, and Kim’s quest, raise important questions about the inevitability of death, the value of hope and the possibilities of science.

headline: Donald Trump, N.C.A.A. Basketball, St. Patrick’s Day: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Tai Chi Encourages Calm. So Why Are Its Chinese Fans Stressing Out?
text: BEIJING — Last year, Indian yoga made Unesco’s list. In 2011, South Korea’s taekkyeon became the first martial art so honored.

headline: Not My Mother’s Yoga
text: My mother used to chant in Sanskrit in her study before sunrise every morning. Though she died when I was 16 — 22 years ago — I always hear her voice that way. Off-key, but strangely hypnotic, the language both complicated and pure, reverberating around our house.

headline: In Vietnam, a Doyenne of Food Expands to Tasteful Lodging
text: Doubles from $120.

headline: where have classical music’s uppercase letters gone?
text: Composers of what is known, for better or worse, as classical music have broken over time with sonata form, tonality, serialism and minimalism. And in recent decades, quite a few have also broken with the shift keys on their keyboards.

headline: A Restaurant That Brings the Italian Coast to Miami Beach
text: Forte dei Marmi is a tale of three seaside resort towns. You have Miami Beach, home to this pale, airy and nicely tailored restaurant that opened in late 2016. Then there is its name, which comes from a popular Tuscan beach town. Finally, there is Nerano, down on the Amalfi Coast, where the chef, Antonio Mellino, has had a restaurant since 1983. It all adds up to food kissed by a sea breeze, always a good idea in a sun-drenched location.

text: She is a Russian-born mezzo-soprano.

headline: Graham, Taylor, Cunningham: Three Titans. One Stage. One Night.
text: The modern dance tree has many branches, but three of its sturdiest belong to the groundbreaking choreographers Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor. Their influence — on stages, in studios and in schools — is just as crucial as ever. Squabbles aside — and, yes, they’ve had a few — Graham, Cunningham and Mr. Taylor are tied by choreographic blood.

headline: What if Sociologists Had as Much Influence as Economists?
text: Walk half a city block in downtown Washington, and there is a good chance that you will pass an economist. People with advanced training in the field shape policy on subjects as varied as how health care is provided, broadcast licenses auctioned or air pollution regulated.

headline: The Life of Her London Parties, Now Out to Save Them All
text: LONDON — In the 25 years since she moved to London from her native New Jersey, Amy Lamé has staged a late-night manifesto on protected sex in one of the city’s most notorious gay cruising zones, and created and hosted a sex and sexuality-themed TV game show. She has also emceed a cabaret night whose guests have included a flame dancer, a hula hoop artist and a stripping dwarf.

headline: A Woman in Charge: A Biography of Liberia’s President

headline: Rex Tillerson Rejects Talks With North Korea on Nuclear Program
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson ruled out on Friday opening any negotiation with North Korea to freeze its nuclear and missile programs and said for the first time that the Trump administration might be forced to take pre-emptive action “if they elevate the threat of their weapons program” to an unacceptable level.

headline: 13 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
text: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, we’re also tooting our own horn here. We’ll share can’t-miss Times articles from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

headline: Japanese Government and Utility Are Found Negligent in Nuclear Disaster
text: TOKYO — The Japanese government and the electric utility that operated the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant were negligent in not preventing the meltdowns in 2011 that forced thousands of people to flee the area, a district court in eastern Japan ruled on Friday.

headline: Debunking a Myth: The Irish Were Not Slaves, Too
text: It has shown up on Irish trivia Facebook pages, in Scientific American magazine, and on white nationalist message boards: the little-known story of the Irish slaves who built America, who are sometimes said to have outnumbered and been treated worse than slaves from Africa.

headline: Airstrike Kills Dozens of Somali Migrants Off Yemen’s Coast
text: SANA, Yemen — More than 30 Somali migrants, including children, were killed in the Red Sea on Friday when a military helicopter opened fire on their boat, according to Yemeni and United Nations officials.

headline: How Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee, Cancer Expert, Spends His Sundays
text: Working as a cancer physician, researcher and assistant professor at Columbia University doesn’t seem to be enough action for Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee. He is also a renowned science writer, having won the Pulitzer Prize in 2011 for “The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer.” His latest book, “The Gene: An Intimate History,” will be released in paperback in May. Dr. Mukherjee, 46, lives in the Flatiron district, with his wife, Sarah Sze, 48, a sculptor; their two daughters, Leela, 11, and Aria, 7; and their Papillon, Ginger.

headline: Home Sales Brisk in New York City’s Suburbs
text: Real estate market temperatures in the commuter suburbs around New York City range from warm to sizzling, having never really cooled down for the winter.

headline: Cholesterol-Slashing Drug Can Protect High-Risk Heart Patients, Study Finds
text: The first rigorous test of an expensive new drug that radically lowers cholesterol levels found that it significantly reduced the chance that a high-risk patient would have a heart attack or stroke. These were men and women who had exhausted all other options.

headline: George Osborne, Ex-Finance Chief of U.K., to Become Editor of Evening Standard
text: LONDON — Britain is no stranger to its leading figures moving between journalism and politics. Now, George Osborne, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, is set to be prominent in both spheres at once.

headline: Taraji P. Henson: Talking Cookie, and the Impact of ‘Hidden Figures’
text: If you love Taraji P. Henson as the music executive Cookie Lyon in the Fox drama “Empire” or as the mathematician Katherine Johnson in the Oscar-nominated film “Hidden Figures,” savor those performances, because you likely won’t see anything like them again.

headline: Trump Offers No Apology for Claim on British Spying
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump provoked a rare public dispute with America’s closest ally on Friday after his White House aired an explosive and unsubstantiated claim that Britain’s spy agency had secretly eavesdropped on him at the behest of President Barack Obama during last year’s campaign.

headline: Want to Make Budget Cuts? Start Here
text: The Trump administration on Thursday provided an outline of its first budget, a proposal that will dramatically reshape how the United States spends money on national security and defense. There is no question that the United States’ security spending patterns need to be rebalanced to better address urgent security challenges. The Trump budget will not do that.

headline: What My Red State Sees in Me
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — I saw my first loose gun in 2014 here in Austin. I was headed to lunch with a friend at a homey Mexican place near the University of Texas campus, where I was a graduate student. As we pulled into a parking spot on the side of the road, I noticed a white man — tall, with dirty yellow hair and crumpled white clothes — on the sidewalk. Seconds later, he had pulled out a pistol and was waving it at someone outside the restaurant. My friend ducked. I backed out, spun the car around, and drove off.

headline: Turkey’s Quarrel With Europe
text: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has escalated a war of words with Germany and the Netherlands.

headline: What Is This ‘Iron Fist’ Controversy? (Also, What Is ‘Iron Fist’?)
text: With a racially-tinged controversy and terrible early reviews, few Netflix projects have had as bumpy a rollout as the new Marvel series “Iron Fist.” The fourth Marvel-Netflix collaboration, after “Daredevil,” “Jessica Jones” and “Luke Cage,” “Iron Fist” introduces the final character in the coming Avengers-style superhero crossover series, “The Defenders.” All 13 episodes of “Iron Fist” arrive on Netflix on March 17, so before deciding whether or not to watch, familiarize yourself with the character, the controversy and what people are saying about the series.

headline: Everyday Design Objects Get a Sleek Upgrade
text: An unexpected finish or material transforms the utilitarian into something exceptional.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Irvine Welsh

The next in the series is Irvine Welsh, the author of the book “Trainspotting,” which became a film in 1996. “T2 Trainspotting,” the sequel, opens in theaters today.

headline: An Unorthodox Gift to Notre Dame from Muslim Philanthropists
text: Rafat and Zoreen Ansari, medical doctors who were born in Pakistan, have spent the last four decades working and raising their three children in a suburb of South Bend, Ind., where they also have earned a reputation as civic leaders.

text: The Ghanaian-British architect, who will be knighted by Queen Elizabeth II this year and whose current projects include the new Studio Museum in Harlem, sketched his answers with a Paper Mate Flair felt-tip pen.

text: When the architect and designer Fabrizio Casiraghi was in school, he studied urban planning. It turns out this comes in handy for projects that are worlds in and of themselves.

headline: 135 Years Ago, Another Travel Ban Was In the News
text: “And as for the assertion that we have no moral right to say who shall and who shall not come into the country, no true American will for one moment admit a doctrine so dangerous, or make a confession so weak.”

headline: Derek Walcott, Poet and Nobel Laureate of the Caribbean, Dies at 87
text: Derek Walcott, whose intricately metaphorical poetry captured the physical beauty of the Caribbean, the harsh legacy of colonialism and the complexities of living and writing in two cultural worlds, bringing him a Nobel Prize in Literature, died early Friday morning at his home near Gros Islet in St. Lucia. He was 87.

headline: Real Madrid Draws Bayern Munich in Champions League Quarterfinal
text: The defending champions Real Madrid will play Bayern Munich in the quarterfinals of this season’s Champions League, as Friday’s draw pitted two of the competition’s favorites against each other.

headline: New York Has 77 Police Precincts. Why Do Their Numbers Go Higher?
text: Q. There are 77 police precincts in New York City. How then can there be precincts with numbers 109 (Flushing) and higher? Why don’t the precinct numbers end with 77?

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE MOST WANTED MAN IN CHINA: My Journey From Scientist To Enemy Of The State, by Fang Lizhi. Translated by Perry Link. (St. Martin’s Griffin/Holt, $17.99.) Before his death in 2012, Fang was one of China’s most noted scientists and an outspoken critic of the Communist government. His memoir, detailing the regime’s absurdities and hypocrisies, was written during 13 months spent at the American Embassy after the Tiananmen massacre.

headline: What Are the Best Snacks Before Bedtime?
text: Q. I know it’s not good to eat close to bedtime, but I get hungry. What are the least harmful things I can eat — or drink — say, an hour or two before going to bed?

headline: Want a Feminist Daughter, Dad? Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie Has Advice for You, Too
text: Father, Heal Thyself: The Nigerian novelist and feminist thinker Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie has a new book on the hardcover nonfiction list — “Dear Ijeawele: Or, A Feminist Manifesto in 15 Suggestions” debuts at No. 4. The book began as a letter to a childhood friend, who wondered how she might raise an empowered daughter. Adichie’s customarily direct advice was, more or less, to overthrow the system: “Teach her that the idea of ‘gender roles’ is absolute nonsense,” she writes. “Do not ever tell her that she should or should not do something because she is a girl. ‘Because you are a girl’ is never a reason for anything. Ever.”

headline: 1892: Strained Relations Between England and Turkey
text: CAIRO — The presence at Alexandria since yesterday of nine English ironclads with 3,400 men on board, while the Turkish ship carrying the Sultan’s envoy has neither arrived nor is officially signaled, has called forth some comment in the political world, and has revealed the somewhat strained relations between England and Turkey.

headline: Hand Me the AUX Cord
text: Q. I just bought a Chevy Bolt. It has no CD player. I have a music history course on 48 CDs, and other courses on CDs. I am only going to listen to these once, so I don’t want to have to transfer the audio to a USB device. Is there a CD player that I can hook up to a Bolt’s audio system?

headline: What Do Trump’s Tax Forms Mean to You?
text: The revelation this week of pages from President Trump’s 2005 tax forms provided a glimpse at documents that he has refused to disclose, breaking with decades of tradition. The disclosure elicited some strong responses from taxpayers across the country as the April 15 filing deadline approaches. The New York Times spoke with a few people from either side of the partisan divide. Here are excerpts.

headline: Syria Fires Missiles at Israeli Warplanes
text: JERUSALEM — The Syrian armed forces fired antiaircraft missiles at Israeli warplanes that had struck targets deep in Syria early Friday, in what appeared to be the most serious clash between the two militaries since the start of the Syrian civil war six years ago.

headline: Ways to Save (and Not Spend) Your Tax Refund
text: More than 70 percent of taxpayers are expected to get refunds this year, the Internal Revenue Service reports. That represents a big opportunity, according to savings advocates and financial advisers, since many Americans struggle to set aside cash for emergencies.

headline: How Much Is Your House Worth Per Minute?
text: Suburban home buyers can get a lot more house for the money compared with city dwellers. Sales prices tell us how much money people spend for their space, and train schedules tell us how much time. Together they give us a sense of what a suburban home is worth in a cost-per-minute figure.

text: When Creighton lost its star point guard, Maurice Watson Jr., to a season-ending knee injury in January, its season almost went down with him.

headline: Dave Chappelle on Trump, Cosby and His Netflix Deal
text: Whether lambasting racial inequity with his trademark eccentricity, or putting on a Jheri curl wig for a now-legendary parody of Rick James, Dave Chappelle has long been considered one of the most exciting stand-ups in comedy. But he hasn’t issued a special or album since his infamous decision to walk away from the critically acclaimed “Chappelle’s Show” on Comedy Central — and a $50 million contract — in 2005.

headline: A New Film Series Will Show Movies From Countries Affected by the Travel Ban
text: In a protest against Islamophobia, a new film series, to be shown across the country in May, is to feature movies from countries affected by President Trump’s latest travel ban, which has been blocked by the courts.

headline: 350 Square Feet, Two Kids, Two Cats and a Rabbit
text: Maligned though New York’s rental market may be, a fortunate few do manage to stumble onto the ideal apartment early and easily. Such was the case with Sacha Moore, who scored a charming one-bedroom with a working fireplace in Brooklyn Heights (with the help of her sister) when she and her husband moved back to the city from New Orleans in 2003.

headline: Iranian Pilgrims Can Participate in Hajj This Year, Saudi Arabia Says
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia said on Friday that Iranians would be able to participate in this year’s hajj pilgrimage to the holy cities of Mecca and Medina, a rare bright spot in relations between the two regional rivals.

headline: For Refugee Agencies, a Court Stay Only Adds to the Confusion
text: Last month, in anticipation of the Trump administration shutting down the flow of refugees entering the United States, Church World Service, one of the groups that handles resettlement, took drastic measures. It laid off all but 40 of the 600 employees at its African center that prepared refugees for travel.

headline: Bombing Foiled After Lull in Bangladesh Attacks Ends
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The police in Bangladesh said they foiled an apparent bombing attempt at a checkpoint of Bangladesh’s elite police force on Saturday, less than a day after an attempted suicide attack outside another police facility.

headline: Going From Marginalized to Welcomed in the Workplace
text: When Michaela Mendelsohn, the owner and chief executive of the Pollo West Corporation, arrived at her restaurant company’s holiday party in 2006, it had been a year since she had seen most of her 500 employees. In that time, she had worked from her home in the Conejo Valley of Southern California and was in contact with only a handful of staff members.

headline: Penn State Hockey, Still New to Division I, Chases First Tournament Berth
text: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. — Five years ago, the only hockey team on campus here was the Penn State Icers, a perennial club hockey power in the top division of the American Collegiate Hockey Association. They competed against the likes of Ohio University, Lindenwood and Delaware.

headline: Left-Leaning Documentary World Seeks Right-Wing Perspective
text: Three of the 10 top-grossing political documentaries ever are the work of the right-wing polemicist Dinesh D’Souza. The most powerful documentarian in the country is the White House adviser Stephen K. Bannon. Still, the rap on documentaries is that they preach to a left-leaning choir, one still trying to figure out how Donald J. Trump became president.

headline: For Former Hockey Champions Michigan and Michigan State, Unaccustomed Struggles
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — In college hockey, Michigan and Michigan State are storied programs with much in common.

headline: When the Boss Is Half Your Age
text: Christine Sabo had three decades of fund-raising experience behind her when, three years ago, she was hired as the vice president for major giving at a nonprofit in South Florida. But right about the time Ms. Sabo came aboard, the chief executive had accepted a new position elsewhere.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
text: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there’s much more where these came from.

headline: British Police Net a Butterfly Killer, and Now He May Face Jail
text: LONDON — The killer, a former body builder, stalked his frail victims at nature reserves, in one case clambering over a locked gate armed with a net, before he chased them down, trapped them and carried them away, dead or alive.

headline: On Banning Leaf Blowers
text: New Yorkers who leave the city for the suburbs often do so for three reasons: schools, space and silence. The silence, it turns out, can be a problem.

headline: Basque Separatist Group ETA Is Said to Promise to Disarm
text: ETA, the Basque separatist group, is expected to turn over its remaining weapons next month, the Basque regional leader and a Basque activist said Friday, a development that brought a cautious response by the Spanish government as the organization has not followed through on similar pledges in the past.

headline: Things Go Awry at ‘Desert X,’ as Shy Bot Disappears
text: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — The shy bot has stopped communicating: Last month this small robotic vehicle, designed to avoid people as well as plants and rocks, started its off-road journey as part of the sprawling art exhibition known as “Desert X.” Now it is missing, and its data stream is dead.

headline: 5 Numbers That Say a Lot About the Election
text: Turnout in the 2016 presidential election, initially characterized as low, actually exceeded that of the 2012 race in which President Barack Obama won re-election. The candidates devoted virtually all their time and money to 14 battleground states, regarding the vote in the rest of the country as a foregone conclusion. Elections to the House of Representatives were the least competitive since political junkies began rating them in 1984. And unsurprisingly, states that made it easier to register and vote usually experienced significantly higher turnout than states that did not.

headline: UConn Women Enter Tourney With 107 Consecutive Wins, But ...
text: STORRS, Conn. — As the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament opens on Friday, Connecticut is again unbeaten. But for once the Huskies do not appear unbeatable.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, the opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal talks about the news — the good, the bad and the most maddening.

headline: ‘You Are the Future of Europe,’ Erdogan Tells Turks

headline: Frederic Nathan, New York City Legal Officer, Dies at 94
text: Frederic Solis Nathan, the New York City legal officer whose prosecution of the striking teachers’ union in the late 1960s helped transform its pugnacious president, Albert Shanker, into a national figure by sending him to jail for a month, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: Hudson Yards, Meet Your New Neighbor, Manhattan West
text: It is built partly over West Side train tracks. It will have apartments, offices and stores. But it is not Hudson Yards, a high-profile neighboring mega-project taking shape along 10th Avenue.

headline: Behind Lucky Peach’s Closing, Colliding Visions
text: When it first appeared in 2011, Lucky Peach was something new: an irreverent food magazine that broke down barriers between journalists and cooks. Founded by two veteran writers, Peter Meehan and Chris Ying, and a successful chef, David Chang, it ran articles and recipes from creative minds all over the culinary landscape and beyond.

headline: When Decorating Styles Clash
text: Whether you’re taking on a roommate or moving into a new place with your significant other, combining different styles can be challenging — especially when the people involved have strong opinions. But some of the most interesting spaces, designers say, integrate a variety of influences. Here are some suggestions for creating an environment that’s cohesive, not clashing, and preserving your relationship along the way.

headline: Watch U.S. Nuclear Tests
text: Thousands of films showing U.S. atmospheric nuclear tests between 1945 and 1962 have been declassified. Scientists are studying them and posting them for all to see.

headline: U.S. Nuclear Weapons Tests Come to YouTube
text: The cameras shudder as blinding light flashes across the earth. Deformed white clouds balloon and mutate from the force of the nuclear test explosions.

headline: (Early) Spring Reading
text: Here in New York City, we had several days of baseball-appropriate weather in February. The famous cherry blossoms in Washington, D.C., are due to peak as early as they ever have. Spring — and spring books — are here.

headline: FilmStruck and Warner Archive Instant Are Classic-Movie Troves
text: “Two great tastes that taste great together” was how Reese’s once extolled the virtues of its famous peanut butter cups. A similar notion endures when considering the streaming services FilmStruck and Warner Archive. If you are a fanatical lover of classic movies and are moving away from physical media, both sites offer cinematic stimulants and comforts in often complementary ways.

headline: So Many Pharaohs: A Possible Case of Mistaken Identity in Cairo
text: CAIRO — The Pharaonic statue that was discovered in a Cairo slum last week, believed to depict Ramses II, one of ancient Egypt’s best-known rulers, most likely is of a lesser-known pharaoh, the Egyptian authorities said Thursday.

headline: States Could Make Work a Medicaid Requirement Under G.O.P. Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump and conservative lawmakers in the House agreed Friday to significant changes to Medicaid that could impose work requirements on able-bodied Medicaid beneficiaries in some states and limit federal funds for the program, as Republican leaders tried to rally balking lawmakers behind legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Fairfield, Conn., and Old Westbury, N.Y.

text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Review: A Scalding Take on Race in ‘White Guy on the Bus’
text: For 20 minutes or so after settling into your seat at the 59E59 Theaters to see “White Guy on the Bus,” you may have the uncomfortable feeling that your ticket has bought you an annoying lecture about race by, well, a white guy and his family.

headline: Greg Bird Draws Attention and Praise, Hit After Hit
text: TAMPA — A new Twitter account recently popped up under the name of Greg Bird, who someday soon enough may become a Yankees slugger. It looked legitimate enough, with mostly innocuous comments and the occasional plea for more followers. But there was one important clue exposing its deceit.

headline: A Tweet to Kurt Eichenwald, a Strobe and a Seizure. Now, an Arrest.
text: WASHINGTON — When the journalist Kurt Eichenwald opened an animated image sent to him on Twitter in December, the message “You deserve a seizure for your posts” appeared in capital letters along with a blinding strobe light. Mr. Eichenwald, who has epilepsy, immediately suffered a seizure.

headline: Chance the Rapper Says His Apple Music Deal Was Worth $500,000
text: In a rare public disclosure of closed-door music industry dealings with one of the biggest companies in the world, Chance the Rapper said on Friday that he was paid half a million dollars by Apple to host his digital mixtape, “Coloring Book,” exclusively on its streaming service for two weeks last year.

headline: Review: In ‘Spider Network,’ an Intriguing Tale of Complicity
text: Mention Libor — an acronym for the London interbank offered rate — and even bankers’ eyes are likely to glaze over.

headline: Superflex Is Chosen for Tate Modern Turbine Hall
text: LONDON — The Danish art collective Superflex, known for its politically charged work, will take on the 2017 commission for the cavernous Tate Modern’s Turbine Hall, the museum announced on Thursday. The Hyundai commission, as it has been known since 2014, is an annual site-specific installation in the 85-foot-high entrance to the Tate Modern that draws high numbers of visitors.

headline: Tesla’s $1 Billion Cash Raise May Fall Short
text: Tesla’s capital raise is dangerously underpowered. The electric-car company run by Elon Musk will sell stock and notes worth a bit over $1 billion. Tesla is burning cash, and investing heavily to gear up for production of its coming Model 3. Unexpectedly small dilution pleases investors, but may miss the more important goal of capital sufficiency.

headline: Review: Robert Lepage Goes Home Again in ‘887’
text: A shabby apartment building becomes a cabinet of wonders in Ex Machina’s glittering “887” at the BAM Harvey Theater. A solo show made more populous by dolls, toy cars and hand shadows, it is Robert Lepage’s fragmented recollection of his childhood in 1960s Quebec City.

headline: Animals in Extra Large
text: Q. Why were prehistoric animals so big? Or is the real question why are their descendants so much smaller?

headline: Canada Today: Back Home, a Hidden Harvest and Water Worries
text: Each week, Canada Today mixes the Times’s recent Canada-related coverage with back stories and analysis from our reporters along with opinions from our readers.

headline: Trump’s Budget Expands the G.O.P.’s War on Math
text: Spending cuts alone do not a fiscal conservative make. Remember that as President Trump claims to be one, bigly, based on the deep cuts he’s proposed in just about everything the government does other than defending the nation and distributing Social Security and Medicare checks.

headline: Ignore the Snobs, Drink the Cheap, Delicious Wine
text: So-called natural wines have recently supplanted kale as the “it” staple of trendy tables — the “latest in holier-than-thou drinking,” according to The Financial Times. Farmed organically and made with minimal intervention, the wine in these special bottles is not to be confused with what one natural wine festival called “industrialized, big-brand, manufactured, nothing-but-alcoholic-grape-juice wines.” In other words, what most of us drink.

headline: Proposed Cuts in the Trump Budget
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Do Bridge Pose
text: This is a back-bending pose that stretches the muscles of the chest, back and neck. It also builds strength in the back and hamstring muscles.

headline: Oklahoma State Senator Faces Charges and Condemnation
text: When Ralph Shortey arrived in the Oklahoma State Senate in 2011, he quickly made a name for himself as a leading Republican voice in a conservative state. He discovered the spotlight with legislation over the years that at times embraced the fringe.

headline: A Pyeongchang Preview
text: Pyeongchang will host Korea’s first Winter Olympics in February. The New York Times photographer Chang W. Lee, who left South Korea 30 years ago, returned last month to visit the region where the 2018 Games will be held. The trip brought back memories of the seven Olympics he has covered for The Times — which gave him a front-row seat for the struggles, the beauty, the smiles and the tears that make the Olympics one of his favorite events. But the trip also brought a sense of anticipation, a sense that a new set of magic moments, a new wave of drama, was on its way again, and this time in Korea, his home.

headline: Ex-VW Chief Looks to Sell $1.2 Billion Stake, Creating Uncertainty
text: BADEN BADEN, Germany — Ferdinand Piëch, the scion of an automaking dynasty who dominated Volkswagen for two decades, is trying to sell his substantial indirect stake in the company to members of his extended family, which could create uncertainty in the aftermath of the carmaker’s diesel deception.

headline: The Cost Can Be Debated, but Meals on Wheels Gets Results
text: Meals on Wheels has been delivering food to older people in the United States since the 1950s. Last year it served 2.4 million people. This week, after President Trump released his budget proposal, a furor erupted over the program’s future and effectiveness. Let’s look at the evidence.

headline: Third Time’s the Charm: Bass Museum Sets October Opening
text: MIAMI BEACH — The third time’s the charm. Following two postponements caused by construction delays, Miami Beach’s city-owned Bass art museum has announced its October 2017 reopening following a $12 million renovation project.

headline: Gender-Bending Debate Play ‘Her Opponent’ to Open Off Broadway
text: As President Trump begins his third month in office, one production hopes to bring Americans back to the 2016 presidential debates and ask: How did we get here?

headline: At 22, Mikaela Shiffrin Flies to Skiing’s Pinnacle. And Aims to Move It Higher
text: ASPEN, Colo. — “Is my career ahead of schedule?” Mikaela Shiffrin, the precocious Olympic and world ski racing champion, asked here on Monday, her 22nd birthday. “No, I don’t think I’ll ever believe I’m ahead of schedule.”

headline: George Braziller, Publisher of Fresh Literary Voices, Dies at 101
text: George Braziller, whose small, independent publishing house introduced Americans to groundbreaking novelists, poets and new voices from abroad, including those of Jean-Paul Sartre and Orhan Pamuk, and the works of 20th-century and classical artists in fine reprints, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 101.

headline: The Billboard Charts Are Wackier Than Ever: What’s Going On?
text: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: My New Favorite Beans
text: I always keep a large supply of dried beans in the pantry. (There are a few tins of canned beans, too, but only for emergency use.)

headline: The Difference Between the Nets and the Knicks? The Nets Have a Plan
text: As he approached the birth of his N.B.A. head coaching career last fall, Kenny Atkinson considered calling Brett Brown, the Philadelphia 76ers’ coach and an expert on the burden of losing and losing to the point where your winning percentage resembles the batting average of a journeyman infielder known for his glove.

headline: In Netflix Specials, Dave Chappelle Challenges His Audience
text: It was probably inevitable that Dave Chappelle would do the most provocative comedy on Bill Cosby.

headline: Trump the Builder? Budget Blueprint Puts His Promises on Infrastructure in Doubt
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s budget was billed as a blueprint for acting on campaign pledges, but neglected in his cascade of spending cuts to federal agencies and largess for the military and border protection was one of his biggest promises: investing in infrastructure.

headline: From Michael Bloomberg: Fighting Climate Change Despite Trump Rollbacks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Venezuela on the Brink
text: Dispatches from a Latin American country in crisis.

headline: These Women’s Magazines Aren’t Just for Women
text: In spring 2013, Joanna Demkiewicz, a journalism student at the University of Missouri, went to hear the longtime Esquire writer Mike Sager talk about his new book, “Next Wave: America’s New Generation of Great Literary Journalists.” The collection, which Mr. Sager had edited, celebrates 19 underappreciated young writers. But there was a problem.

headline: John W. Walsh, Who Fought for Cure for Lung Disease, Dies at 68
text: John W. Walsh, who led a national campaign for a cure for a form of lung disease that killed his mother and afflicted his sister, his twin brother and himself, died on March 7 in Miami. He was 68.

headline: Review: Spruce and Taut, the Met Opera’s ‘Fidelio’ Looks Good at 17
text: How does an opera company keep an ambitious production vibrant and vital when it’s revived? The best way, of course, is to bring back the original director, something Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, has tried over the years. Because these artists are often busy elsewhere, revivals are routinely entrusted to an in-house stage director, who basically recreates the original while taking some liberties and adapting the concept to new casts.

headline: Review: The Desdemona in This ‘Otello’ Spits Fire
text: Verdi’s Desdemona has always seemed to me a pious drip. In my personal pantheon of opera heroines who should have shown more grit before succumbing to their inevitable deaths, I have long reserved special contempt for her. Why is she so meek in the face of her husband Otello’s false accusations, and so quick to accept the honor killing he is clearly bent on?

headline: Cloning Yo-Yo Ma: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Moments
text: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what they’ve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

headline: The Playlist: Feist Ponders ‘Pleasure,’ and Frank Ocean Delivers Another Surprise
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, in the East Village and in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

headline: The Hermès of Marijuana
text: Recreational cannabis may be legal in California, but buying the actual stuff still makes Scott Campbell, a celebrity tattoo artist and fine artist, feel like a class-cutting teenage stoner.

headline: Bluebonnet Season Came Early in Texas This Spring
text: Every year in Texas, millions of bluebonnets bloom after warm weather, just at the cusp of spring. Bumpy blankets of blue spread across pastures, parks and highway shoulders. And because of a series of warm days in February, this year’s show has already begun. It’s expected to peak in the next week or two, so grab your camera and hop in the car — it’s time to get out there and find them.

headline: Karlie Kloss, Ruth Bell and Rebecca Hall Celebrate Dior at Saks Fifth Avenue
text: A cocktail party and dinner to celebrate a new Dior boutique and new collection at Saks.

headline: Fighting Fakes on Alibaba From Arizona
text: Some small American businesses accuse Alibaba.com, China’s largest e-commerce company, of tolerating sales of counterfeits on its platforms. Step inside an industrial furniture workshop in Phoenix to see what’s at stake for the originals.

headline: Karlie Kloss, Ruth Bell and Rebecca Hall Celebrate Dior at Saks Fifth Avenue
text: “It’s definitely a bit weird,” the model Ruth Bell said on Thursday night. She was surveying a new installation on the third floor of Saks Fifth Avenue, where her face was plastered on nearly every surface.

headline: All Eyes on China as U.S. Signals New Tack on North Korea
text: BEIJING — Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson signaled on Friday that the Trump administration was prepared to scrap nearly a decade of United States policy toward North Korea in favor of a more aggressive effort to eliminate the country’s nuclear weapons program. Whether that means pre-emptive action, which he warned was “on the table,” will depend a great deal on how China responds.

headline: An Early Bird Gets Caught in the Snowstorm
text: Say what you will about the could-have-been-worse winter storm on Tuesday: it still made for difficult traveling. Flights were canceled, buses rerouted, subway and train lines shut down.

headline: Seeking Style in the Markets of Abidjan, Ivory Coast
text: “If you want to shoot fashion in New York, you’re probably going to hang out in very trendy spots,” the photographer Émilie Régnier said.

headline: The Trump Resistance Will Be Commercialized
text: Recently I received an email inviting me to attend a private salon held at a Brooklyn restaurant. “Under this new … ahem … ‘administration’ … you gotta stay loud,” the invitation read. “We’ll gather round an ~intimate~ table of fellow disruptors to eat out + speak up.”

headline: Betsy DeVos’s Hiring of For-Profit College Official Raises Impartiality Issues
text: As chief compliance officer for a corporate owner of for-profit colleges, Robert S. Eitel spent the past 18 months as a top lawyer for a company facing multiple government investigations, including one that ended with a settlement of more than $30 million over deceptive student lending.

headline: Ivanka Trump’s Lesson in Canadian Values
text: The Prime Minister of Canada, Justin Trudeau, attended a performance on Wednesday of a new Broadway musical, “Come From Away.” It’s based on the true story of a little town in Newfoundland that suddenly became host to thousands of air travelers stranded by 9/11.

headline: How ‘Consumer Relief’ After Mortgage Crisis Can Enrich Big Banks
text: In every multibillion dollar settlement with a big bank that peddled faulty mortgage securities, a major provision has been a requirement that the bank provide “consumer relief.”

headline: Republicans Start Lining Up to Fight for the N.E.A. and N.E.H.
text: At first blush it’s like a dream come true for conservatives: Donald J. Trump has become the first president to formally propose eliminating federal programs for the arts and humanities, which have long been in the cross hairs of Republicans, and the threat is all the more real because the party also controls Congress.

headline: Tillerson, Trump, ‘Beauty and the Beast’: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mandarin Gets One Shining Moment in a First-Round N.C.A.A. Game
text: INDIANAPOLIS — As if on cue, Yiqing Zhou and Xueyin Shi let out the same response when asked how they will feel about having their commentary heard on national television.

headline: Fact Check: Budget Director’s Claims That Programs Don’t Work
text: WASHINGTON — Facing criticism over proposed spending cuts in arts, education and antipoverty efforts, President Trump’s budget director repeatedly argued Thursday that at-risk programs neither help nor work.

headline: White House Fence Jumper Was on Grounds 17 Minutes Before Detection
text: WASHINGTON — A California man who climbed over the White House fence last week managed to roam undetected on the grounds for about 17 minutes, as Secret Service agents appeared to ignore several alarms, officials said Friday.

headline: Give President Free Rein to Fire Consumer Board Chief, Justice Dept. Argues
text: The Justice Department on Friday took the rare step of opposing another federal agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, in court, arguing that the bureau’s structure is unconstitutional and should be changed.

headline: A Timeline on Trump’s Wiretap Claims
text: A look at the reactions, clarifications and explanations after President Trump, in a series of tweets, accused Barack Obama of tapping his phones last fall.

headline: Dave Stallworth, Bulwark for Knicks’ First N.B.A. Title, Dies at 75
text: Dave Stallworth, an all-American forward at Wichita State before joining the Knicks, was on his way to a fine pro career when he was sidelined by a heart attack near the end of his second N.B.A. season. Doctors doubted he would play again.

headline: Trump Plan Eliminates a Global Sentinel Against Disease, Experts Warn
text: Nobody in the United States has ever died from an intercontinental missile strike. Over the past 50 years, hundreds of billions of dollars have been spent on silos, submarines, bombers and satellites to ensure that does not happen.

headline: ‘The Pages of the Sea’: A Derek Walcott Sampler
text: [ Read Derek Walcott’s obituary ]

headline: C.I.A. Torture Left Scars on Guantánamo Prisoner’s Psyche for Years
text: Nearly a decade after C.I.A. interrogators tortured a Saudi man suspected of involvement in Al Qaeda’s bombing of the American destroyer Cole in 2000, the prisoner continued to experience lingering psychological consequences, including “nightmares that invoked being chained, naked and waterboarded,” newly declassified documents show.

headline: Ex-Gymnastics Chief’s Career: Swift Success Marred by Years of Scandal
text: After nearly two decades working for U.S.A. Gymnastics, including 12 years as its president, Steve Penny resigned on Thursday, smack in the middle of a sexual assault scandal that involves dozens of young gymnasts.

headline: Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri Supreme Court Petition
text: Documents show that the waterboarding and other torture techniques used against a terrorism suspect had long-term consequences, including “nightmares that invoked being chained, naked and waterboarded.”

headline: Questioning Whether de Blasio Will Learn From a Teachable Moment
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio occasionally lectures his staff about what he calls teachable moments — mistakes they or others have made that provide an opportunity for reflection and a change of course.

headline: Jason Pierre-Paul Agrees to Four-Year Contract With Giants
text: The Giants were exceptionally busy Friday, agreeing to contracts with four veteran players, most notably defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul, who received a four-year deal less than two years after a harrowing fireworks accident put his football career in jeopardy.

headline: U.N. Diplomat Behind Report Accusing Israel of Apartheid Quits
text: The top official of a United Nations commission that published a report describing Israel’s treatment of Palestinians as apartheid quit on Friday, saying the organization’s leader insisted that she withdraw it. The report provoked outrage from Israel and the United States.

headline: Nick Kyrgios’s Withdrawal Illustrates the Season’s Uncertainty
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Nick Kyrgios’s withdrawal because of illness before his quarterfinal with Roger Federer on Friday was a major letdown, no doubt.

headline: Fox’s Andrew Napolitano Stirred the Pot for Trump’s British Tempest
text: Andrew Napolitano was a Superior Court judge in New Jersey until, frustrated by the constraints of his salary, he left the bench for more lucrative pastures: talk radio, a syndicated small-claims court TV series (“Power of Attorney”) and, eventually, Fox News, where he rose to become the network’s senior legal analyst.

headline: Brazil’s Largest Food Companies Raided in Tainted Meat Scandal
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Federal agents raided the operations of Brazil’s largest food companies on Friday over accusations that their employees oversaw a scheme that included bribing inspectors to allow rotten meals to be served in public schools and salmonella-contaminated meat to be exported to Europe.

headline: One Billion Yahoo Accounts Still for Sale, Despite Hacking Indictments
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For sale: one billion Yahoo accounts, $200,000 or best offer. The passwords don’t work, but the dates of birth, telephone numbers and security questions could still be useful to an adept cyberthief.

headline: Trump Stays Buggy
text: Whatever Donald Trump has, it’s spreading.

headline: N.C.A.A. Leader Mark Emmert Says Discrimination Policy Is Clear
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The N.C.A.A. president, Mark Emmert, said Friday that the organization was standing behind the firm position it has staked out on anti-discrimination protections for athletes and fans, a decision that led it to bar North Carolina from hosting N.C.A.A. championship events like this week’s men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Quotation of the Day: States Could Make Work a Medicaid Requirement Under G.O.P. Deal
text: “If I hear one more senator tell me that this bill is dead on arrival, I think my head is going to explode.”

headline: Trump Budget Cuts Put Struggling Americans on Edge
text: Regina Feltner, a retired nurse, was recovering from side effects of radiation therapy when she got the notice that her heat would be cut off. It was a bone-cold January day. The snow was so high that her daughter had to come over to take the dog out.

headline: Merkel Meets Trump, the Defender Versus the Disrupter
text: WASHINGTON — Near the end of his meticulously formal, utterly impersonal news conference with Chancellor Angela Merkel, President Trump finally sought a sliver of common ground with his guest: They both, he said, had been wiretapped by former President Barack Obama.

headline: For Some Basketball Coaches, Ties That Bind Are Better Off Left in the Closet
text: BUFFALO — Mike Brey and Bob Huggins do not have much in common. During Brey’s long tenure at Notre Dame, which began in 2000, Huggins has coached three programs, including, since 2007, West Virginia. Brey runs an elegant motion offense of cutting and passing, while Huggins installed an aggressive full-court defense that earned the Mountaineers the nickname Press Virginia. Brey, a smooth-talking smiler, rarely loses his cool during games. Huggins, uh, does.

headline: Pentagon Releases Photo to Rebut Contention It Bombed a Mosque
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon released an aerial photo on Friday of a pulverized building in Syria in an unusual defense of an American airstrike that officials said killed dozens of Al Qaeda operatives at a meeting place — and not civilians at a mosque, as activists and local residents maintain.

headline: What to Ask About Russian Hacking
text: On Monday, the House Intelligence Committee holds its first hearing on Russia’s hacking of the election. (No date has yet been set for the Senate Intelligence Committee’s parallel investigation.) The list of initial witnesses does not inspire confidence in the House committee’s effectiveness.

headline: Norbert W. Sander Jr., Champion of New York Running, Dies at 74
text: Dr. Norbert W. Sander Jr., the only runner from New York City to win its marathon and the driving force behind building one of the world’s premier indoor track facilities, in Upper Manhattan, died on Friday. He was 74.

headline: Cold Snap Kills Half of the Cherry Blossoms in Washington
text: The iconic cherry blossoms in Washington, which were forecast to bloom early this year because of unusually warm weather in February, instead endured a cold snap this week that killed half of them.

headline: Think Over
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I do try to pick fun pictures for the top of this blog, people. I try to follow the rules, be relevant and not too loopy, but today I stumbled on this awesome little metaphor for modern times, the glofish™. Thanks to years of high-end scientific research, the embryo of a perfectly fine little zebra fish (among other species) is injected with a single gene to produce fluorescence; for its entire life, then, and for our entertainment, this little fish is like a neon beacon flittering nervously through its watery environment, uncamouflaged unless it gets lucky enough to wind up in a submerged ‘80s nightclub.

headline: London Ridicules the Ridiculous
text: Will President Trump ever learn — or care — that his fact-free tweets have painful consequences, not just at home but abroad? Surely he must sense this by now, as the administration faces the outrage of British allies who have been dragged into his increasingly bogus allegation that he was spied on by the Obama administration.

headline: Texas Needs a Remedial Lesson on Voting Rights
text: In Texas, which has for decades made an art of violating the voting rights of minorities, officials and lawmakers can’t seem to keep their hands clean. Now, the state may become the first to have its voting practices placed under federal oversight since the Supreme Court struck down a central part of the Voting Rights Act in 2013.

headline: Me, Myself and My Hijab
text: OXFORD, England — One of the many issues that have been raised here in the aftermath of the Brexit vote revolves around identity. What does it mean to be British, to look British, to sound British?

headline: Depressed by Politics? Just Let Go
text: When is politics like a tree?

headline: The Long History of the Vietnam Novel
text: In 2012, the author Ben Fountain won the National Book Critics Circle Award for his book “Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk.” The novel — Mr. Fountain’s first — was also a finalist for the National Book Award, along with another debut novel, Kevin Powers’s “The Yellow Birds,” which received the 2013 PEN/Hemingway award for first fiction. Both are American novels about the Iraq war. In the half-decade since, literature about the Iraq and Afghanistan wars — much, but not all, by veterans of those wars — has done much to shape the cultural commentary on America’s latest military engagements, even as thousands of American service members remain in the regions.

headline: John Van de Kamp, Former Prosecutor in California, Dies at 81
text: John Van de Kamp, a prominent former prosecutor in Los Angeles who, as California’s attorney general, carried an AK-47 into a State Assembly hearing to demonstrate his opposition to assault rifles, died on March 14 at his home in Pasadena. He was 81.

headline: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
text: Between the blizzard on Tuesday (which wasn’t that bad, or was actually very bad), March Madness and St. Patrick’s Day, this has been a busy week for many.

headline: Corrections: March 18, 2017
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: A Yankees No-Hitter Is Just Part of a Strong Spring
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — It has been a smooth spring training for the Yankees with plenty to boast about. They have compiled the best record in the Grapefruit League, their young prospects have shone, and to top it off, they pitched a combined no-hitter in a matinee Friday that left the Detroit Tigers stifled and frustrated.

headline: A Comeback, a Controversial Call and Some Crackle at the N.C.A.A.s
text: Once again, there were no buzzer-beaters, no unexpected upsets or overtime thrillers, but at least the second day of the N.C.A.A. tournament offered a few reasons not to change the channel. Each of the four venues Friday hosted an early game that extracted a welcome dollop of drama, with three decided in the final seconds.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Why Him?’ and ‘Ice Age: Collision Course’
text: “Why Him?,” the crass comedy that pits Bryan Cranston against James Franco, arrives on iTunes. And “Ice Age: Collision Course” makes its way to the small screen on HBO and its streaming platforms.

headline: Hugh Hardy
text: The architect Hugh Hardy breathed new life into some of New York City’s most storied theatrical landmarks.

headline: Hugh Hardy, Architect Who Lent Pizazz to New York Landmarks, Dies at 84
text: Hugh Hardy, an architect who breathed exuberant new life into some of New York City’s most storied theatrical landmarks, among them Radio City Music Hall and the New Amsterdam Theater, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: In Silicon Valley, a Voice of Caution Guides a High-Flying Uber
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Travis Kalanick, the famously combative chief executive of Uber, took the stage at a Vanity Fair conference in San Francisco last October and quickly faced a prickly question. Why all the blunders at the company, Vanity Fair’s editor, Graydon Carter, asked. And had Mr. Kalanick learned anything?

headline: ‘Kids Are Unpredictable’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: Fighting Fakes on Alibaba From Arizona
text: Some small American businesses accuse Alibaba.com, China’s largest e-commerce company, of tolerating sales of counterfeits on its platforms. Step inside an industrial furniture workshop in Phoenix to see what’s at stake for the originals.

headline: A Small Table Maker Takes On Alibaba’s Flood of Fakes
text: PHOENIX — From his desk in a downtown workshop, Greg Hankerson is at war with a Chinese company half a world away.

headline: Gunman Is Killed in Orly Airport in France After Attacking a Soldier
text: PARIS — An attack on a soldier at Orly Airport near here on Saturday is being treated as a possible act of terrorism, according to the Paris prosecutor’s office. The assailant, the prosecutor said, had carried out a burst of violence over a period of two hours before being fatally shot.

headline: How I Became Addicted to Online Word Games
text: Everyone has heard grim tales of lives blighted by online gaming, stories that sound like urban legends even when they actually happened. There is the friend of a friend who played Second Life so obsessively that his real-life business failed; the web addict in Taiwan who died after a three-day binge; or even Alec Baldwin, kicked off a plane after refusing to stop playing Words With Friends. But most of us have too much sense to let online games mess up our travel plans, much less hook us on what the Chinese call “digital heroin,” right?

headline: With Her Dating App, Women Are in Control
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — As at most tech start-ups, the fridge was stocked with green juice and cold brew coffee. Unlike at most tech start-ups, there was not a single man present.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. Is His Own Kind of Trump
text: Donald Trump Jr. is the Trump who has not always seemed at ease with being a Trump. He grew up in the penthouse of Trump Tower but was happy to escape the gilded trappings of his Manhattan childhood to spend parts of the summers hunting and fishing with his maternal grandfather in the woods of what was then Czechoslovakia.

headline: Door-Busting Drug Raids Leave a Trail of Blood
text: Using SWAT officers to storm into homes to execute search warrants has led time and again to avoidable deaths, gruesome injuries and costly legal settlements.

headline: Murder or Self-Defense if Officer Is Killed in Raid?
text: With battering rams and flash-bang grenades, SWAT teams fuel the risk of violence as they forcibly enter suspects’ homes. Five months and 85 miles apart, two cases took starkly divergent legal paths.

headline: Gripes About Obamacare Aside, Health Insurers Are in a Profit Spiral
text: Over the last few years, big managed care companies like UnitedHealth Group have contributed to the furor over the fate of the Affordable Care Act by saying that important parts of it are fundamentally flawed.

headline: Violence in Forced-Entry Police Raids
text: As policing has militarized to fight a faltering war on drugs, few tactics have proved as dangerous as the use of forcible-entry raids to serve narcotics search warrants, which regularly introduce staggering levels of violence into missions that might be achieved through patient stakeouts or simple knocks at the door.

headline: Shadow Lending Threatens China’s Economy, Officials Warn
text: BEIJING — The chairman of China’s biggest bank and a senior Chinese insurance regulator issued strong warnings on Saturday about the dangers of shadow banking to the Chinese economy, in the latest signs of growing top-level concern here about a rise in highly speculative, poorly regulated lending.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Intel’s Big Bet on Self-Driving Cars
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: The Neighbors Won’t Stop Cutting Branches
text: Q. While we were away, our neighbors in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, cut branches hanging on their property from a tree in our backyard. We have a decent relationship with them, yet they did not say anything about it until we mentioned it. Then, when we were away again, they cut back the tree in our front yard. In both cases, they cut without regard to how the trees look or whether they would grow back. If they had asked, we would have trimmed the trees. Can we do anything? I know they can trim what hangs on their side, but they could destroy the trees.

headline: Trump Seeks Proposals for ‘Physically Imposing’ Wall With Mexico
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration late Friday night took the first steps toward fulfilling a campaign promise, requesting proposals to build a “physically imposing” wall on the border with Mexico.

headline: Losing a Business Deal but Winning Her Hand
text: Mary Rose Loney and Randall Schrader were married March 17 at Rose Creek Cottage in San Diego. Christine Brickley, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Getting It Wrong on Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
text: What are some of the treatment regimens that sufferers of chronic fatigue syndrome should follow? Many major medical organizations cite two: psychotherapy and a steady increase in exercise. There’s just one problem. The main study that has been cited as proof that patients can recover with those treatments overstated some of its results. In reality, the claim that patients can recover from these treatments is not justified by the data.

headline: In Gorsuch, Conservative Activist Sees Test Case for Reshaping the Judiciary
text: WASHINGTON — Deep into the Senate’s 68-page questionnaire of Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, the Supreme Court nominee was asked to describe how he had come to President Trump’s attention.

headline: We Who Remain
text: A relentless war persists in Sudan’s Nuba Mountains. Thousands have had to flee. In this virtual reality film, witness the story of those who remain.
