headline: Tony Conrad Was Such a Good Minimalist, He Was Almost Forgotten
text: In February 1963, a 22-year-old experimental violinist named Tony Conrad stood outside Philharmonic (now David Geffen) Hall in New York wearing a signboard that read “Demolish Lincoln Center!” With the composer Henry Flynt and the filmmaker Jack Smith, Mr. Conrad formed a three-man picket line that spent a day marching at the center, the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They were protesting, Mr. Conrad later recalled, “the imperialist influences of European high culture” and gesturing toward “the dismantling and dispersion of any and all organized cultural forms.”

headline: How Mick Rock, Music Photographer, Spends His Sundays

Between shoots, Mr. Rock, 68, edits his photography books and travels all over the world to attend his exhibition openings. A documentary about his life, “SHOT! The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock,” will be released on April 7 by Magnolia Pictures. Mr. Rock lives in Livingston, Staten Island, with his wife, Pati, who works in real estate, and their two Maine coon cats, Bellini and Razor.

headline: For Some, a Win-Win Election in Hong Kong
text: Hong Kong’s new leader will be selected on Sunday. Since Britain handed the territory back to China in 1997, the election of the chief executive — which is performed by a special 1,200-member committee stacked in Beijing’s favor — has generally been a foregone conclusion. But this year China’s leaders may not be able to dictate the outcome. A faction of powerful local business interests sidelined during the last election, in 2012, will come out on top no matter the result of the vote itself.

headline: Paul Farmer: Humans Aren’t Winning the War on TB
text: For decades there were few developments in the fight against tuberculosis — at least by humans. The bacteria that causes this airborne disease, in contrast, regularly boasts a number of deadly new upgrades, including mutations conferring resistance to almost all antibiotics developed to cure it. It has also made common cause with new allies (AIDS, weak health systems and budget cuts further sapping them) while maintaining its longstanding alliances with war, hunger, overcrowded and poorly ventilated housing, prisons, and workplaces.

headline: Semilla, Praised for Its Tasting Menu, Is Closing

Cooks at the small restaurant, acclaimed for its tasting menu of mainly vegetable and grain dishes, will bake whole roasted sunchokes into sourdough bread, and serve Carolina Gold rice with parsnips and black truffles.

headline: 5 Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
text: When visiting Philly, the waterfront working-class neighborhood of Fishtown may not be at the top of your list. Not just because you likely haven’t heard of it, but because there isn’t anywhere to stay. But it now comes highly recommended by locals for its growing food scene and small-town vibes despite steady gentrification. It’s home to more than a few hipster and creative types, and on one quiet corner sits a charming restaurant to rival any Brooklyn eatery: Wm. Mulherin’s Sons, which gets its name from the 19th-century whisky bottling and blending company that once occupied the space. Nearly every ingredient on its menu is made in-house, right down to the flour blends for the homemade pizza crusts. (Bon Appétit named it one of the 50 best restaurants to open in 2016.) And now, you can sleep upstairs — in one of the four chic rooms Wm. Mulherin’s Sons just opened as a hotel. They’re uniquely designed (and stocked with things like Kinfolk magazine and Aesop toiletries), and perfectly sized for longer stays (with full kitchens and even washing machines). The rooms are conveniently located above Wm. Mulherin’s Sons (for nightcaps) and around the corner from the La Colombe flagship (for morning coffee.) The most exciting part of your stay might just be checking in: Like at any old seaside pub, keys are simply doled out by anyone working the bar, so you can grab a pint before heading up to your room. From $275/night, wmmulherinssons.com — ALAINNA LEXIE BEDDIE

headline: This Meaty Fish Begs to Be Roasted
text: The monkfish ranks among the most fierce-looking of sea creatures, with an ugly mug only a monkfish’s mother could love. The horrid face with its wide, round smile reveals two enormous bear-trap-like rows of razor-sharp teeth pointing backward. This presents a clear hazard for unwary small fish that happen to be in proximity when said monkfish has its mouth open. They swim in naïvely but can’t swim out.

headline: The Head Honcho’s Head Honcho
text: White House chief of staff is such a thankless job that Jack Watson, who served in the role under Jimmy Carter, once compared it to being a “javelin catcher.”

headline: Amid Slaughterhouse Crackdown, India’s Lions Sample New Cuisine
text: MUMBAI — When the newly elected government of India’s most populous state began shutting down parts of the buffalo meat industry this week, the effects reverberated far and wide, but most immediately in the lions’ area at a city zoo.

headline: Marine Le Pen of France Meets With Vladimir Putin in Moscow
text: PARIS — Marine Le Pen, the French far right’s presidential candidate, has never hidden her admiration for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and on Friday she met with him in the Kremlin.

headline: The Great American Novelist Who Spied for the Soviets
text: The Old Man And The C.C.C.P.: The military historian Nicholas Reynolds considers himself a lifelong fan of Ernest Hemingway. “I started reading Hemingway when I was in junior high,” he told me in a recent email exchange, and even at that precocious age he admired all the things you might expect a future military historian to admire in Hemingway’s work. “The characters he created embodied so many American values we still cherish,” Reynolds explains in the introduction to his new Hemingway biography, “Writer, Sailor, Soldier, Spy,” which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 14. “Truth, bravery, independence, grace under pressure, standing up for the underdog.”

headline: An Obituary Six Years in the Making for Jimmy Breslin
text: “People are always dying in The Times who don’t seem to die in other papers, and they die at greater length and maybe even with a little more grace,” the New York Times columnist James Reston wrote in 1962.

headline: ‘Ties’ to Ferrante?
text: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: Janelle Monáe, Gloria Steinem and Cecile Richards Among CFDA Honorees
text: In 2017, it seems that everything is somehow touched by politics. And fashion, even when it is celebrated at a chic penthouse with Champagne and Hudson River views, is no exception.

headline: What a Buddhist Monk Taught Xi Jinping
text: ZHENGDING, China — In 1982, two men arrived in this dusty provincial town. One was Shi Youming, a Buddhist monk who was taking up a post in the ruins of one of Zhengding’s legendary temples. The other was Xi Jinping, the 29-year-old son of a top Communist Party official putting in a mandatory stint in the provinces as a bureaucrat in the government he would eventually lead.

headline: Understanding Race and History Through Photography
text: Sarah Lewis, an assistant professor at Harvard, challenges students to explore how photography, art and design formed concepts of racial identity.

headline: Understanding Race and History Through Photography
text: Sarah Lewis’s career path started long before she became an assistant professor of art history and African-American studies at Harvard, or held curatorial positions at the Museum of Modern Art and the Tate Modern.

headline: As a Paramedic Mourns a Colleague, the Calls Don't Stop
text: Capt. Mark A. Bonilla gets the call. He flips on the lights and siren of his red Emergency Medical Service vehicle and steps on the gas. A life in the balance. Adrenaline.

headline: John Mayer Has More to Say: The Outtakes
text: For this Sunday’s Arts and Leisure section, I profiled John Mayer, the 39-year-old singer, songwriter and guitar virtuoso, who also happens to be a prodigious talker — for better or worse. In 2010, a run of ill-advised interviews changed the course of his career as both a musician and a celebrity.

headline: Sarah Dunn on the Anatomy of an Open Marriage
text: It’s every married couple’s fantasy, at least in theory: You get to have sex with anyone you want, no questions asked. “I’m saying let’s both do it, and let’s swear to keep our mouths shut about it for the rest of our lives,” says the wife in Sarah Dunn’s new novel, “The Arrangement,” as she and her husband devise a little six-month-long adultery program.

headline: 12 Wine Grapes Worth Discovering
text: In the distant, cobwebbed past of the early 1980s, when I was first learning about wine, the choices were not so different from what they had been 100 years before.

headline: The Jihadi Who Turned to Jesus
text: ISTANBUL — When 22 Christian refugees gathered in the basement of an apartment in Istanbul early on a recent Sunday afternoon, it was quickly clear that this was no ordinary prayer meeting. Several of them had Islamic names. There was an Abdelrahman and even a couple of Mohammads. Strangest of all, they jokingly referred to their host — one of the two Mohammads — as an irhabi. A terrorist.

headline: Live Vote Count: Republicans Pull Health Care Bill
text: There will be no vote on the proposed legislation.

headline: A Rogue Trader Blames the System, but Not All Are Persuaded
text: LONDON — Six years ago, Kweku M. Adoboli was a UBS trader with a rich life in London.

headline: The Playlist: Kendrick Lamar Backs Up His Boasts
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

headline: The London Attacker: What We Know
text: Khalid Masood is the man identified as the attacker who killed four people near British Parliament on Wednesday. This is what we know about the still-emerging details of his life.

headline: What I Love | Lena Hall
text: The Tony Award-winning actress rents a studio apartment in the theater district.

headline: Lena Hall’s 500-Square-Foot Apartment in Midtown
text: The actress Lena Hall has a big, infectious chortle. It would fill a space far larger than the immaculate 500-square-foot alcove studio she rents in the theater district, and a card on a table by the window pays fitting tribute: “You have the best laugh in the history of best laughs.”

headline: China’s New Limits on Money Outflows Hit a Would-Be Paradise
text: HONG KONG — China’s intensifying efforts to keep money from leaving the country have cast doubt over big Hollywood deals and other marquee investments.

headline: Israeli City Stunned That Anti-Semitic Threats Came From Within
text: ASHKELON, Israel — On the rare occasions that this small Israeli city makes the news, it is usually because it has been struck by militant rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip.

headline: A New Twist in iHeartMedia’s Debt Struggles
text: In a restructuring world dominated by oil and gas companies on the one hand and retail on the other, iHeartMedia stands out.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: The Best of Our Lives Column
text: Since 1996, The Times Magazine has published the Lives column, a series of incisive, 800-word essays or as-told-to accounts that highlight small moments in real people’s lives. While a number of well-known writers have contributed to this column — including Nora Ephron, Michael Pollan, Karen Russell and others — some of the best submissions have been from nonprofessional writers, people who felt that they had a really good story to tell. As we close the column this week, we’ve gathered some of our favorite essays from the archive that illustrate the power of a simple story well told.

headline: Why the Payout to Credit Suisse’s Chief Is Undeserved
text: Tidjane Thiam’s compensation for 2016 shows Credit Suisse’s tin ear.

headline: Grieving Father of Germanwings Co-Pilot Tries to Clear Son’s Name
text: BERLIN — While families and friends gathered in Germany and southern France to mourn the victims of the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525, Günter Lubitz broke his silence on Friday to challenge the authorities’ conclusion that his son Andreas deliberately crashed the plane into the face of a mountain two years ago.

headline: Not Leadership Material? Good. The World Needs Followers.
text: In 1934, a young woman named Sara Pollard applied to Vassar College. In those days, parents were asked to fill out a questionnaire, and Sara’s father described her, truthfully, as “more a follower type than a leader.”

headline: A Nobel Laureate Takes On Trump in Her Latest Play
text: “On the Royal Road: The Burgher King,” a new play about President Trump written by the Nobel laureate Elfriede Jelinek, will have its first presentation next week in the United States.

headline: Review: Emperor Jones, Fearsome and Fearful in a Roaring Revival
text: The unbounded fury of Emperor Brutus Jones blasts into the room before he does. It is the sound of a powerful man in a dangerous fit of temper. “Who dare wake up the emperor?” he roars.

headline: Live Chat: Health Care Bill’s Collapse
text: Join Times reporters for coverage and analysis of the effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Review: ‘American Jihad’ and the Problem With the Internet
text: All the noise about immigration and travel restrictions is missing the point. Terror by radicalized Muslims isn’t going to be stopped unless someone unplugs the internet.

headline: The ‘Essential Health Benefits’ Conservatives Are Pushing to Cut
text: A list of the basic benefits insurers must offer to people who buy their own insurance in marketplaces established by the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Want Change? Shareholders Have a Tool for That
text: Are you an investor who usually junks the voluminous corporate proxy statements that arrive each spring, declining to take part in director elections and other governance matters because you think your vote won’t count?

headline: When Others Die, Tontine Investors Win
text: Living a long life is its own reward. But when you invest in a tontine, there’s an added benefit: You collect money that would have gone to people who have died.

headline: Luxury Buildings’ Latest Amenity: Co-Working Spaces
text: Maani Safa, the co-founder of Etch, does not lack for places to work. His company, which focuses on digital innovation, strategy and product development, rents a shared work space in TriBeCa and has offices in London and Sydney. He also keeps a home office in his two-bedroom apartment at Abington House, a rental building in West Chelsea owned by Related Companies.

headline: A Pitch for Eyeglasses That Sounds Eerily Familiar
text: On March 9, Sarah Lauch received an email from a company called OpticsFast that left her shaking with anger. It read: “Good news! I finally found the 3115b glasses for you, that you originally wanted. I know it’s been a while, I always follow up on my good customers.”

headline: At a Therapeutic Ranch, No Payday Until Later
text: As I set a spade to dirt, I thought back to the moment I had arrived at this dusty working ranch in southern Utah. I stepped off the plane knowing very little about what lay ahead — only that this rehabilitation program would include long periods of hard labor.

headline: Visualizing the Cosmic Streams That Spew Meteor Showers
text: The Earth sails through streams of cosmic debris as it orbits the sun. When specks of dust and ice left behind by comets or asteroids collide with our atmosphere, we experience meteor showers. But what we’re seeing are only the final moments of a particle’s path through space. Most flecks have traveled for millions of miles before we see them burn up (if we’re lucky).

headline: Gershon Kekst, Leader in Wall St. Public Relations, Dies at 82
text: Gershon Kekst, a corporate adviser who counseled many of the biggest deal makers during the merger boom of the 1980s and helped form the modern financial public relations industry, died on March 17 in New York. He was 82.

headline: The Displaced
text: Nearly 60 million people are currently displaced from their homes by war and persecution. Half are children. This virtual reality film tells the stories of three of them.

headline: Providing a Haven for the Homeless
text: Olga Bas, 30, is a youth counselor at the Ali Forney Center in New York.

headline: Africa Center Looks to Close Fund-Raising Gap, and Open Its Doors
text: The building that houses the Africa Center, a Harlem institution devoted to African art and policy, has been completed for several years now. But fund-raising obstacles have prevented the center’s space itself from opening.

headline: A Met Opera Star is Born: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
text: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what they’ve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

headline: U.S. Investigating Mosul Strikes Said to Have Killed Up to 200 Civilians
text: BAGHDAD — The American-led military coalition in Iraq said Friday that it was investigating reports that scores of civilians — perhaps as many as 200, residents said — had been killed in recent American airstrikes in Mosul, the northern Iraqi city at the center of an offensive to drive out the Islamic State.

headline: SeaWorld Stake, Long Held by Blackstone, Is Sold to Chinese Firm
text: Over seven years, the Blackstone Group nearly tripled its investment in SeaWorld, the home of Shamu and other killer whales.

headline: Former Penn State President Found Guilty in Sandusky Abuse Case
text: Five years after a child sex abuse scandal rocked Penn State, damaging its reputation, exposing a revered coach as a serial predator and sending him to prison, a jury on Friday convicted the former president of the university of child endangerment for failing to stop the abuse.

headline: E.U. Is Turning 60 and Searching for Something to Celebrate
text: LONDON — Sixty years after the treaty that led to its founding, the European Union is under fundamental stress — divided and divergent, anxious that it no longer represents the future but the past, and that it may be incapable of handling the serious challenges of this already-turbulent century.

headline: Behind the Rise of the Tampa Bay Rays’ Fastballs
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — In the last 10 years, no pitching staff in the American League has recorded as many strikeouts as the Tampa Bay Rays’. Their pitching coach, for all that time, has been Jim Hickey, who spent two decades as a pitcher and a coach in the minors. When he joined the Houston Astros, in 2004, he saw up close how a rising fastball really looks to a hitter.

headline: Eggs for Dinner, and Make It Spicy
text: Eggs have not been part of the regular dinner rotation at my house nearly as often as they should be.

headline: Eggs in Spicy Tomato Sauce (Ande Ki Kari)
text: Dress up hard-boiled eggs with bold flavors in this Indian curry sauce.

headline: California Upholds Auto Emissions Standards, Setting Up Face-Off With Trump
text: California’s clean-air agency voted on Friday to push ahead with stricter emissions standards for cars and trucks, setting up a potential legal battle with the Trump administration over the state’s plan to reduce planet-warming gases.

headline: Owner of Airbnb Listing in Trump Tower Is Fined $1,000
text: New York City officials issued a summons to the owner of a condominium at Trump Tower that gained notoriety after being rented out on Airbnb, determining that the unit was being illegally advertised for rent.

headline: On Eve of E.U. Anniversary, Pope Warns of Bloc’s Fragility
text: ROME — On the eve of celebrations commemorating the 60th anniversary of treaties that led to the creation of the European Union, Pope Francis warned the bloc’s leaders on Friday that while their countries may be “inseparably linked,” the project could still fail.

headline: Can the Arts Thrive Without Washington? A Kansas Town Says Yes
text: HAYS, Kan. — When taxpayer money for the arts started getting tight in Kansas, Brenda Meder began scrubbing toilets at the gallery she oversees here, rather than paying for custodial services. She cooked the finger food for receptions, instead of using a caterer. And she signed up more dues-paying members of the Hays Arts Council, a 49-year-old organization where she is the executive director and only full-time employee.

headline: Boris V. Shekhtman, Who Taught Russian to Journalists and Diplomats, Dies at 77
text: Boris V. Shekhtman, a Soviet émigré who taught conversational Russian to a generation of American journalists, diplomats and entrepreneurs — from the grim lingo of Cold War aggression to the beguiling argot of capitalist negotiation — died on March 18 in Silver Spring, Md. He was 77.

headline: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend

headline: In a Call to The Times, Trump Blames Democrats for the Failure of the Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Just moments after the Republican plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act was declared dead, President Trump sought to paint the defeat of his first legislative effort as an early-term blip.

headline: Court Awards $1 Million for Victims of Congolese Warlord
text: PARIS — The International Criminal Court on Friday found a former militia leader liable for $1 million in reparations to his victims and their relatives in a village in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It ordered that payments be made in small amounts of cash to individuals and used for projects benefiting the wider community.

headline: With Classic Watch, TAG Heuer Turns Back Time at Baselworld Fair
text: Two years ago, TAG Heuer grabbed headlines at the giant Baselworld watch fair with a glimpse of the future: a Google-enabled smartwatch, the Connected, that was considered the first big Swiss counterstrike to the Apple Watch.

headline: Big Ben Still Tolled
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Waking From Hibernation, the Hard Work of Spring Begins
text: For animals that hibernate, making it to spring is no small feat. Torpor — the state of reduced bodily activity that occurs during hibernation — is not restful. By the time they emerge, hibernating animals are often sleep-deprived: Most expend huge bursts of energy to arouse themselves occasionally in the winter so their body temperatures don’t dip too low. This back-and-forth is exhausting, and hibernators do it with little to no food and water. By winter’s end, some have shed more than half their body weight.

headline: Tracing His Roots, Georgetown Employee Learns University Sold His Ancestor
text: As a Georgetown employee, Jeremy Alexander watched as the university grappled with its haunted past: the sale of slaves in 1838 to help rescue it from financial ruin.

headline: Don Hunstein, Who Photographed Great Musicians, Dies at 88
text: On a freezing February afternoon in 1963, the photographer Don Hunstein asked Bob Dylan and his girlfriend, Suze Rotolo, to walk along a slush-covered Jones Street in Greenwich Village, near Mr. Dylan’s small apartment. Mr. Dylan, in a thin jacket, and Ms. Rotolo, bundled in a coat over bulky sweaters, strolled arm in arm past cars and trucks and into music history.

headline: The Photographs of Don Hunstein
text: As a staff photographer for Columbia Records, Mr. Hunstein shot Bob Dylan, Billie Holiday and many others.

headline: Women’s Team’s Fight Sheds Light on U.S.A. Hockey Leadership
text: After a 10-hour meeting Monday with U.S.A. Hockey, members of the United States women’s national team were confident that an agreement for increased pay and support was near.

headline: Russian Agent Killed Lawmaker in Kiev, Ukraine Officials Say
text: The assassin who gunned down a prominent Russian opposition figure on a sidewalk in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev was identified by Ukrainian officials on Friday as a 28-year-old Russian agent.

headline: Trump’s Trainwreck
text: For seven years — seven years — Republicans thundered about the evils of Obamacare, yearned for the day when they could bury it and vowed to do precisely that once the ball was in their hands.

headline: How the Health Care Vote Fell Apart, Step by Step
text: WASHINGTON — After several days of dramatic back and forth between President Trump and Republicans in Congress, House Republicans pulled a bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, delivering the president a staggering defeat in his first high-profile legislative effort.

headline: Toronto Schools to Cease Field Trips to U.S.
text: Toronto schools have stopped planning field trips to the United States, citing concerns that some students may be turned away at the border in the wake of President Trump’s latest travel ban and the American immigration authorities’ newly implemented “extreme vetting” procedures.

headline: Bizarre Stunt at Auschwitz: Group Kills a Sheep, Then Strips
text: WARSAW — Nearly a dozen people in their 20s gathered beside the entrance to the Auschwitz memorial on Friday afternoon, slaughtered a sheep, stripped naked and chained themselves together. A fireworks device was set off in the nearby parking lot.

headline: On the Rock, Looking Inward and Outward
text: Jeffersonville, Vt. — Just at the edge of sight, a man dangled from a rope, high in the air. For days, storms had dimmed the sky, but the angle of the cliff overhung so much that the drops of water fell to the ground without touching him. It was as if, he later wrote, he climbed under the protection of a “stupendous umbrella.”

headline: The Real Threat to National Security: Deadly Disease
text: While the Trump administration is proposing significantly increased military spending to enhance our national security, it seems to have lost sight of the greatest national security threat of all: our fight against infectious disease.

headline: I Loved My Grandmother. But She Was a Nazi.
text: My grandparents were Nazis. It took me until recently to be able to say — or write — this. I used to think of and refer to them as “ordinary Germans,” as if that was a distinct and morally neutral category. But like many “ordinary Germans,” they were members of the Nazi Party — they joined in 1937.

headline: Amid Trump Inquiry, a Primer on Surveillance Practices and Privacy
text: WASHINGTON — The assertion by the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Devin Nunes, that he saw intelligence reports showing that government surveillance programs “incidentally” collected communications involving Trump transition team members between November and January, has further muddied an already murky imbroglio.

headline: Trump’s Choice on Obamacare: Sabotage or Co-opt?
text: President Trump and a Republican-led Congress tried and failed to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Now, they have to decide whether they want to work with it or sabotage it.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2017: Friday Night
text: How does it feel to walk into the biggest crossword puzzle tournament in the country? Walk into the Stamford, CT Marriott Hotel with Deb Amlen to find out.

headline: Starting for Oregon, Three Freshmen Who Don’t Play Like It
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — The Oregon Ducks women’s basketball team, which has reached the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 16 for the first time and faces mighty Maryland on Saturday, appears to contradict the idea that experience is vital to winning games in March.

headline: Fact Check: Trump’s Misleading Claims on the Health Bill Failure
text: WASHINGTON — Reeling from a major blow to his legislative agenda, President Trump blamed Democrats on Friday after House Republicans rescinded their bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. He insisted it wasn’t an immediate priority anyway.

headline: Civics Lesson Unfolds at Capitol as Health Care Bill Incinerates
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump had already given his blessing: Pull the bill. Speaker Paul D. Ryan, bound for the basement of the Capitol, was preparing to deliver the news to his conference.

headline: The Trump Administration Clears Trump’s Washington Hotel
text: Since the election, it has been clear that Donald Trump cannot both be president and maintain a lease on the government-owned Old Post Office building in Washington, where he opened an opulent hotel last year. Now, a federal official who works for the agency that negotiated the lease (and that, conveniently, reports to the president) has come up with a bizarre, tortured and ultimately dishonest rationale for why Mr. Trump can keep it.

headline: Meet the Queens of Monday Puzzles
text: Lynn Lempel and Andrea Carla Michaels meet for the first time Friday night at the 2017 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

headline: Stolen Bases Continue to Plague Noah Syndergaard and Travis d’Arnaud
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets starter Noah Syndergaard has made a point of improving the pace of his delivery to home plate. He has had no choice, really, because he allowed a major league-leading 48 stolen bases last season and teams were increasingly looking to run on him.

headline: Paul Manafort to Testify Before House Intelligence Panel
text: WASHINGTON — Paul Manafort, who served as President Trump’s campaign manager and is under scrutiny for his ties to Russia, will testify before the House Intelligence Committee, the panel’s chairman said on Friday.

headline: Who Stopped the Republican Health Bill?
text: A closer look at members who were against the proposed law.

headline: Bernie Wrightson, Artist and a Creator of Swamp Thing, Dies at 68
text: Bernie Wrightson, a widely admired comic book artist who was known for his lush, intricate, otherworldly visions of horror and who was one of the creators of the popular DC Comics character Swamp Thing, died on March 18 in Austin, Tex. He was 68.

headline: In Reporter’s Hometown, Students Look Toward ‘Somewhere They’re Welcomed’
text: One by one, the students in Phillip Wrigley’s college advising class at Topeka High School listed their names, the colleges they wanted to apply to and the majors they might like to pursue.

headline: William Keeler, Cardinal Who Championed Sexual Abuse Victims, Dies at 86
text: Cardinal William H. Keeler, who as archbishop of Baltimore strove to improve relations between the Roman Catholic Church and American Jews, and who championed victims of sexual abuse by priests, died on Thursday in Catonsville, Md. He was 86.

headline: Trump’s Triumph of Incompetence
text: One of President Trump’s rare strengths has been his ability to project competence. The Dow Jones stock index is up an astonishing 2,200 points since his election in part because investors believed Trump could deliver tax reform and infrastructure spending.

headline: Echoes of Gunfire Hurt Tender N.R.A. Ears
text: It is a chilling commentary on the nature of gun mayhem in this country that dozens of cities and towns are resorting to new listening technology so the police can track the location of gunfire in a matter of seconds.

headline: The TrumpRyanCare Debacle
text: Repealing the Affordable Care Act was meant to be the first demonstration of the power and effectiveness of a unified Republican government. It has turned out to be a display of incompetence and cruelty.

headline: Israel May Offer Only a General Commitment to Slow Settlement Building
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s negotiations with the Israeli government are expected to yield only a general commitment — and not a specific pledge — to slow the building of Jewish settlements in the West Bank, an administration official briefed on the talks said on Friday.

headline: Bracing for the Fallout of the Health Bill’s Collapse
text: WASHINGTON — Friday’s collapse of Republican plans to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act has broad implications not only for the nation’s health care system, but also for the fate of President Trump’s ambitious agenda in his young and chaotic presidency.

headline: The Health Care Bill Has Failed. Let the Finger Pointing Begin.
text: The blame game is a time-honored Washington tradition. A look at who’s blaming whom for the failure of the House bill, in public and in private.

headline: Republicans Land a Punch on Health Care, to Their Own Face
text: WASHINGTON — At the end of the long day, the alliance of conservative ideologues who once shut down the government over President Barack Obama’s health care law could not find the will to repeal it.

headline: In Dropping Health Vote, Trump Swallowed Need for a Showdown
text: WASHINGTON — When Speaker Paul D. Ryan arrived at the White House on Friday to inform President Trump that the health care bill he had made his first major legislative push could not pass, Mr. Trump had one reaction: He wanted revenge.

headline: Canada Today: Restaurant Resentment and Cardboard Trudeaus
text: Each week, Canada Today mixes the Times’s recent Canada-related coverage with back stories and analysis from our reporters along with opinions from our readers.

headline: U.N. Takes Step Toward Future Prosecutions Against North Korea
text: The United Nations Human Rights Council adopted a resolution on Friday that authorizes the use of criminal justice experts to devise legal strategies for eventual prosecutions of violations by North Korea.

headline: North Carolina Runs Over Butler in Path to Redemption
text: MEMPHIS — Coach Roy Williams recalled feeling so inadequate in that locker room last season. North Carolina had just lost in the national championship game to Villanova on a last-second shot, and Williams was left to rummage through his team’s splintered dreams. What could he say? How could he help?

headline: Time of One’s Life
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s such a relief to me that crosswords are a “cool” thing to do now.

headline: Republicans Withdraw Their Health Bill
text: President Trump faced stiff opposition from lawmakers in his own party to the measure he had endorsed, and it was withdrawn.

headline: Police Posted Missing Teenagers’ Data on Social Media. A City Took Note.
text: A new approach by the Metropolitan Police Department in Washington to use social media to raise awareness about teenagers reported missing did indeed gain attention — some of it unintentional.

headline: South Carolina Stuns Baylor to Reach the Round of Eight
text: South Carolina’s win over second-seeded Duke was not only a surprise to fans. In the postgame revelry, Coach Frank Martin had to ask an assistant whom his team would face next.

headline: Two Die in Separate Cases of Falling From Buildings in Brooklyn
text: A 21-year-old man died at an apartment party on early Saturday morning in Brooklyn after falling through a screen window on the building’s fourth floor, the police said.

headline: Alone in the Wild for a Year, TV Contestants Learn Their Show Was Canceled
text: The remaining contestants on a reality television series have emerged after surviving 12 months in the Scottish wilderness — fending off hunger, infighting and fatigue — only to learn that the show stopped broadcasting after four episodes, the last of them in August.

headline: Arkansas Struggles to Find Enough People to Watch Executions
text: The state of Arkansas, which plans to execute eight inmates over 10 days next month, is struggling to overcome a logistical problem to carry that out: There are not enough people who want to watch them die.

headline: John Calipari Has a Winning Return to Memphis as Kentucky Tops U.C.L.A.
text: MEMPHIS — At halftime, Kentucky Coach John Calipari relayed a set of instructions to his players.

headline: Dustin Johnson and Phil Mickelson Cruise at Match Play
text: Dustin Johnson and Phil Mickelson showed the simple side to the Dell Technologies Match Play in Austin, Tex. For three straight days in warmth, wind or rain, they built early leads and never let anyone get close to them in advancing out of their groups to the knockout stage.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: Adam Driver in ‘Paterson’ and a Murderous Mother-to-Be in ‘Prevenge’
text: Adam Driver gets behind the wheel — and turns his musings into poetry — in Jim Jarmusch’s “Paterson.” And an expectant mother goes on a killing rampage guided by her fetus in “Prevenge.”

headline: U.S. Routs Honduras and Steadies Its World Cup Qualifying Campaign
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — There was never any reason to worry. Nope, never, not at all.

headline: Chris Chiozza’s Buzzer-Beater Sends Florida Past Wisconsin in Overtime
text: There were five Wisconsin players and one whirring blur of white cleaving all of them — a Florida point guard motoring up the court, veering out of control and finally planting his foot at just the right spot.

headline: Seen on the Streets: Fashion Mavericks, a Stylish Couple and Fran Lebowitz
text: “I’m not really interested in color,” said Andre Wagner, a Brooklyn photographer who specializes in street style. “Black and white photography just has a harmony that I like.”

headline: ‘Never Has Politics Felt So Personal to Me’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: Amazon’s Ambitions Unboxed: Stores for Furniture, Appliances and More
text: SEATTLE — Last Sunday in Palm Springs, Calif., Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, climbed into the cockpit of a 13-foot robot and began flailing his arms as though warming up for a workout, causing the robot’s enormous appendages to mimic his movements.

headline: Animals in the Artist's Studio
text: Artist Kendra Haste was commissioned to create sculptures of the wild animals that once lived in the Royal Menagerie. Get a 360 view of her studio/zoo and the installation at the Tower of London.

headline: When David Met Brooke: The Ultimate New York Power Couple
text: At the Museum of Modern Art’s annual spring benefit last June, Helen Mirren could be spotted near one of the artists being honored that night, Brice Marden. A few feet away was Marilyn Minter, squiring another honoree, Mark Bradford.

headline: Canadians Adopted Refugee Families for a Year. Then Came ‘Month 13.’
text: TORONTO — One year after Canada embraced Syrian refugees like no other country, a reckoning was underway.

headline: Missing Taiwanese Man May Be in Chinese Custody, Some Fear
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The disappearance of a Taiwanese activist for human rights and democratic causes has raised fears here that he may have been detained by the Chinese authorities.

headline: What’s Ann-Margret Doing at 75? Still Playing the Girl Next Door
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — In the new Zach Braff-directed heist comedy “Going in Style,” out April 7, the performer Ann-Margret stars as Annie, a supermarket employee who flirts, overtly, with a grumpy old man of a customer played by Alan Arkin.

headline: Ariel Levy Has Written a Thoroughly Modern Memoir
text: Just before Thanksgiving 2012, Ariel Levy, a staff writer at The New Yorker, flew to Mongolia to report on that country’s mining boom. She was 38 years old and five months pregnant, and on her second night there, she miscarried in her hotel room, delivering her son in a torrent of blood that nearly killed her. Her son would not survive, but Ms. Levy detailed in a heartbreaking essay a year later that would win her a National Magazine Award that after she yanked the placenta from her body, crawled to the phone and called a local doctor, she took the boy’s photo.

headline: The Perverse Thrill of Chaotic Times
text: For all the rational appeal of peace and stability, Americans have a powerful attraction to calamity and disruption. World War II veterans commonly speak of their time in the military, when they felt deeply connected to a meaningful goal, as the best years of their lives. For many baby boomers, the late 1960s, with all its sturm und drang over an unpopular war and antiquated social policies, remains on their personal highlight reels (the free love and drugs may have had something to do with it, too). People who came of age in the pacific ’90s just don’t speak as reverently of seeing Stone Temple Pilots play Lollapalooza as flower children do of watching Hendrix at Woodstock.

headline: Ginger Gibson and Travis Burk: She Was All Business, or So He Thought
text: Virginia Stella Gibson and Travis Andrews Burk were married March 25 at Maison du Lac, an event space in New Orleans. The Very Rev. William A. J. Heine Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: The New Currency Champ Lives South of the Border
text: Can you guess which world currency has gained the most since Donald J. Trump’s inauguration as president?

headline: E.U. Leaders Sign Rome Declaration and Proclaim a ‘Common Future’ (Minus Britain)
text: ROME — Proclaiming “Europe is our common future,” 27 leaders of the European Union signed a statement on Saturday in Rome declaring their commitment to integrating the Continent even as a series of crises has badly weakened the efforts and Britain prepares  to leave the bloc.

headline: One Nation, Under Fox: 18 Hours With a Network That Shapes America
text: “I know maybe the president is watching.”

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: YouTube’s Problematic Advertising
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Endless Parties Next Door
text: Q. I live in a rent-stabilized building in Chelsea, Manhattan, next to a  woman who gives  loud parties. She and her guests yell, bang on  walls and slam doors until 5 a.m. The police will not intervene because she will not open the door for them. After I complained, she retaliated by banging on my door, which I considered harassment. Many tenants, and the live-in super, have complained to her and notified the landlord, who said there is nothing he can do. Is this  true? What legal standing do we have?

headline: Knicks’ Joakim Noah Suspended for Failing a Doping Test
text: The Knicks’ Joakim Noah became one of the rare prominent N.B.A. players to be suspended under the league’s policy on performance-enhancing drugs when the league announced Saturday that he would serve a 20-game penalty.

headline: Robin O’Hara, Producer of Independent Films, Dies at 62
text: Robin O’Hara, who was a producer of Tom Noonan’s “What Happened Was ...,” a co-producer of Harmony Korine’s “Gummo” and a producer of other notable independent films, died on March 14 in Manhattan. She was 62.

headline: Clint Dempsey’s Hat Trick Seals a Win and Steadies a World Cup Campaign
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — This whole notion of the United States national team being in crisis has been getting a little tiresome for the players, and as if to underscore his frustration after its 6-0 thrashing of Honduras at Avaya Stadium on Friday night, midfielder Michael Bradley dipped into the past for context.

headline: After London Attack, Living Between Cultures
text: Five days ago in London, Iranians were celebrating Nowruz, teaching our English friends to say “Happy New Year” in Farsi. Two days later, a terrorist named Khalid Masood drove into a crowd of pedestrians on Westminster Bridge, killing two and injuring forty. Now, again, here we are on familiar ground: Someone has killed in the name of Islam.

headline: Where You’re Not a Senior Until You’re Eighty
text: SPECIAL POST — If you can read and write, you can solve a crossword puzzle. It doesn’t make much of a difference if you are eight or eighty, except as far as your cultural references are concerned. Taking delight in playing with words and language helps.

headline: Miners Found a 706-Carat Diamond in Sierra Leone. Who Should Get the Profit?
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Fist-size and lumpy, the rock that a team of miners came upon recently in the diamond fields of Sierra Leone was orange with red speckles that looked like tiny droplets of palm oil.

headline: Indonesians’ Taste for Dog Meat Is Growing, Even as Others Shun It
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Parlin Sitio leaned back from a table of empty dishes at a restaurant in eastern Jakarta with a look of satisfaction. He had just enjoyed an order of rica-rica — dog meat with Indonesian spices.

headline: British Party That Backed ‘Brexit’ Loses Its Only Member of Parliament
text: LONDON — The short and happy life of the United Kingdom Independence Party, or UKIP, may be coming to a close after its only member of Parliament, Douglas Carswell, quit the party on Saturday to become an independent.

headline: Renegotiate Nafta? Mexicans Say Get On With It
text: MEXICO CITY — For more than two decades, free trade has been at the heart of Mexico’s relationship with America, responsible for pumping a stream of vehicles, audio components and avocados north and cheap corn, cattle and software south.

headline: Nebraska May Stanch One Town’s Flow of Beer to Its Vulnerable Neighbors
text: WHITECLAY, Neb. — This town is a rural skid row, with only a dozen residents, a street strewn with debris, four ramshackle liquor stores and little else. It seems to exist only to sell beer to people like Tyrell Ringing Shield, a grandmother with silver streaks in her hair.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — The last time a Puns and Anagrams puzzle ran in The Times, the editor Will Shortz gave us a handy lesson on the wide variety of cluing that solvers can find in PandAs, as they are affectionately called. Mr. Shortz wrote the piece to clarify that PandAs had a method for cluing beyond just puns and anagrams, and that they are a type of puzzle that stands strongly on its own, as opposed to just being somewhat similar to a cryptic crossword.

headline: Trump Becomes Ensnared in Fiery G.O.P. Civil War
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump ignites a lot of fights, but his failure to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the biggest defeat in his short time in the White House, was the result of something else: a long-running Republican civil war that humbled a generation of party leaders before he ever came to Washington.

headline: Paul Ryan Emerges From Health Care Defeat Badly Damaged
text: WASHINGTON — For two days in January, all seemed right in the Republican Party.

headline: Trump’s Biggest Obstacle to Policy Goals? His Own Missteps
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s failure to make good on his signature promise to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act is the most crushing political defeat of his early days in the White House.

headline: Shoes, Shirts, You Name It, College Basketball Players Get It. Free.
text: MEMPHIS — One of the perks of playing college basketball for a powerhouse program like North Carolina is all the team-issued gear. Every year, the Tar Heels are outfitted with more shirts, sweats and sneakers than they can possibly wear in a season.

headline: U.S.-Led Coalition Confirms Strikes Hit Mosul Site Where Civilians Died
text: WASHINGTON — The American-led military coalition in Iraq said Saturday that an initial review of recent airstrikes in Mosul, the Islamic State’s last stronghold in Iraq, had confirmed that the strikes hit a site where scores of civilians were killed.

headline: Greg Bird’s Bat Has Powers. His Cat Has Dr. Evil.
text: TAMPA, Fla. — For more than four decades, the Yankees’ lineup has almost always included a first baseman with left-handed power. Think of Chris Chambliss, Don Mattingly, Tino Martinez, Jason Giambi and Mark Teixeira. Chances are you picture a lot of home runs clearing the inviting right-field wall in the Bronx.

headline: Going Under the Knife, With Eyes and Ears Wide Open
text: BENSALEM, Pa. — “Do you want to see your tendons?”

headline: Watching My Surgeon Cut Into My Knee
text: What if the surgeon started slicing into my knee before it was completely numb?

headline: Meet the Judges
text: SPECIAL POST — The prospect of running a tournament with more than 600 competitors over the course of an exhausting weekend is a daunting one, but Will Shortz, who has hosted the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament for 40 years, is prepared.

headline: Donald, This I Will Tell You
text: WASHINGTON — Dear Donald,

headline: U.S. vs. Nordic Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Would You Do With an Intruder at the Door?
text: LOS ANGELES — I was working at my desk the other day, overlooking my front yard, when I saw a man walk by the window and around the corner toward the back of the house. He was in his late 20s, wearing a rumpled gray sweatshirt; I’d never seen him before.

headline: Will the Labor Secretary Help Labor?
text: R. Alexander Acosta had an advantage last week when he appeared before the Senate committee overseeing his nomination by President Trump to be secretary of labor: He was not Andrew Puzder, the unqualified fast-food executive and Mr. Trump’s first choice, who had to withdraw in the face of public and senatorial opposition to his appointment.

headline: Pumping Life Into the Equal Rights Amendment
text: The progress of women’s equality has not exactly been swift in American history. The endorsement of the Equal Rights Amendment on Wednesday by the Nevada Legislature — 35 years after the congressional deadline for passage — is being read by supporters as an encouraging sign, however slow-paced.

headline: Thanks for Submitting Your Résumé to This Black Hole
text: From: Job Spotter

headline: Congress’s Duty in the War With ISIS
text: On the verge of driving the Islamic State out of Mosul, once Iraq’s second-largest city, the United States and its allies are beginning a push to recapture Raqqa, the Syrian city that is the de facto capital of the self-declared caliphate.

headline: Don’t Fight Their Lies With Lies of Your Own
text: A student asked me the other day whether I approved of exaggerating for a good cause. The topic had apparently been discussed at an environmental forum, and the question was, essentially, “Does saving the climate justify lying?” Wouldn’t it be a good idea to use an impressive, if not necessarily factually correct, message to counteract the mind-numbing cacophony of the Trump administration, which drowns out more reasoned speech?

headline: The Love Letters of Manly Men
text: Flowers, trinkets, borrowed sweaters and other reminders of our romantic past may get tossed out. But love letters, for those lucky enough to receive them, are different. They are more likely tucked in a wallet or safeguarded in a box under the bed.

headline: After Great Pain, Where Is God?
text: These days I find I’m more alert to the grief and sorrow around me than I once was. In part it’s a product of my age, of youth giving way. I’m guessing my situation is not that different from many of yours.

headline: Justice Springs Eternal
text: THIS wasn’t how the story was supposed to end. After almost 50 years of relentless prison-building in the United States, of aggressive policing and a war on drugs that goes after our most vulnerable citizens, the movement for a more merciful criminal justice system had begun to seem, if not unstoppable, at least plenty powerful.

headline: Break Up the Liberal City
text: THE age of Trump has inspired soul-searching within our overclass — long nights reading “Hillbilly Elegy,” mostly — but also a wave of cosmopolitan pride. During the presidential campaign, when Trump talked about making America great again, Hillary Clinton countered that “America is already great” — meaning, of course, dynamic and diverse and tolerant and future-oriented, all the things that Trump seems to dismiss and his voters seem to fear.

headline: What You Can Do About Climate Change
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — What can you — just one concerned person — do about global warming?

headline: The 2017 A.C.P.T. Rankings After Puzzle 2
text: SPECIAL POST — We’re headed into Puzzle 4 as of this writing, but the rankings after Puzzle 2 are available online here.

headline: Congolese Militia Beheads Dozens of Police Officers
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Members of a militia ambushed and then beheaded about 40 police officers on Friday in a central province of the Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said on Saturday.

headline: North Korea’s Rising Ambition Seen in Bid to Breach Global Banks
text: When hackers associated with North Korea tried to break into Polish banks late last year they left a trail of information about their apparent intentions to steal money from more than 100 organizations around the world, according to security researchers.

headline: Uber Suspends Tests of Self-Driving Vehicles After Arizona Crash
text: Uber said on Saturday that it was suspending the testing of its self-driving vehicles, a day after one of the vehicles was involved in a collision in Tempe, Ariz.

headline: Out to Fix the Twins, a New Executive Wants More From the Mound
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The best Derek Falvey can say about himself, as a pitcher, is that he usually put the ball where he wanted. He had a generic assortment of pitches: a curveball, a changeup and a fastball that never reached 90 miles per hour. Sometimes he varied arm angles. He tried anything to survive.

headline: Neighbors of Masood: ‘We Are All Very Shocked’
text: Neighbors of Khalid Masood, the London attacker, were left stunned by the news that he had lived alongside them in Birmingham, after police officers raided his former home.

headline: Health Bill’s Failure Leaves Supporters in a Political Jam Back Home
text: They went to unusual, even dangerous lengths to support President Trump’s unpopular health care bill, facing down protesters at home and begging for special accommodation from House leaders in Washington. John Faso of New York negotiated a side deal for his state in exchange for backing it. Mike Coffman was the lone Colorado lawmaker to endorse the bill, while his Republican neighbors agonized and stalled.

headline: Alex Jones Apologizes for Promoting ‘Pizzagate’ Hoax
text: Alex Jones, a prominent conspiracy theorist and the host of a popular right-wing radio show, has apologized for helping to spread and promote the hoax known as Pizzagate.

headline: Andorra Ends 11 Years of Losses, With a Tie
text: Rarely has a scoreless stalemate tasted so sweet. But 11 years of nothing but losing will do that to a team.

headline: After an Uncharacteristic Early Stumble, UConn Breezes to Win
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma won his 112th N.C.A.A. tournament game on Saturday, tying Tennessee’s Pat Summitt for the career record. And his top-seeded team advanced to the Bridgeport Regional final with an 86-71 win over fourth-seeded U.C.L.A., the 110th straight victory for the Huskies, four-time defending national champions.

headline: Mixed Results
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — A brief one today, as I am off to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, which will be well underway by the time you read this column.

headline: ‘A Risk We Choose’: Emergency Workers Mourn One of Their Own
text: Five magenta balloons bobbed above a crowd of onlookers, near the white caps of uniformed chiefs arrayed along University Avenue in the Bronx. They were held aloft by five strangers, united in sadness for a fellow Bronx woman whom none had ever met, but each felt they knew.

headline: Gonzaga Marches Into Its First Final Four by Routing Xavier
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Mark Few’s father, Norm, was a Presbyterian minister for more than 50 years. He entered hundreds of couples into the bonds of matrimony and comforted the bereaved at more than a thousand funerals.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Embracing Refugees, Then Letting Go
text: “If we keep up like this, they’re just going to become more and more dependent. Maybe we’re giving them unreal expectations for the next 10, 20 years of their lives.”

headline: Corrections: March 26, 2017
text: NATIONAL

headline: The Rankings After Puzzle 6
text: SPECIAL POST — The excitement mounts as the puzzles fall: Dan Feyer is still in the lead, with Erik Agard in second place. Joon Pahk and Tyler Hinman are close behind Mr. Agard.

headline: Boris Epshteyn, Trump TV Surrogate, Is Leaving White House Job
text: Boris Epshteyn, an official in the White House press office who had a contentious relationship with television producers and was once a frequent presence on TV himself, is leaving his job, according to three people with knowledge of the move.

headline: The 2017 Merl Reagle MEmoRiaL Award
text: SPECIAL POST — The crossword world suffered a devastating loss in 2015 with the death of the constructor Merl Reagle.

headline: Oregon Topples Kansas for First Final Four Appearance Since 1939
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — For all of the storied history they can boast, the Kansas Jayhawks were not in the very first Final Four. The Oregon Ducks were.

headline: Lindsey Mitrani, Charles Harris
text: Lindsey Rebecca Mitrani and Charles Louis Harris are to be married March 26 at the University Club of New York. Rabbi Elliot Cosgrove is to officiate with Rabbi Sholom Lipskar, who is to perform the marriage blessings.

headline: Keriann Backus, William Pisarello
text: Keriann Marie Backus, the daughter of Carol A. Sorbie-Backus and Ned A. Backus, was married March 25 to William John Pisarello, the son of Ann M. Pisarello and William J. Pisarello of Copiague, N.Y. The groom’s father, who was appointed a deputy commissioner for the day by San Diego County, led the ceremony at Seagrove Park in Del Mar, Calif.

headline: Jill Weiskopf, Jesse Burros
text: Jill Morgan Weiskopf and Jesse Michael Burros were married March 25 at the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Zalman Rothschild led the ceremony.

headline: Maya Lau, Jesse Hardman
text: Maya Treacy Lau and Jesse Adams Hardman were married March 25 in New Orleans at the home of Tammy Pittman and Benjamin Warnke, who are friends of the couple. Rosie Schaap, a friend of the couple and a minister ordained through the Interfaith Temple, officiated.

headline: Jessica Siebel, Joshua Gruss
text: Jessica Elizabeth Siebel, a daughter of Judy A. Siebel and Kenneth F. Siebel of Ross, Calif., was married March 25 to Joshua Carl Gruss, the son of Agneta Angel of New York and Martin D. Gruss of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Nicholas Vesey, a priest ordained in the Church of England, performed the ceremony at Aspen Chapel in Aspen, Colo.

headline: Sarah Rienhoff, James Novogrod
text: Sarah Wilckes Rienhoff and James Campner Novogrod were married March 25 at the Maryland Club, a private men’s club in Baltimore. The Rev. Susan J. McCone, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

text: Rachel Faith Milen and Michael Ian Nakash were married March 25 at the Ritz-Carlton in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Joey Krakoff officiated.

headline: Lindsay Alper, Andrew Maller
text: Lindsay Royce Alper and Andrew Russell Maller were married March 25 at the Plaza hotel in New York. Rabbi Michael White officiated.

headline: Alexandra Pillat, Todd Hoepker
text: Alexandra Kadyn Pillat and Todd Michael Hoepker were married March 25 at the Dr. Phillips Center for the Performing Arts in Orlando, Fla. Lloyd Schwed, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the groom, officiated.

headline: Natalie Montano, Matthew Young
text: Natalie Helene Montano and Matthew David Young were married March 25 at Il Mercato, an event space in New Orleans. Gina Beard, a New Orleans justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: Hope Stockman, David Smith
text: Hope Monroe Stockman and David Branson Smith were married March 25 at the Ruin, an outdoor event space in Joshua Tree, Calif. The Rev. Donald J. Schell, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Danny Gomez, John McGowan
text: Danny Manuel Gomez and John Francis McGowan were married March 25 at Bow Bridge in Central Park in Manhattan. Edward J. McGowan, who became a minister through Rose Ministries, and is Mr. McGowan’s brother, officiated. On April 11, his brother is to lead them in their vows at Aiguadolç Beach in Barcelona, Spain.

headline: Frank Sheppard, Range Shaw
text: Frank William Sheppard and Range Preston Shaw were married March 25 at their home in Phoenix. Lawrence Winthrop, a judge with Division One of the Arizona Court of Appeals, officiated.

headline: Jennifer Yoon, Gustav Cederquist
text: Jennifer Sung-Ae Yoon, the daughter of Dr. Florence L. Yoon and Dr. David K. Yoon of Ormond Beach, Fla., was married March 25 to Gustav Young-Min Cederquist, the son of Dr. Hyunduck N. Cederquist and Dr. Robert Cederquist of Malvern, Pa. The Rev. Timothy Yoon, a Presbyterian minister and the bride’s paternal grandfather, officiated at the Harvard Club of New York.

headline: Victoria Santana, Adam Goldstein
text: Victoria Gabriela Santana and Adam Sigmon Goldstein were married March 25 at their home in Manhattan. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich officiated.

headline: Amanda McKean, Taylor Brown
text: Amanda Agassiz McKean, the daughter of Lisa McKean and Quincy Adams Shaw McKean III of Rumson, N.J., was married March 25 to Taylor Lansing Brown, a son of Barbara Brown and Stephen R. Brown of Red Bank, N.J. The groom’s father, a Baptist pastor, officiated at the Naples Beach Hotel & Golf Club in Naples, Fla.

headline: Drone Strike Kills Planner of 2008 Islamabad Hotel Bombing, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — A Pakistani militant who planned a devastating truck bomb attack on a hotel in Islamabad in 2008 — which left two members of the American military and dozens of others dead — was killed in recent days by an American drone strike in Afghanistan, the Pentagon said on Saturday night.

headline: Carrie Lam Wins Vote to Become Hong Kong’s Next Leader
text: HONG KONG — A committee dominated by supporters of the Chinese government chose Carrie Lam as Hong Kong’s next leader on Sunday, opting for Beijing’s preferred candidate in a move likely to dismay residents who see the city’s freedoms as being under threat from China.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: The Brontë Sisters and Love in the Mediterranean
text: Travel through Victorian England as the Brontë sisters prove themselves in a man’s world. Then take a Mediterranean vacation with some passionate couples.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
text: 6 Gilman Lane, Cortlandt

headline: Inside the Wooden Worlds of Prayer Beads
text: For centuries, experts were mystified by Gothic boxwood miniatures — intricate scenes carved into walnut-size spheres in the 1400s and 1500s. Now, high-resolution scans bring their detail to life. Step inside the beads yourself in this 360° video.

headline: Health Care, London, Mosul: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Trump vs. Congress: Now What?
text: On Monday, Jan. 9, less than two weeks before President Trump’s inauguration, the House speaker, Paul Ryan, hosted a dinner at his office in the Capitol with members of Trump’s inner circle. The guests included the president-elect’s chief White House strategist, Stephen K. Bannon; his son-in-law and family consigliere, Jared Kushner; his chief of staff, Reince Priebus; his economic adviser, Gary Cohn; his nominee for Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin; his incoming deputy chief of staff, Rick Dearborn; and his legislative-affairs director, Marc Short. The ostensible purpose of the dinner was to discuss the details of Trump’s legislative agenda — in particular, the prospects for a sweeping tax-reform measure that Republicans, and especially Ryan, have been coveting for the past decade.

headline: What Racial Terms Make You Cringe?
text: This is a version of the weekly Race/Related newsletter. To get it in your inbox, sign up here.

headline: China Bars Professor at Australian University From Leaving, Lawyer Says
text: BEIJING — A Chinese-born professor at an Australian university who has often criticized Beijing’s crackdown on political dissent has been barred from leaving China and is being questioned by state security officers as a suspected threat to national security, his lawyer said on Sunday.

headline: In a Twist, It’s Saniya Chong Powering UConn Women’s Basketball
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Saniya Chong fell hard after a rattling foul late in Connecticut’s 86-71 victory over U.C.L.A. on Saturday. She made two free throws, then soon jogged to the sideline. She rinsed a small cut on her lip with a swig of water and spit into a cup, as if the game were being played by rounds instead of quarters.

headline: Looking Back on the Crime Scene That Spanned the Entire City
text: There is a planter on the sidewalk in front of a 7-Eleven on Eighth Avenue in Chelsea. It is intended to cheer the place up, unless one knows how it came to be there.

headline: When a President Says, ‘I’ll Kill You’
text: On the streets of Manila, the body count rises daily as journalists document the crusade of President Rodrigo Duterte.

headline: Before and After Chuck Berry
text: An audio guide to Chuck Berry's influential hits — from what came before to what came after. Listen to the sound of rock ’n’ roll being made.

headline: Going to the Big Boards
text: SPECIAL POST — At this writing, the crowded ballroom of the Stamford Marriott is silent as more than 600 competitors race to finish Joel Fagliano’s Puzzle 7. It’s really just a formality, because the solvers who will compete in the Finals has mostly been determined, but it does give all of the competitors one last chance to say they beat the clock.

headline: Jeanine Pirro Calls for Paul Ryan to Step Down After Health Bill Failure
text: Jeanine Pirro, a Fox News host, is a longtime friend of President Trump. So when Mr. Trump said on Twitter on Saturday — a day after his crushing defeat in the House on health care — that people should watch her show that night, political observers began guessing what was in store.

headline: Angela Merkel’s Re-election Bid Is Buoyed by Widely Watched State Election
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany received a significant lift to her re-election bid on Sunday when her party finished a clear first in a state election that was widely watched as a test of her strength.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Who Killed the Iceman? Clues Emerge in a Very Cold Case
text: BOLZANO, Italy — When the head of a small Italian museum called Detective Inspector Alexander Horn of the Munich Police, she asked him if he investigated cold cases.

headline: Unity, Instead of Fear, After Swastikas Are Carved Into a Church Door
text: “We’ve done a pretty good job of covering them up,” the Rev. Schuyler Vogel said.

headline: What David Rockefeller Wanted Built Got Built
text: David and Nelson were not just the names of two Rockefeller brothers.

headline: Old Man on the Ducks: Dylan Ennis Takes the Long Way to the Final Four
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — On the wall of the bedroom that Oregon point guard Dylan Ennis shared with his younger brother Tyler, there was a makeshift growth chart. Their father had drawn lines and numbers so the brothers could see how tall they were, and the boys turned their heights into a competition.

headline: Adding Homeless Shelters Is a Political Risk, but de Blasio Sees No Alternative
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio embarked this month on one of the more challenging and unenviable tasks of his tenure: selling the virtues of a plan to open dozens of new homeless shelters across the city.

headline: Aleksei Navalny, Top Putin Critic, Arrested as Protests Flare in Russia

headline: Baseball Is Practically a Water Sport to the Mets’ Curtis Granderson

Mobile still and more affable than rumor would have it. Wants steady employment in Hollywood. (Has had Broadway.) References upon request.”

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Wendy’s Back
text: Two weeks ago, I wrote about Wendy Rhoades’s period in exile, and how it has affected both her as a character and a show that relies on her as a unifying element. Her time as a free agent had left Chuck and Axe without the woman they claimed but could not possess, and her re-entry into their lives rekindles a conflict that circumstances had miraculously conspired to resolve. “Billions” isn’t a exactly comedy, but the psychology it assigns to these two Masters-of-the-Universe types emphasizes the absurd gulf between their intellectual capacity and their raw, bone-stupid masculinity. They may sip on fancy scotch or take the private helicopter to dinner, but at heart they’re possessive and tempestuous beasts, like Jake LaMotta in expensive shoes.

headline: Our Delight in Destruction
text: “I, for example,” says the nameless narrator in Fyodor Dostoevsky’s “Notes From Underground (1864),” “would not be the least bit surprised if suddenly, out of the blue, amid the universal future reasonableness, some gentleman of ignoble or, better, of retrograde and jeering physiognomy, should emerge, set his arms akimbo, and say to us all: ‘Well, gentlemen, why don’t we reduce all this reasonableness to dust with one good kick, for the sole purpose of sending all these logarithms to the devil and living once more according to our own stupid will!’ That would still be nothing, but what is offensive is that he’d be sure to find followers: that’s how man is arranged.”

headline: The Bolsheviks Versus the Deep State
text: Vacant offices. Barren corridors. The hush of work not being done settles across the capital city, a silence of memos untyped, papers unpushed, file cabinets sealed shut. The machine of state is not in use. This is not Washington today; it is Petrograd, Russia, 100 years earlier, where after the Bolsheviks seized power in late October, the bureaucrats of the Russian state — tens of thousands of them — locked their desks and pocketed the keys on their way out the door. They declared themselves on strike, protesting what they viewed as the Bolsheviks’ shocking and illegitimate violation of the public trust.

headline: How to Build on Obamacare

headline: A Chia Bowl Recipe From ABC Home’s Newest Restaurant, ABCv

So it was an interesting decision for the duo to offer breakfast first at their newest restaurant, ABCv, which opens at 7:30 a.m. each day (and just began serving dinner last Friday). The morning hours, and to-go options, were inspired by their own morning routines: Upon waking, Vongerichten and Cole each drink water with lemon, and crave foods that will sustain and energize them throughout the day. “Part of the frustration,” Cole says of every New Yorker’s morning rush, “is you want to grab something but half the places only offer the most delicious croissant,” which isn’t necessarily nutritionally supportive.
